resources.string: An ancient and bitter rat by the name of Dagget Filth suggests that the upper portion of the Arcanists' Tower is being stolen, brick and mortar, by jealous planar creatures known as Shadovar. From his account, it appears they covet an artifact called the Dark Wind most of all.
Arcanists' Tower - The Shadow Lich

After fighting through a sea of shadows, you arrive in the High Arcanist's Chambers only to see the lichly ruler of the Shadovar escape back to the safety his plane with the artifact known as the Dark Wind. With the shadow portal closed, you'll have to find some other way into his lair if you intend to steal his prize.
Ashtara

Ashtara, the Asabi merchant, concedes that you have performed your tasks admirably. Concerned for his own safety, however, he has refused to remove the slaver's collar from around your neck. That said, he has no further tasks for you and has granted you the freedom to explore the city as you wish. You can already feel the tremors growing in strength and you suspect it will not be long before Heurodis has freed the ancient city from its mooring.
Ashtara - Golem Destroyed
One of the ten guardian golems has been destroyed. With its fall, you feel one step closer to your freedom.
Two of the ten guardian golems have been destroyed. With its fall, you feel one step closer to your freedom.
Three of the ten guardian golems have been destroyed. With its fall, you feel one step closer to your freedom.
Four of the ten guardian golems have been destroyed. With its fall, you feel one step closer to your freedom.
Five of the ten guardian golems have been destroyed. With its fall, you feel one step closer to your freedom.
Six of the ten guardian golems have been destroyed. With its fall, you feel one step closer to your freedom.
Seven of the ten guardian golems have been destroyed. With its fall, you feel one step closer to your freedom.
Eight of the ten guardian golems have been destroyed. With its fall, you feel one step closer to your freedom.
Nine of the ten guardian golems have been destroyed. With its fall, you feel one step closer to your freedom.
All ten of the guardian golems have been destroyed. Though Ashtara's task was not an easy one, it is now complete. Your master will want to hear news of your accomplishment.
Ashtara - Golem Disabled
One of the ten guardian golems has been disabled through the use of the Golem-Maker's ring. Ashtara's task now seems far less daunting and you can almost taste your freedom from his accursed collar.
Two of the ten guardian golems have been disabled through the use of the Golem-Maker's ring. Ashtara's task now seems far less daunting and you can almost taste your freedom from his accursed collar.

Three of the ten guardian golems have been disabled through the use of the Golem-Maker's ring. Ashtara's task now seems far less daunting and you can almost taste your freedom from his accursed collar.

Four of the ten guardian golems have been disabled through the use of the Golem-Maker's ring. Ashtara's task now seems far less daunting and you can almost taste your freedom from his accursed collar.

Five of the ten guardian golems have been disabled through the use of the Golem-Maker's ring. Ashtara's task now seems far less daunting and you can almost taste your freedom from his accursed collar.
Six of the ten guardian golems have been disabled through the use of the Golem-Maker's ring. Ashtara's task now seems far less daunting and you can almost taste your freedom from his accursed collar.

Seven of the ten guardian golems have been disabled through the use of the Golem-Maker's ring. Ashtara's task now seems far less daunting and you can almost taste your freedom from his accursed collar.

Eight of the ten guardian golems have been disabled through the use of the Golem-Maker's ring. Ashtara's task now seems far less daunting and you can almost taste your freedom from his accursed collar.

Nine of the ten guardian golems have been disabled through the use of the Golem-Maker's ring. Ashtara's task now seems far less daunting and you can almost taste your freedom from his accursed collar.
All ten of the guardian golems have been disabled through the use of the Golem-Maker's ring. Ashtara's task is now complete and you can almost taste your freedom from his accursed collar.
Ashtara - The Golem Emporium

The automatons that still stand guard over the ruined homes of Undrentide continue to advertise their maker's shop, no doubt long since destroyed. It was called the Golem Emporium and was apparently located in the northwest portion of the city though it is hard to say which way had pointed north when this city once flew.
Ashtara - The Golem-Maker's Ring

A ring has been found in the burial chamber of a long-dead Golem-Maker of Undrentide. Judging by the instructions around the outer band, he used it on his golems, deactivating them so he could tinker with their inner workings.
Ashtara - The Slaver's Task

Ashtara, the Asabi merchant who rescued you, also chose to make you his slave. Even though he is trapped within the ruined city and has lost some of his thralls in the collapsed tunnels, his greed continues unabated. He has informed you that ten guardians protect the ruined homes and has ordered you to destroy them so he and his thralls can continue their looting in safety.
Ashtara - The Stone Butler's Love

After so many years, a Stone Butler continues to pine for his long-dead master, the Golem-Maker of Undrentide. He lingers by the man's tomb even now and has confessed that his master wore a ring that kept him safe around his more violent creations.
Crypt Tower
Long protected by the dead of countless ages and the mysteries of the world beyond, the Dead Wind has at last been captured and encased in glass.
Crypt Tower - A Maze of Bones

Above the fiery chambers of the Burning Men lies a maze of bones. By some infernal magic, the walls of this place are there one moment and gone the next. All the while, the skeletons of the dead stalk those who wander their domain, mindlessly seeking to add more to their number.
Crypt Tower - Atop the Tower
The Dead Wind rests atop the shattered Crypt Tower, lost, defenseless, and alone. But nothing is defenseless so long as it has friends and, as for the Dead Wind, it knows how to make its own.
Crypt Tower - Discovery
A crumbling sign has been found along the northern edge of the city, identifying the ruins there as a Crypt Tower of some sort.
Crypt Tower - Disturbing the Dead
Dread sarcophagi glow in the dim light of the Crypt Tower's initial floor. From their stony depths climb an endless stream of the Disturbed, shuffling toward any who dare trespass here.
Crypt Tower - The Burning Men

The second floor of the Crypt Tower is like a furnace, fuelled by the self-flagellation of accursed souls known only as the Burning Men. Despite their name, their fiery torment does not consume them and it seems they shall walk this scorched domain for all eternity.
Heurodis

Heurodis is destroyed, the tatters of her lichly flesh slowly dissolving into dust and scattering with the ferocious wind. You lie there bleeding in the Chamber of the Shattered Mythallar and time itself seems to slow to nothing. The desert floor towards which you plummet seems so far away and desolate. But above you the sky seems so close and beautiful. Smiling, you close your eyes for the last time.
Heurodis - Farewell to the Mythal

The only way to destroy Heurodis has been to destroy the very mythal that protected her. That mythal is also what kept this floating city aloft. The wind screams all around you as, groaning, the city begins to fall. You know your death is imminent but what of Heurodis? She is a lich and no doubt her magic will allow her to survive the fall. You must destroy her here and now or all will be for naught.
Heurodis - The Chamber of the Mythallar

As suspected, Heurodis has been found in the Chamber of the Mythallar atop the Temple of the Winds. Protected by the mythal's power, she has finally raised the city from the sands and the sun of a desert dawn now bathes the ruined city in its glory. Heurodis' madness knows no bounds and she must be stopped.
Heurodis - The Lost City of Undrentide

You have no idea how much time has passed since Heurodis turned you to stone but the lost city of Undrentide remains trapped below the sands, at least for the time being. Even so, the ground continues to shake with tremors and you know that you must hurry if you intend to put a stop to her madness.
Heurodis - The Mythallar

The flying cities of ancient Netheril drew their power from a magic known as the mythal. This magic was somehow associated with artifacts known as mythallar, a fragment of which you once wore on a chain around your neck until Heurodis stole it from you. Here in Undrentide, the mythallar were housed atop the Temple of the Winds and no doubt that is where Heurodis will be found.
Library
There was much to be learned from the magic tomes of fallen Undrentide and much to be gained from their reading. The Wise Wind, who hid within their enchanted pages, has finally been captured.
Library - A Romance Novel

A strange tome discovered in the Great Library of Undrentide appears to have the power to whisk its readers into the very world that it portrays. The tome claimed to be a romance novel of sorts and lo, a young man weeps out his heart into yonder canyon.
Library - A Romance Rewritten
The romance novel in the back room of Undrentide's Great Library has been rewritten.
Library - A Treatise on Forgiveness
The philosophical treatise on the nature of hell has been rewritten to allow for the concept of redemption.
Library - A Treatise on Hell

Tales within tales and tomes within tomes... Buried within the magical realm of the romance novel is another book, this one a philosophical treatise on the nature of hell. It, too, is enchanted to bring its reader into the world that it depicts, fearsome though it might be.
Library - Dark Rituals

Some dark ritual seems to have taken place within this temple. Incense burns with a fetid scent and the body of a fair young maid lies broken beneath it on a skull-shaped dais. Her blood seeps into the dark stone, mingled with the darker blood of summoned demons, now destroyed.
Library - Discovery
A crumbling sign has been found along the eastern edge of the city, identifying the ruins there as being that of the Great Library.
Library - Karsus' Promise

An angel waited within the hellish domain of the revised philosophical treatise. Karsus, Archmage of Netheril, has been redeemed and left a grateful message promising that he would aid in the capture of the Wise Wind.
Library - Poor William

The central character of the romance novel found in the Great Library of Undrentide appears to be a young, lame beggar by the name of William. He fell in love with Jendra, a noble's daughter, and she loved him in return. On discovering their tryst, however, her parents sent her off to a nearby temple where William fears she is coming to great harm.
Library - Sins Against Netheril

In the depths of hell, Karsus, Archmage of Netheril, burns in eternal torment for his hubris. In his arrogance, he destroyed the Netherese empire and sent its floating cities, Undrentide included, plummeting to their doom. Hell made him a humbler man, however, and he wrote his confessions in another magic tome that rests in a back room.
Library - Sir William's Promise
Grateful for his less tragic end within the romance novel's magical realm, Sir William has promised to aid in the capture of the Wise Wind.
Library - The Catching of the Wind
At last the empty tome in Undrentide's Great Library lies empty no longer. A cunning tale has been crafted there and a trap set by which the capture of the Wise Wind might be possible.
Temple of the Winds

The mystery of the Ark of the Three Winds has been solved and the door to the temple now lies open. Even now you can feel the floor rumble and shift beneath you as Heurodis struggles to tap the mythal's power in the temple's upper chambers. It will not be long before she has the city aloft.
Temple of the Winds - An Empty Ark

Much of the wood that once sheathed the Ark of the Three Winds in the temple's outer sanctum has long since crumbled into dust. Its body and hinges were carved from stone, however, and the counter-weighted lid lifts as easily now as the day it was made. Inside, amidst rotten velvet lining, are three round depressions. They look as if they are meant to hold three spheres, each slightly larger than a grapefruit.
Temple of the Winds - Discovery

At the very heart of ruined Undrentide rests a tower unlike any other you have seen. Its glowing walls stretch into darkness of the cavern's upper reaches, seeming almost ethereal in substance yet at the same time invulnerable to even the mightiest of blows. The walls are smooth and seamless, with no apparent entry, though a strange ark rests nearby on the ruined floor, aligned to one of the facets.
Three Winds

All three Winds have been captured and placed within the sacred ark that rested at the base of the Temple of the Winds. Together, they unleashed a whirlwind that rent a hole within the temple's seamless walls and thereby granted entry.
Three Winds - An Ancient Ritual

An ancient ritual once protected the Temple of the Winds, keeping it sealed off from the city that surrounds it. Now that the magic of the mythal has been restored, that seal is once again intact. It cannot be broken without three artifacts known as the Dark Wind, the Dead Wind, and the Wise Wind. One is rumored to be hidden amongst the tomes of Undrentide's Great Library while another was given to the city's High Arcanist that he might protect it. The final Wind was buried in the Crypt Tower where few of the living were ever known to tread. The seal will only be broken when all three can be brought together within the Ark of the Three Winds that rests at the temple's base.
Three Winds - The Dark
The Dark Wind, stolen from its rightful place in the High Arcanists' chambers, has been recovered from the Plane of Shadows.
Three Winds - The Dead
The Dead Wind has been recovered from the heights of Undrentide's dreaded Crypt Tower.
Three Winds - The Wise
The Wise Wind has been recovered from its hiding place amidst the enchanted tomes of the Great Library.
Reference Point
Arrow of the Vampire
No one knows when or where these arrows were made. It is rumored that each tip is made with a vampire tooth. That seems unlikely due to the number of quivers of these arrows that can be found.

Round Oriental Rug
This high-backed throne seems to exude a calming influence as you draw near to it.
This gruesome totem is undoubtably meant as a warning...or a threat.
Noel
Here lies the one-time king of all, Who died because he grew too tall.
Sydney
Here lies the mortal grave of Sydney Who said "I don't need no steenkin' kidney!"
Ross
Lover, wizard, pirate, fool, He choked upon his morning gruel.
Brent
His ways so wise, his manners mild, torn apart by beasts most wild.
Dave
Here he lies forevermore - Listen close and you'll hear him snore.
Jon
Once he was the king's taste tester, 'Til a poisoned meal left him to fester.
Dan
With a pretty wife and children five, 'Tis a shame he isn't still alive.
Keith
Hard is the life of a pleasure slave - Women keep weeping on his grave.
Nolan
From this cold world doth Nolan part, Forever remembered by his art.
Sung
For painting the queen's skin too coarse, he was drawn and quartered by a horse.
Paul
He did not die of mortal sin; 'Twas the music that did him in.
Yaron
A traveller from across the seas, This one died of a nasty sneeze.

Asabis are desert-dwelling reptillian humanoids who are often found as mercenaries or slaves in the service of evil creatures. The average asabi male stands nearly seven feet tall, and their thick, pebbly skin is brown or gray in hue. They have yellow, egg-shaped eyes with horizontal slit pupils.
Crumbling Door
This gate hangs awkwardly on its hinges, its former beauty all but gone. A stout chain binds it, held together by a magical clasp you do not recognize.

This crystal appears to be a long, rough prism. Upon utterance of a command word, the crystal emits bright light of one of three sorts.
The first type of light shines as brightly as a torch. The second type of light shines as a very bright ray that can strike and blind a single target. The last type of light shines in a wide beam out from the gem, blinding all targets in the area.
Helmed Horror
Helmed Horrors are suits of empty armor imbued with magical life and purpose. They make tireless and extremely effective guardians, soldiers, and bounty hunters.
Battle Horror
Battle Horrors are magically animated suits of empty armor. They have a greater array of magic powers than do their lesser kin, Helmed Horrors.

A wise and powerful bard in the Moonshaes named Falataer created the first of these instruments, using them to test and reward the student of his bardic college. Others have since copied the designs, keeping the name Falataer gave them to honor him.
This eight-stringed masterwork mandolin can be played to cast haste, remove curse, and sound burst each once per day.
An adventure designed for 1-4 characters, of levels 7-9.

It appears that some creatures have passed through this area recently. The nature and number of these intruders is unclear.
A small group of humans has passed through this area very recently. The tracks are faint and it is difficult to determine where they lead.
A group of five to ten humans has recently passed through this area. It appears that they did not go through the bridge to the west, but went on the north where their tracks disappear.
The stinger tracks are abundant in this area.
There are several scuff marks amongst the stinger tracks here.
The tracks in this direction are very scuffed and possibly indicate that the stingers were dragging a burden. This is likely the way Zidan was carried off.
There are ghostly footprints in the dust, but they disappear quickly.
Ghostly footprints in the dust seem to indicate the passage of several humanoid creatures through this area.
Ghostly footprints in the dust seem to indicate the passage of five humanoid creatures to the north.
Some tracks and spots of blood indicate someone wounded either came from the north or was headed north.
Some tracks and spots of blood indicate someone wounded came from the north.
Footprints, handprints and a few drops of blood indicate that someone, probably a humanoid, was wounded and stumbled towards the Ao encampment from the North.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
You know we're still a week away from the encampment, brother. And that's with good weather.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Yes, well, I don't like it either. But those Ao fellows do throw a good party.
Sand. It's everywhere, you know.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Yes, there too. Sorry... my brother gets a bit fidgety in the desert.
Now that's not a very nice thing to say to <him/her>.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Oh, well *excuse me* for mis-hearing you, Mister Mumbley-pants.
The desert's not so bad. You always gripe when we're passing through.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Okay, them scorpion fellows aside. It could have been beholders... remember the beholders?
Don't mind him. He had a bit o' bad soup last night. Was belchin' something fierce, let me tell you.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Oh. Well I don't think <he/she> wants to hear *that*.
Ummm... maybe was extra worms Deekin puts in?
He says you have our thanks for finding the guide. Now we can leave.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Well, yes I told <him/her>. Didn't you hear me tell <him/her>?
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Oh. He says you're not so bad... even if you're not a halfling. High praise from him.
Oh. He says that you're one of the bravest halflings he's ever met. Not bad, coming from Mr. Grumpy, here.
This boulder is large enough that it might be climbable to reach the hole above. Doing so will be tricky, however, and there is a possibility of injury.
<StartAction>Leave the boulder alone.</Start>
<StartCheck>[Dexterity]</Start> <StartAction>Climb the boulder.</Start>
Back again, are we? What can Daschnaya do for you now, dear <boy/girl>?
Greetings, dear <boy/girl>. How has your voyage into the great Anauroch been so far?
Impatient, are you? You remind me of Katriana... no time for sentimentality, as she calls such things as legend and history.
Battle is no longer my place, dear <boy/girl>. I travel with Katriana to heal and to advise, and sometimes to remind my fellow halflings that there is more to existence than commerce. Nothing more.
How many times we have crossed this desolate wasteland and never stopped to consider what it once was, a place great for more than its size.
But, then, I am sure you have more on your mind than old tales that have mostly been forgotten. What can Daschnaya do for you?
Then I wish you well, dear <boy/girl>.
It will take me but a moment to find the proper scroll, my dear, and then I will gladly aid you.
I do not have much to show you, dear, but you're welcome to see it.
Your crystal... it radiates with great power. But it is a form of magic that I have never seen before, such raw energy!
I cannot, however, tell you more of its origin... not without guessing, and I do not wish to do that. I am sorry.
Is there something else I may do?
What it is today is plain to see, dear <boy/girl>. All I can tell you is what it once was. Do you know about the Netheril Empire, and how it fell?
As you wish. Is there something else you desire?
Very simple: this desert was not always here. The fall of the Netheril Empire created it. Hostile magic, cursed blight, the destruction of their cities... it turned a verdant land into a desolation.
Try to consider what kind of power could bring ruin to a land larger than the fabled Dales and you will realize why there are many who come to this desert seeking the answers to its mysteries.
Now that is the mystery, isn't it? Whatever happened to the Netherese it happened suddenly. There are many tales but no records of this calamity.
Perhaps their magic simply stopped working, perhaps they were attacked... perhaps the gods struck them down because their pride was so great.
However it happened, one day the flying cities of the Empire crashed to the ground and their power was no more. Lost to time and legend, as they say.
Traces, perhaps. Ruins, scattered artifacts, perhaps more buried beneath the sand under our feet. Little more.
Think on this: there is a legend of a single surviving set of scrolls from this Empire that is said to contain enough power to change Faerun forever.
Imagine for yourself what more might exist that has not yet been uncovered. All mysteries are solved in the end... don't you agree?
Mmmm. The Netherese Scrolls. Aye, what Xanos would not do to stumble across artifacts such as that.
They say that the Anauroch is nothing more than the corpse of the Empire buried under the sand of time. There have been great wonders unearthed here, <FirstName>, trust me.
There be flying city buried under Deekin's feet?
Very possibly, little one. If one of us knew the answer to that, who knows what power we might possess?
Ages ago this desert was not as you see it now. It was a lush land filled with the Netherese people... humans who commanded magic the power of which has not been seen since.
They ruled all that the Anauroch now encompasses, and likely further as well. They built great structures that awed all, and most fabled were their flying cities.
Imagine, dear <boy/girl>, the power it would take to lift a mountain into the air and build a glorious city on it. And the Netheril Empire had many.
It is said that whatever caused the Empire to fall brought their great cities crashing to the ground. You do not see mountains flying in the air today, do you?
There are rumors, but no doubt they are only that. Can you imagine if a city such as that did exist today? An unassailable fortress filled with magic and power beyond measure.
Deekin sees Old Master fly, once. That come pretty close... Old Master was pretty fat.
Fabled, indeed. These are tales and nothing more.
Are you so certain, my friend? There is much evidence that would prove you wrong. Perhaps you will find some for yourself.
I've read of those. It's said that the Netherese took the tops from whole mountains and made them fly, and it was on those that the cities were built.
As you wish. Since my cards were returned to me, I have in fact spent a great deal of time attempting to discern more of what is to come for you... in anticipation of your asking.
It is not an easy path you are on, dear <boy/girl>. The mission that you were sent here for involves much more than you believe it does.
Before it is over, you must confront one whose face is hidden from me. You will suffer great personal loss and all will seem lost... but do not despair!
There is still hope, but when you act remember that there is far more than your own life at stake. You *must* ascend the tower.
That is not clear to me. It may not even be an actual tower... but always with you the Tower card is the last I draw. Always.
The Tower card depicts a great tower being broken in two by a stroke of lightning. It symbolizes destruction, an end... a great fall due to pride. That is where your destiny lies.
Perhaps. Or it will be the one you must confront who falls due to pride. Look on this as your opportunity to decide which it shall be.
Such advice rarely is clear until it is past being of use... such is the nature of prophecy. I do urge you, however, to think on what I have said.
Eh? This 'tower' you speak of. It is a card that means a fall from a great height, yes? Something great coming to ruin?
Hmmm. I wonder if that has anything to do with the tower statue. That's where the crystal was, after all.
The Tower could represent what you speak of, yes, but also a great many other things as well.
You means like little broken tower statue, maybe?
I speak of the Tower card, little one, though it may very well represent what you speak of... and a great many other things, as well.
Not one as I did before, perhaps, for your destiny has not changed. I can, however, provide you some limited advice on your immediate future... that is up to you.
I can also offer you any healing you might need, as well as access to my limited supply of potions and scrolls... should you desire them.
I'm almost hesitant to ask... but is it possible for others to get a reading, as well?
Naturally, my dear. Be aware, however, that you may not like what I have to tell you.
Why would you say that? Is there something you already know about my future?
I... see sadness, my dear. If you wish to know more about it, we could certainly sit down and I could do a full reading for you.
Actually, come to think of it, I'd rather not know. If there's sadness to come, I don't want to stand around wondering what I could do to stop it. Thank you anyhow.
Hmph. Xanos finds it hard to believe that you hold any true power, old woman.
I may not have the sort of power that you seek, my friend, but if you believe me devoid of knowledge then why did you steal in here yesterday asking for a reading?
Xanos did no such thing!
I see. My mistake. Perhaps you thought we were playing a simple game of diamondback, yes?
Bah. Your technique is flawed, anyhow. You are supposed to tell Xanos he gets rich and powerful, not that he dies alone and other drivel.
You may choose to listen or not. That is your choice, my friend.
Ooooo... that sounds neat! Can you reads Deekin's future?
I have already read your future this very trip, little kobold. How very different do you think the outcome will be already?
Oh. Deekin was hopings for future where he not gets eaten by big monster. That too much to ask?
<StartAction>[chuckle!]</Start> It is destiny that swallows you, little one, and not any creature. Ponder my other words to you and perhaps then we can speak again.
I can offer you healing, free should you need it. I also have a limited supply of potions and scrolls and similar goods... for a small fee, I'm afraid.
I would also have once offered to look into your future... alas, I lost my cards to the looting kobolds in Hilltop. Perhaps one day I will find some new ones.
It may not be much assistance to one as skilled and powerful as you are, dear <boy/girl>, but I can only do what I can.
Since my cards were so kindly recovered, I can also offer you advice on your future... should you choose to hear it, that's up to you.
Then you are fortunate, for many find the prospect of crossing this desolation a terrible one indeed. The Anauroch was not always as you see it, however. Once it was great for more than its size.
It is a desolate place, that's true. An immense wasteland that stretches for many leagues in every direction. But it was not always so... once it was great for more than its size.
Enough with the pleasantries. I have questions.
Fine, except for the fighting... which you didn't join in.
I should be going
I need some healing.
I'd like to see what you have in stock.
<StartAction>[Show her the crystal.]</Start> Have you ever seen anything like this?
Tell me what you know about this desert.
I don't need to know any of this.
What does that have to do with this desert?
Why did the Empire fall?
There are no traces of it?
Tell me about the Netheril Empire.
That's all I need to hear.
Flying cities? Do they still exist?
I could use some advice on my future.
Tower? What tower?
Are you saying that *I* will fall due to pride?
This is of no help at all.
Bah! I don't believe any of this!
Thank you very much.
Can you give me another reading?
I don't know. What can you do for me?
It's been tolerable, so far.
It doesn't seem so great to me.
You don't suppose we'll see some Asabi again, do you?
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Okay, okay, forget I mentioned it. My brother has this *thing* against them Asabi. Just because they tried to eat him once. Pfft.
Blech. I got sand in my mouth. Again.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Hmm. Come to think of it, you're right, brother. That *does* taste like last night's soup, doesn't it?
Crimeny! I wonder how long the trip through the desert's going to be this time!
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Shush, you. I don't need to hear that kind of talk when we still got more than a week to go.
I suppose you'll be trying to find that guide, then, hey?
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
He may still be alive, brother. You have to try and think positive.
What are the chances that guide's still alive, you think?
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
True. If it had been the Asabi, like my brother said, then the guide would be a goner for sure. Lizard folk having funny tastes and all.
That poor guide. Torias says they'll be sucking all the juices out of him before morning comes.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Really? I'm not so sure I'd want to see that.
Well, now, isn't that the guide there?
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Sure it is. And he doesn't have any of his inner juices sucked out at all. Are you sure you're the guide we started out with, you?
Err... yes. I am Zidan, complete with bodily juices, yes...
Huh. Well, go figure.
Aren't we leaving yet? The guide's back now, isn't he?
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Quiet, you. The sooner we get underway, the sooner we'll get to the Ao encampment.
If you got any business, you might want to talk to Katriana.
Ughh... what was in the soup this morning?
That kobold's not exactly the best cook. My stomach is grumblin' something fierce...
Hmph. You know, I bet anyone we meet will just assume the big folk here are in charge.
Heh... have you seen 'em big folk trying to sleep in the wagons? Pretty funny.
Hey there. Always nice to have some regular-sized folk about.
You're not so frightenin', you know. Gigantic as you are and all.
You large folk can't find the wagons too comfortable, I bet.
How are you faring, big 'un?
Ahh!
Grrr!
Short doesn't mean weak!
That's it! You're dead!
Pick on a halfling, will you?!
Take that!
You're askin' for it!
I'll get you!
You are too kind, my <lord/lady>.
Thank you for aiding me.
Ahh... that feels much better.
Much obliged!
You have my thanks!
I am completely healed... thank you!
This recently-burrowed hole leads down into what appears to be an underground cave. With nothing to tie a rope to and no clear way to descend, climbing down into the cave may be tricky.
<StartAction>Leave the hole alone.</Start>
<StartCheck>[Dexterity]</Start> Climb down into the hole.</Start>
This recently-burrowed hole leads down into what appears to be an underground cave. With nothing to tie a rope to and no clear way to descend, climbing down into the cave may be tricky.
What? What did I do that would be worthy of such a suspicious tone, I wonder?
I have two words for you, dear cousin. "Bandits" and "asleep while on watch".
That's more like five words. And besides, I had a full stomach that night. You can't expect a man to stay awake all night after eating a full pot roast, can you?
<StartAction>[Sigh.]</Start> Just be careful, will you? Daschnaya's predicted some trouble and I don't want to take any chances.
Hmph. Daschnaya's always predicting trouble...
Between you and your companions and that odd little kobold we hired on outside of Hilltop, our group is much larger than it normally is. I'm surprised we haven't drawn more attention by now.
I trust crossing the desert isn't completely unbearable? You'll be alright for the night?
I'll leave you alone, then. You can handle yourself, I'm sure. Just be careful... the desert gets colder than you'd think during the night. And don't wander too far from the fire.
If you need any assistance or have any questions, Zidan here can help you out. He's the guide I hired for us back at Blacksands.
I would be most pleased to help however I am needed.
Yes, well... that's good. As for me, the desert makes me tired and cranky. I'm going to bed. Good night to you both.
Not much. This caravan isn't meant for carting along passengers, after all. Still, I wouldn't want you dropping dead from heat exhaustion or the like.
Actually, I would have thought we'd have had a bit of trouble before now. There's no way we can pass through the Anauroch unnoticed with a caravan this crowded.
Daschnaya knows that, too. But she wouldn't say anything if it was just a hunch... and that makes me nervous. I'd suggest sleeping with your hand on your blade.
Hmm. Well, the big half-orc kept complaining about the sand and finally went indoors a couple of hours ago. Can't imagine what he's up to.
As for the dwarven lass, I think she wandered off to eat her dinner alone. Hope she doesn't get too far from camp... it's not safe out there.
As for the dwarven lass, she's right here with you. Been whispering sweet nothings with Torias for half the trip, I see.
Just exchanging trade secrets. Nothing more than that.
Are we talking about the same Torias?
I did have to threaten to break all of his fingers once. He's been a perfect gentleman ever since, I assure you.
I'll have to remember that trick. My cousin can be a bit of a handful.
Well, your big half-orc friend is right here as you can obviously see. He's rather hard to miss.
Pfah. The "big half-orc" has a name, little squishable halfling girl.
I know I've thought of a few.
That is funny. Xanos will remember to laugh when a giant desert bird swoops down and carries you off to become a very tiny snack.
Keep it up, sorcerer, and you can sleep with the oxen.
I did. Haven't you seen him? My first impulse was that it wouldn't be a good idea considering the trouble we had earlier... but this fellow seems pretty earnest.
Not only that, he seemed pretty desperate to hire on. I'm paying him almost nothing... although his cooking skills have been pretty questionable. I suppose you get what you pay for.
That's it. I'd almost forgotten. He spends all day with Daschnaya, so I've barely seen him... she seems to have taken a shine to the creature, oddly enough.
I'm surprised you haven't spotted him. He mentioned you several times when we first spoke.
Oh, something about you being a great hero and how he wanted to be just like you. It was cute, actually.
I must admit, it took awhile before I got accustomed to it. You've got more on your mind than just traveling, however, I suppose.
If you like. You might want to wait until the morning, however, as mostly everyone's retired for the evening. It's up to you.
Not now!
Those? Stingers, they're called. Half man, half scorpion. I haven't seen them on the last two trips through... it was too much to hope that I'd never see them again, I see.
But that's not important, right now. Have you see Zidan or not?!
No, he's not! He was out here, fighting... I saw him! Damn it anyway, we *need* him in order to cross the desert!
I don't mean to sound uncaring, <FirstName>, but the plain fact is that we *need* Zidan in order to cross the desert!
You might not care either way, but that doesn't change the fact that we *need* him! How else are we supposed to cross the desert?!
Torias! Is there any sign of him?!
Ah, where is that drunkard of a brother? Oh, I see him. Maybe he is looking for Zidan, too.
Nope. Nothin'. He's just up an' vanished, as near as I can tell.
Damn it! I knew this was too good to be true! We can't go anywhere without our guide or we'll be lost for sure!!
Split up my men so that the stingers can pick them off one by one? Not on your life, <FirstName>. We don't do things that way.
Let me put it this way: we can head back to Blacksands and hope we don't get lost en route and delay our trip by about a week hiring a new guide.
Or you can volunteer yourself to go and look for Zidan and pray to the gods that those stingers haven't torn him apart for a late-night snack. Your choice.
Good. I'm glad that's settled. Should you need any supplies, by the way, I have plenty to sell you now.
Excellent. We'll keep an eye out for you. Don't take any foolish risks unless you absolutely have to.
Oh, and don't expect to be sneaking up on the stingers, from what I have been told, they have a special ability to detect vibrations, so they will know you are coming.
You mean like chasing after poisonous creatures into their own lair in the middle of an unfamiliar desert?
You mean besides the foolish risk we are already undertaking.
Correct. I'm glad we understand each other.
Is that so? There's something wrong with earning <CUSTOM1010> gold, I suppose? What did you have in mind?
Don't mind if I do.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Alright, then. Have it your way... *another* 100 gold on top of your reward. You drive a hard bargain.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> No, I don't think you really need any more incentive than you already have. Off you go.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Hmph. Fine, fine. Another 100 gold it is. You're robbing me blind, however, you know that?
I trust that's finally enough for you. Now... don't you have a guide to find?
Be that as it may, gold is all I really have to offer. Take it or leave it.
So that's the way it is, is it? Sorry, but unless you can turn into a halfling on the spot, there's just no future between us. Let's keep our mind on business, shall we?
You're not bad for a halfling, but let's keep our mind on business, shall we? I don't like to get the two mixed up.
I'd sooner kiss a stinger. Let's keep our mind on business, shall we?
Oh no you don't. I'm paying you all I can afford to. Try to milk any more out of me and it'll be more profitable to turn around and head back to Blacksands, it will.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> I suppose I really don't like the possibility of a delay any more than you do... but I'm hardly in a position to be throwing about gold.
How about this: I'll give you five hundred gold if you bring the guide back. Then I'll talk to him about how much of that is coming out of his own pay.
That's enough of a reward, isn't it? Now, is there something else?
Oh? What might those be?
Very well. Anything else you'd like?
Not really. Just don't go out there alone... and speak to Daschnaya if you get hurt. She can mend you up just fine, I'm sure.
I don't. I've heard, however, that stingers take slaves... we can only hope that was their intent. At least they'd keep him alive.
We're not very far in, but if I were you I wouldn't pin your hopes on the scenery becoming very varied. That's why it's so easy to get lost here... only a native can tell one sand dune from the next.
More than I'd like. The guides tend to give their hives a wide berth, but the creatures tunnel under the earth and spring up to ambush you.
Most of them only look like men... really they're feral and vicious beasts who think only of blood-letting and gathering slaves. Some of them can be quite intelligent, however.
I've heard tell of stinger mages and priests, but I've never seen one. All I know is that it's best to avoid the poison in their tail... deadly stuff, that.

Daschnaya made some antidotes once that might work. Try talking to her. Oh... and if you manage to kill any of those stingers, feel free to bring me their poison glands. Worth a pretty coin, they are.
For the usual. Slaves. Food. Bounty. Where one of us ranks on that list I really couldn't say... I've never heard tell of anyone escaping them before.
That's a good question. I explained to your Master Drogan that there's no guarantee that your friend Garrick will still be where we dropped him off, but he seemed unconcerned.
About a week's travel into the desert, there's a small temple encampment that we tend to stop at. Worshippers of Ao... harmless folk, really.
This Garrick fellow seemed to think that was where he needed to be. Talked a lot about "excavations" and similar kinds of work.
I think he was on the lookout for ruins dating back to the old Netheril Empire, actually. Your Master Drogan said he's something of an expert on the topic... I'm not surprised.
No doubt it will require even more mindless wandering in the desert once we get there. Hmph.
No doubt. But that's not my responsibility.
Master Drogan said he knew this man Garrick, so we'll have to trust that he knows best.
Sure thing. Watch the sticky fingers, however... I have enough trouble keeping my eyes on Torias.
This is your show, <FirstName>, and not mine. I didn't ask you to come along, remember? I have to make a living and not give all my goods away for free.
You may be a halfling, but you're not my cousin or my <brother/sister>, are you? I have to make a living and not give my goods away for free.
With that said, I'm sure I can come up with a reasonable discount for you, seeing as I'd rather see Zidan saved than not. Fair enough?
As I see it, you're the one who needs to find that fellow we dropped off so badly. We're not the ones in a rush to get across the desert.
So you can either get off your backside and earn your keep or you can sit tight and accept the delay. That's not blackmail, that's just the way it is.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> None of us get exactly what we want, now, do we? Isn't this the sort of adventuring you like to do anyway? So go to it... adventure!
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> I suppose I really don't like the possibility of a delay any more than you do... but I'm hardly in a position to be throwing about gold.
How about this: I'll give you five hundred gold if you bring the guide back. Then I'll talk to him about how much of that is coming out of his own pay.
So I trust that's settled, then? Should you need any supplies, by the way, I have plenty in store to sell you now.
Take one of your friends from the school. That's what they're here for, aren't they? Or take that kobold, Deekin, with you... he seems eager enough.
But I need everyone else here to guard the caravan in case those things decide to come back. You won't begrudge us that, I hope.
I really don't know. But there has to be some evidence around that shows where the stingers came from, doesn't there?
I don't propose that it will be an easy task to find Zidan and bring him back, but what choice do we have, really?
You know a little about tracking and such, don't you? Find out where the stingers came from, follow them back to their lair!
Yes, of course, but none of us are natives! The Anauroch Desert is huge! Unless you want to risk wandering off to your death, you have a guide with you!
What? Why not?! Don't just leave him out there... we need him!
You found him? Then you'll have to go back! Quickly, go!
That's progress, at least. Keep on looking... he must be in there somewhere.
Damn. Well... what can I do to help?
I would not advise that, Madame Katriana.
Neither would I, to be honest. It's good to have you back... none the worse for your experience, I see.
That is true. The thanks must go to <FirstName> for that.
True enough. Well, <FirstName>... you rescued Zidan, as you said you would. I suppose you'll be wanting your <CUSTOM1010> gold?
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Fine, fine... though I'll point out we *did* have a deal., and that all this urgency to cross the desert is your doing, not mine!
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> The offer was <CUSTOM1010> gold and you'll get <CUSTOM1010> gold and not a copper more. No hard feelings, but business is business.
As for you, Zidan, we'll have to discuss just what your rescue is worth in relation to our deal...
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> I suppose so... even though we *did* have a deal, as you'll recall. I'm grateful, however, so I'll overlook that.
So here, then... <CUSTOM1010> gold. Hopefully I'll make up for that in trade. We'll also need to discuss what your rescue is worth in relation to our deal, Zidan.
I... I... yes, of course, Madame Katriana...
But... but I have already paid <FirstName> for my rescue!
That's between you and <him/her>, isn't it? It doesn't have anything to do with me... or your fee, as the case may be.
Now, then... I trust we're ready to move on? <FirstName>?
Right, then. Don't take all day, though... I don't need to wait until something else descends upon us here. Tell me when you're done.
Good. Torias, what's the delay?! Why aren't we moving yet?!
And here I was enjoying this relaxing stop of ours...
I said move it, lazy bones! Everyone on your feet... we leave NOW!
What?! After all those demands and such? You're a strange one, <FirstName>, I'll give you that. I'll take it, though, and give you my thanks.
And you, Zidan, are one lucky man. That reward was going to come out of your pay.
You... are too kind, Madame Katriana...
Don't I know it.
<StartAction>[snicker!]</Start>
I can find you something to do, cousin, if you've got enough spare time to be eavesdropping.
Err... but I have already given much of my gold to <FirstName>...
Well that sounds appropriate somehow, don't you think? It was <FirstName> who risked <his/her> neck to save you.
True enough. Well, <FirstName>, you rescued Zidan just as I'd hoped you would. I suppose you'll be wanting a reward?
Fair enough. How does <CUSTOM1010> gold grab you?
Fair enough. You, my dear Zidan, are one lucky man... that reward was going to come out of your pay.
Oh. Fair enough, I suppose... you're a kind <man/woman>. You have my sincere thanks in return.
Hmph. I suppose you're right... though I hate over-paying the help. Here, then, Zidan. For all the trouble.
Thank you kindly, Madame Katriana. And you, as well, <FirstName>... this is most unexpected.
Yes, well... we're just glad that you're safe, that's all.
When did I become invisible? <FirstName> wasn't the only one there, you know.
Of course, my lady. You have my apologies... I did not mean to exclude you.
Oh yes. Let's forget the half-orc was at all involved, shall we? Bah.
My apologies, sir. Of course you deserve my gratitude, as well.
I'll be fine. Don't worry about me.
And if I'm not alright? What are you going to do about it?
Do you think there's going to be trouble?
Where are my companions?
Did you say you hired a kobold?
Is his name Deekin?
He did? What did he say?
I should get some sleep.
Bah. I hate this desert.
Maybe I should go and speak to him.
Wait one second... what *were* those creatures?!
I don't know. Is he in one of the wagons?
Thank you for the personal concern and gratitude.
Who cares? He probably fell in battle.
Do you want me to look for him?
Go and look for him, then, if you're so worried.
We'll just have to make do without him, won't we?
Very well. I will do what I can.
I should be going.
I think we need to re-negotiate my reward, first.
Forget about it.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> I want another 100 gold.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> I want another 100 gold.
I think we still need to negotiate.
I want something in return besides just gold.
I was thinking about something a little more personal...
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> I could use a little incentive from you for this mission.
I have some questions.
I have no more questions.
Do you have any advice for me?
How do you know this Zidan isn't dead?
What can you tell me about this desert?
What do you know about these stingers?
Is there anything that can counter that poison?
Why would they have attacked the caravan?
Just where will I find Garrick, anyway?
What kinds of excavations? Did he say?
Show me what you have in stock.
I have to *buy* my supplies off of you?
I don't appreciate being blackmailed into helping.
Fine. You don't leave me much choice.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> I could use a little incentive.
I don't suppose I get any help in this, do I?
Just how am I supposed to look for him?
Wait a second, I thought you'd been across this desert before?
I rescued Zidan, but haven't brought him back yet.
I found Zidan, but I haven't been able to rescue him yet.
I've found the stingers' caverns, but no sign of Zidan yet.
No, I haven't found him yet.
Sounds good to me.
<StartCheck>[Intimidate]</Start> This was harder than I'd bargained for. I want compensation... now.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> I think I deserve a bit more than that, don't you?
I have something to do, first.
Yes, let's go.
Forget about it. We can leave, now... that's good enough for me.
You're damned right I do.
We can leave, now... that's reward enough for me.
Getting Zidan back alive is reward enough.
Give it to Zidan. He deserves it for what he's been through.
Talona grant us victory!!
Hsss!! Perish!!
Fool! Here you shall die!
You shall be sacrificed to the Lady of Poison!
The Lady of Poison shall drink your blood!
Hsss! You will die in agony!
Talona shall have your soul!
Mm. I could go for some water. It seems my flask has nothing but wine in it... I wonder who did that?
Eh. Don't mind me. Maybe you should be talking to Katriana... she's getting that look like she's about to explode, you know?
Do you have sand in your ears? I think I have sand in my ears. I hate the bloody desert.
Now that's a shame. Guide's gone missin', here we are stuck in the middle of the desert at the mercy of scorpion men... sounds like it's time for a drink.
Hmmmn. Can't say I've ever gotten drunk much with <race> folk like yourself. Tried some <race> ale once. Vile stuff, no offense. Blech.
You know, I had a woodsy acquaintance once much like yourself. Had a knack for turning tree sap into a swill that would lay me flat for a week. Wonderful chap.
Heh... last time a saw a magely type like yourself drink, we had to clear the entire bar after he tried to light his pipe. You know... drunken fireball and such.
I must admit, I would've thought you holy types to be a bit more stodgy about the spirits. You know... that whole holier-than-thou bit. Good to see that isn't the case.
Would you believe Katriana doesn't drink? Not even a fine ale. She's not like you and me, aye... I say let halflings be halflings!
You know... come to think of it, I don't think I've ever seen elves drink anything other than honeydew-smelling stuff. But they must, I suppose... they make a lovely wine.
You know, I've always liked getting drunk with a decent gnome. Not that there are many. Decent gnomes, I mean... there's plenty of them other kinds.
And remain hyper-conscious for all the fear and paranoia that's sure to set in while we're waitin' on you? No thanks. This seems quite called for, thank you very much.
Pfft. Now you're starting to sound like Katriana. Personally, there's not much else that I'd *want* to think about.
Ahhh. Now that's what I call a remedy for danger.
Now then. What can I do for such a lovely lady such as yourself?
Yep. I'll raise a toast for you while you're gone. Best keep your hopes up and not assume that guide is all bloated and poisoned-like by now, eh?
Stay here, stay drunk. We'll make our way back to Blacksands eventually. But, then, you're in kind of a hurry, aren't you? Very sad, really.
Eccchh... not much. Poisonous as a desert viper, though, I'll tell you that. You can cut out those glands, by the way. Worth good gold, they are.
Hah! I'd like nothing better, actually. But Katriana'd have my hide. She wants me here guarding the caravan, an' not wandering off doing something interesting for once.
An' besides... it looks like you've got all the help you can handle between that snarly half-orc an' that fine dwarven lass. Mmm, I like her.
And then there's always that eager kobold Katriana hired on. I could use him away from dinner for a while... you take my meaning?
And Deekin! You not forgets about help you gets from Deekin!
You hired on that smelly little cook? That's a new one.
Deekin is good cook!
I don't even want to know what was in that soup last night. Maybe it's best that <FirstName> takes you with, you take my meaning?
Yes. Deekin gets to be great hero!
Right, right. Off you go, then.
You're too kind, Torias.
Mmmn. And that form-fitting leather of yours. Yup, I like that, too.
I take it back.
Who are you calling snarly, little pipsqueak?
Well... you, actually.
That is good. Just so long as we are clear, you and I.
Eh. Not much. Katriana's a fine cousin, but she tries to keep me working from dawn to dusk, you know? But the caravan's not so bad, I s'pose.
If you ever need some goods of the not-so-legitimate kind... you know who to talk to. Never mind the vanilla stock Katriana sells.
Oh... here and there. You know. A bit from this town, a bit from that village. It's all good.
You want to see what Torias has in his booty bag, eh? Well, alright... just not a word to the cousin or that's it for my side business.
Now then. What can I do for such a fine lad such as yourself?
Hmmn. I knew another bard, once, who actually sang better after a bottle or two of elven wine. Offended everyone in the room, for sure, but he sounded good.
Hmmn. I once knew this monk who believed drunkeness was next to godliness. Didn't bathe much, either. Had a wicked belch, though.
Hmmn. I remember a certain rogue who got so drunk he fell off a roof in mid-heist. Not, ummm, anyone you would know or anything...
Hmmn. I remember this ranger who I used to share an ale with. He put an arrow in the mayor's backside by accident. Laughed all the way to the stockade, he did.
Hmmn. I remember this druid who would magically grow grapes in the grove and make the best wine. They found him in a vat one morning. Sad, really.
Hmmn. We had this dwarven barbarian who came into town when I was growing up. Acquired a secret fixation for gnomish brandy. Sad case, really.
Hah! I knew a warrior once who refused to go into battle unless he was tanked up on dwarven ale. Then he'd pass out and the enemy'd think he was dead. Lived a long time, though.
Hmmn. I knew a paladin once who had a little fixation for mead. Seems someone told him nothing so sweet could be alcoholic. Not the brightest fellow, I'll admit. Kept falling off his horse.
Hmmn. I knew a priest once who we used to find on the steps of Brandobaris's temple every twelve-day. Gave good sermons. On the other days, I mean.
Aye? Then here... I have an extra flask. Don't tell Katriana it came from me, however.
Aye? You haven't dug up that guide yet, eh? No, I s'pose I'd have heard about that by now.
Well I'll be a wee skinned kitty. You're alive after all, Zidan!
This is true. I am alive... and grateful.
No offense, but I sort of thought you'd be a bloated corpse with a bunch of scorpion kiddies sucking the bodily fluids out of you by now. Gosh, lucky.
Err... yes... that is quite an image you conjure...
Well, <FirstName>, you'd best trot him over to Katriana. Maybe she'll actually stop to breathe, for once.
You bet I am. Short on spirits, too... I'm eager to find the next outpost.
Err... I'm sure Katriana will want to see Zidan, ya know.
Well, are we going to be underway yet? What's the catch? I'm short on spirits here!
If you wish. It doesn't bother me.
Don't you think you should stay sharp, just in case?
Drink? Is that all you can think about?
I should go.
Do you have any advice for me?
Do you know anything about these stingers?
How would you like to join me to look for the guide?
Just what do you do around here, anyway?
And just where do you get your goods?
I'd like to see what you have for sale.
I'll join you, if you don't mind.
Perhaps you're right.
Greetings. I am most pleased to be the one who shall lead this caravan through the great desert. My name is Zidan.
I... I am free! Oh, what sheer relief! I am forever grateful to you, <sir/madam>! How can such a rescue ever be repaid?
It was a close thing. The creatures were about to sacrifice me to their dread goddess... in a manner I would not wish on my worst enemy.
Please... I will follow you out of this place. I saw very little when I was dragged in, I do not think I can find my way out on my own.
Really? Xanos can not think of many things he would not wish on his worst enemies.
Then it is fortunate we came when we did. You are a lucky man.
I agree whole-heartedly, my lady. I will feel safer, however, once we have returned to the caravan.
Really? What kind of way is that? Deekin needs to know... he gots to write it down.
I would rather not think of it, kobold.
Okay. Deekin just makes something up, then. He just thinks back to what Old Master would do... and that is lots, let Deekin tells you.
I... I have only the gold Madame Katriana forwarded me when I was hired. These scorpion creatures saw no need to take it, I suppose. It... it is not much, however.
There is no need to threaten my life, <sir/madam>... I know what you have done for me. It is just that... the only other thing I possess is an heirloom of my family line...
As... as you wish. Here, the heirloom and gold both.
That is it? Bah! If we did not need you to guide us out of this forsaken desert, I would recommend to <FirstName> that <he/she> kill you anyway.
I don't mind lifting a few coins now and then from those who can spare it, but <FirstName>... really, isn't this beneath you?
Dibs! Dibs on gold! Deekin calls dibs!
Then take it. It would not have meant anything had I been killed, no?
Ummm... be easier to collect, though, maybe.
I am grateful never the less. If you had not arrived when you did, the creatures would surely have sacrificed me to their dread goddess!
What? You mean she comes and eats you? I needs to know... Deekin gots to write this all down.
Spare us the melodrama, little man. You are needed to guide us, and that is the only reason you live. Be thankful.
It appears they worship Talona, the goddess of poison. I can't imagine her methods of sacrifice are exactly... pleasant.
Please! I... I am being held here by a... a magical force! Free me, I beg you!
What would you have of me, <sir/madam>?
As you wish, but do not be gone for long. I do not wish to be taken by these creatures once more.
It will be a relief. Lead on.
I owe you my life, <sir/madam>. I shall always be grateful for your assistance.
No need. I'm just happy you're unharmed.
Gold sounds fine, or something better if you have it.
Then forget it. It's not worth my time.
Cough up something better or I kill you here, fool!
Oh, never mind. This isn't worth my time.
Keep it. The gold will have to do.
That should suffice.
I will take it anyway.
I wouldn't have bothered if you weren't needed to guide the caravan.
Never mind.
Stay here for a moment.
Come with me now.
I... I won't be able to survive much longer!
They wish to sacrifice me! Please hurry!
If you have any mercy in your heart, free me!
You... you are from the caravan! Please, help me! I beg you!
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Yes, there was a foul taste to dinner last night.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Well, nobody ever said that a kobold was a proper cook, but he volunteered.
Deekin hear that.
Foul taste? But Deekin uses perfect amount of ox urine, just like mammy did!
There is no such thing as a wookalar.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
No, Uncle Duffer was eaten by a manticore, not a wookalar.
Now that's not a very nice thing to say to <him/her>.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
You did too. Don't blame my hearing everytime I call you out for saying nasty things.
The Bedine're not so bad. You just don't like their camels.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
No, I guess the hungry Bedine must have killed all the camels. I guess the nomads are good for something after all.
Watch your tongue there, Birgen. It's not him that smells, it's you.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Once we get access to the water, I'm going to soak your head for a bit.
What do you think are worse, stingers or ill-tempered dwarves?
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Yes, it is more acceptable to smack a stinger with a hammer.
I promise, if you continue to make rude comments about me, you will find out just how much worse a dwarf can be.
That half-orc nearly squashed me flat last night when I went to bed.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
What do you mean it was an ox? Oh, I guess that's what the smell was.
I did no such thing and I resent the accusation!
Crimeny! This trip through the desert's taking a long time!
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
If you're so thirsty, mister grumbles, why don't you go deal with the problem? I didn't think so.
Hope we can get to that water soon.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
Quiet, you. The sooner we get underway, the sooner we'll get to the Ao encampment.
So we got the water we need? That's a relief.
<StartAction>[grumble... mumble...]</Start>
So what? There's nothing wrong with wanting a bath. You should try it yourself sometime, brother.
I see you have returned. Have you gotten permission to take their water?
It should not be this difficult, <FirstName>. Please hurry. I do not wish to linger here.
Holy Yondalla, <FirstName>! I give you the simplest of jobs and already you have forgotten?
Go to the Bedine and negotiate for water for our caravan. Please. I hope I do not have to write this down for you!
Good luck.
Ummm... Deekin gots notes here, somewhere, just holds on...
Never mind that, kobold. I am perfectly capable of reminding <him/her>.
You wouldn't believe the number of blows <FirstName> takes to the head every day. Really it is a wonder <he/she> can remember not to drool most of the time.
I wonder if that is what is wrong with Torias? No, I suppose that's just because of the drink.
Are they still adamant about the ban on the waterhole? That was many years ago! This is simply ridiculous.
Zombies? I hate undead! Oh, <FirstName>, I... really did not stress how bad our situation is. One of the water barrels was kicked by an oxen on the way here, you see.
If we can get no water here, we will not have enough to get us through to another oasis. I fear that you are going to have to help the Bedine destroy this Kel Garas.
<StartAction>[Failed]</Start> I hate bullies. I always have. Usually they only act that way because they are compensating for some kind of weakness.
Sometimes a good leader must act the role of a bully, when it is in the best interests of a larger goal.
Maybe, but sometimes a good leader accepts that he or she cannot win every battle.
You never mets the Old Master, then.
<StartAction>[Successful]</Start> I hate bullies. I always have. Usually they only act that way because they are compensating for some kind of weakness.
You never mets the Old Master, then.
<StartAction>[Failed]</Start> If I truly thought it would make the difference between life and death for you, I would certainly do so, but I have every confidence in your abilities.
However, I will give you this potion for free. It may come in quite useful if you are facing undead. That is as far as my generosity stretches.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> If I truly thought it would make the difference between life and death for you, I would certainly do so, but I have every confidence in your abilities.
However, I am willing to let you have several potions that I imagine you will find useful. That is as far as my generosity stretches.
If I thought you would possibly not succeed, I would of course make everything available. Luckily for my purse, I have the fullest confidence in your abilities.
I will, of course, give you the best prices I can, considering the difficult market.
That is a poor excuse for being tightfisted. Surely you could just... lend us some magical artifacts?
And you can just lend me some gold in return. Why, I'll even let you keep such items, and I'll just keep the gold.
You talks like Deekin thinks, halfling lady. Great hero do anything, and kicks butt too.
Yes, well... so I've seen. I'll admit that <he/she>'s been earning <his/her> fare on the caravan so far.
You means that barrel Deekin accidentally... ummm, never minds...
And whose bright idea was it to put the water barrels within kicking range of the stupid beasts?
Watch your tone, Xanos! When an ox gets an idea in its skull, nothing stops it.
That is wonderful to hear, though it certainly took you long enough. Well, let us know if you're ready to continue on, and we'll collect what water we need and go.
Right. We'll wait until you're ready, then.
Good. I, for one, would like to reach the Ao encampment as quickly as possible. Let's go.
We could be in some trouble, friend. The oxen have gone through the water rations much faster than expected. There is an oasis near here, but we have had some trouble with the tribe that guards it.
You have a way of dealing with problems that I seem to lack. If you could just go and talk to the Bedine, maybe they would allow us to restock our water supplies.
If you would rather not feel the dry sand in your mouth as your body is wracked with the pain that is dying of thirst, then bloody well do as I say. It is a simple task.
To us it seemed a simple thing; to allow our oxen to walk into the water hole. It was our first time crossing the desert and we did not know the proper customs.
We were never welcomed back, though we would never do such a thing again. We need this water, <FirstName>.
They poops in water, maybe?
Nothing so distateful, no. The Bedine consider the oasis something of a sacred place, however. It's tied into their local history, somehow.
It doesn't seem that difficult to predict that others might become upset when your beasts of burden empty their bladders in their water hole.
Not now, but we had been at another oasis where the animals and Bedine bathed in the water.
Hah! I suppose I should be a little upset if your beasts relieved themselves in my water supply too. That is why Xanos always prepares for the worst.
Are you saying you have water left?
I should certainly think so... <StartAction>[Shakes his canteen.]</Start> That is... strange. I could have sworn Xanos had some left.
Anyways, the Bedine consider the oasis something of a sacred place. It's tied into their local history, somehow.
Good. Return as soon as possible. It would be a good thing if we were able to continue tomorrow morning.
Best of luck.
Certainly. Gold is always welcome.
I'm eager to collect our water and be out of here. Are you ready to go?
Not yet.
What was I supposed to do again?
Goodbye.
There is a problem.
<StartHighlight>[Tell her about Kel Garas.]</Start>
I will be going.
I would like to make a purchase.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - Intimidate]</Start> Your life is on the line here too. Refuse to help me and death might come swifter than you expect.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Don't you think I should have free access to anything that could help us?
Should you not allow me full, free access to your wares, then?
We can use the water.
I have some things to do.
I'm ready to go now.
Get your own water.
What kind of problems did you have with them?
I will try.
I will be going.
I would like to make a purchase.
Yes, let's go.
When evil grows unchecked, then shall one destroy the guardians and prove <his/her> worth to wield the Desert's Fury.
<StartHighlight>[This altar seems to suck the very light from the room. From markings, runes and graven images you can tell this is an altar to the dark god Jergal.]</Start>
<StartAction>Leave the altar alone.</Start>
<StartAction>Spit on the altar.</Start>
<StartAction>Pretend to pray faithfully.</Start>
<StartAction>Pray faithfully.</Start>
Eh, my head really hurts. A little water would be nice about now. Or some wine. Come to think of it, I might even be willing to drown myself in a barrel of orcish ale.
I can't believe I'm already out. Once we get permission to go up to the water hole, I'm going to scavenge for some more... supplies. Katrina will be too busy to complain.
Come back soon, preferably with a vat of wine.
Thanks, I'll stay here and guard the oxen. You never know when a Bedine warrior will get hungry, and then watch out!
They make a very foul brew, but if you don't have anything else, it's better than being sober. That's about the extent of my knowledge, although they do have prickly honor.
Stick to your word until it's time to run, <FirstName>, that's my suggestion.
You not knows much beyond what goes in your mouth, Deekin thinks.
Well, keep up that wit, kobold, and you won't know much beyond the dagger that's in your belly. Hmph.
Hey, Torias, I think I found a bottle of wine!
Really? Where is it?
Oh dear, I was wrong. It's just a dried-out, useless halfling sot.
I hate dwarves that think they're witty.
You are not of much help, halfling. Perhaps if you drank less your head would be filled with more than fog.
Ugh... my head hurts so much I can't even think of a good comeback. Wait... you stink and your mother dresses you funny. That's the best I can do.
You show it who's the daddy?

Sorry. I wouldn't have the slightest idea, not being a priest and all. But I would suggest that you do so very carefully. Personally I would rather stay here and get drunk, but I'm all out of wine, so off you go.
Torias, you aren't terribly funny when you are sober.
Ouch! Xanos has heard better jokes from the kobold!
Ooo! Deekin gots to write that one down!
Hmph. My head's pounding too much. You want some advice, look for it amongst my plethora of goods... there's always something useful in there. Just don't tell the cousin.
Don't get eaten. I've always found that to be good, sound, sensible advice.
You want to see what Torias has in his booty bag, eh? Well, alright... just not a word to the cousin or that's it for my side business.
Ehhhh... what now? Can't ya leave a halfling to his misery?
I heard ya got us the water we need. Whew... by Brandobaris's hairy feet! I can't wait to get out of this desert!
I should go.
Why don't you come with me?
What do you know about the Bedine?
How do you kill a mummy?
Do you have any advice for me?
I'd like to see what you have for sale.
So you shall go and negotiate for our water? Good luck to you. I certainly would not want to deal with the Guardian Bedine.
Be wary, <FirstName>. These are a strange people.
The Bedine of this oasis are a strange lot. I do not know too much about them, but the rest of the Bedine do not deal with the Guardians. It is said that they are cursed.
We are a nomadic people, but this tribe lives here on a permanent basis. The legends of our people say that this tribe was once part of us, but one day they appeared here, strange and elusive.
One day a foolish Bedine nomad decided to steal an heirloom of this tribe. He was caught, and the leader of this tribe cursed him and all other Bedine, so that we can never enter the oasis.
We call them the guardians, though we do not know what it is they are guarding. You could ask them, but I would do so in a polite way.
The artifact was very powerful, they said. It had a specific purpose, one that the Bedine could not fulfill, though they never told us what it was. We do not communicate with them anymore.
We find ourselves getting more nauseous the closer we get. Right now I can feel the effects only slightly. Were I to get much closer I would start to feel cramping in my bowels.
It is hard to fight an enemy while your body is trying to excrete waste out every opening. An effective curse, you might say.
I see you have returned. Did you have any luck?
Yes, be wary. This is a dangerous place.
That is excellent news. We should be leaving soon then.
That is horrible. When this caravan has crossed the desert I shall spread the word among my people. Perhaps we will be able to help the survivors, if there are any.
I will do my best, though I have never been into this oasis before.
You have done an excellent job. Maybe you have the soul of a Bedine.
Good bye.
What are you talking about?
Why aren't you doing it? You're the guide.
What do you mean?
Do you know why they stay here?
Why would they curse all other Bedine?
What happens if you try to enter the oasis?
Goodbye.
We have permission to use the water.
The Bedine have mostly been slaughtered. <StartAction>[Tell him about the undead.]</Start>
I want to ask you some questions.
Why not?
Greetings to you, stranger. You have come to the Oasis of the Green Palm in a time of great danger. I am afraid there is nothing here for you other than death... and the curse of undeath.
There is a threat against all who come to this cursed place, but it does not originate with those of my tribe.
As I said before, there is nothing for you here... least of all the water that once flowed in our oasis. If you do not desire to walk the night without a soul, I suggest you move on.
A powerful creature, an ancient foe of my people, has once again arisen. He has taken our water, destroyed the temple of the Morninglord, and sent his undead minions against us.

His minions drag the corpses of my people down into his tomb, where he brings them back to life and sends them to fight us. Our numbers dwindle as his grow... and without even water to sustain us, we shall soon fall.
No water at all. The creature has dried even the water in my canteen, such is his power.
Over one hundred of my people have died in the last few days, and you claim this is directed at you? Do not disregard the lives of my people in such a selfish manner.

If you are completely out of water, then you are correct. Very well, even though this tale is not normally told outside the Bedine I suppose it is only fair that you know of the cursed creature who hunts us both.
I suppose you face the same death as we do. Very well, even though this tale is not normally told outside the Bedine I suppose it is only fair that you know of the cursed creature who hunts us both.

His name is Kel-Garas. The legends, passed down from father to son for ages in our tribe, tell us that Kel-Garas hails from an age long past... in the time of the Netheril Empire he was an evil necromancer and disciple to the god, Jergal.
You must recover the rod that binds Kel-Garas to this mortal plane. Only when it is destroyed on the altar of Lathander will we be truly free of his evil.

Before you face Kel-Garas in his tomb, I would first suggest you enter the crypt by the oasis. It is the burial place of al-Rashid, my distant ancestor who was the first to gain the power to fight Kel-Garas.

My ancestor's weapon lies within... very effective against the undead, though the legends say it failed him in the end and holds no power when wielded by those of our blood. That is why we buried it with him.
You are not of our blood, obviously. It may be the weapon would work in your hands... and I have little doubt al-Rashid would gladly forgive the intrusion if it meant the death of Kel-Garas.
Oo! Deekin not of your blood!
That... is true. I mean no offense, little one, but I would sooner take heart should my ancestor's weapon find its way into the hands of your <master/mistress>, here.
A powerful weapon to be weilded against our foe! This is fortuitous, is it not?
A weapon against the undead? I bet Katriana would pay handsomely for it! If you do not find it useful, <FirstName>, perhaps we should...
Do not discuss such things in front of me! The weapon is a relic of my ancestors; do not treat it as a common prize, to be bartered away!
My people have been mostly destroyed and our belongings taken. Whatever you can recover from Kel-Garas, you may keep. You also get the water you desperately need.
Now we get to the crux of the situation... what do we get besides water?
It is dead, so it can be of no further aid to us, sadly. But I will tell you all I can.
Do you need other answers, then?
My ancestor, al-Rashid, made a bargain with it, as I said.
Ah, I see. Of course it wanted its freedom, but my ancestor had no knowledge of how to open its Netherese prison.
So instead my ancestor had to promise that he and his descendants would remain in this valley as keepers... we would watch over Kel-Garas and kill him, if ever we got the opportunity.
Why the phaerimm wanted this from us, there is no way to know. Perhaps the phaerimm knew of Kel-Garas, or feared him? Either way it wished him dead.
And so my family, my tribe, has stayed in this valley ever since. We are the Keepers of this oasis; a dark duty that has caused other Bedine to shun us. But such is how it has always been.
Xanos knows the answer to that; it would want to be free! To be locked in stasis for years would be horrible.
I believe my power lies in the ability to remove Kel-Garas's access to his magic, though obviously I have never had the means to test it.
Inside his tomb, Kel-Garas is safe from me. Were he ever to come out, things would be much different. Or, at least, I hope they would... since my power has diminished, even that is no longer certain.
It is far away from here, many leagues to the southeast. I would gladly show you the way, but it is a pointless trek now... there is nothing of interest that remains there.
It was... like nothing I have seen before. Not a demon, nor a humanoid... it seemed more of an ethereal being. Perhaps during the age of Netheril it was a common thing, but certainly no longer.
I do not know. There was evidence that some force had opened its prison and fought it, but it was long gone, whatever it was.
Perhaps, but I don't see how. The prison is many leagues from here, and I suspect the phaerimm was dead long before Kel-Garas's power began to grow.
It has nearly been destroyed. Both the temple and my ancestor's crypt are overrun with zombies. What else can I tell you?
That crypt is the burial place of al-Rashid, my distant ancestor who was the first to gain the power to fight Kel-Garas. I would suggest you enter the crypt before you go to the tomb.

My ancestor's weapon lies within... very effective against the undead, though the legends say it failed him in the end and holds no power when wielded by those of our blood. That is why we buried it with him.
You are not of our blood, obviously. It may be the weapon would work in your hands... and I have little doubt al-Rashid would gladly forgive the intrusion if it meant the death of Kel-Garas.
