Oo! Deekin not of your blood!
That... is true. I mean no offense, little one, but I would sooner take heart should my ancestor's weapon find its way into the hands of your <master/mistress>, here.
A powerful weapon to be wielded against our foe! This is fortuitous, is it not?
A weapon against the undead? I bet Katriana would pay handsomely for it! If you do not find it useful, <FirstName>, perhaps we should...
Do not discuss such things in front of me! The weapon is a relic of my ancestors; do not treat it as a common prize, to be bartered away!
Many generations after my family took up their duty in this valley, a stranger from beyond the desert came to us. He was half-dead from starvation and thirst, but with our aid he survived.
He told us that his god had commanded him to come here... that the Morninglord hated undeath above all else and would assist us. It was he who built the temple.
He died long ago, of course, but our people took up his faith and became priests after him. Now... now there is nothing left. All the priests are dead and only the altar remains.
What questions would you ask?
We were once a nomadic tribe, connected to the other tribes of the Bedine, but when we swore to guard against Kel-Garas we moved here. Now the other Bedine believe we are cursed and avoid us.
The phaerimm's power was a gift, but also a curse, since it meant we could never leave this oasis until the mummy was utterly destroyed.
That... requires a larger explanation that dates back to Kel-Garas's rise, long ago.
Of course. All my knowledge is at your disposal.
Kel-Garas's strength has been growing, and it obviously has reached the point where he was able to reach out from within his tomb and parch the very spring from which the oasis flows.
Even though he remains in his tomb, our tribe is under siege... and he is winning.
You must first destroy his body, which is neither an easy task nor will it be permanent... Kel-Garas is immortal, after all. The source of his eternal life lies within the rod he holds.
According to the legends, whoever recovers the rod can place it on the altar of the Morning Lord and Lathander will destroy its power, for none hate the undead more than him.
The rod's destruction will end Kel-Garas's existence forever, and only that can restore the water to the oasis and give us hope of survival.
When the Bedine first battled Kel-Garas after his rising, he was all but invincible. Many thousands fought only to be slaughtered by his magic or turned into ghastly undead.
We were desperate for aid, for anything that could stop this evil. And we found it... or, rather, one of my own ancestors did.
A prison built by the ancient Netherese, perhaps similar to the one Kel-Garas himself had once been held in, I do not know. This one, however, still held its occupant.
It called itself 'phaerimm' and was unlike anything else my ancestor had ever seen. It had great power, however, power as great as that of Kel-Garas.
It was this power that my ancestor bargained for and was granted, a power that would drive Kel-Garas back into his tomb and keep him there forever.
It does. The power has been passed down in each generation of my bloodline. Should Kel-Garas ever leave his tomb, I could perhaps even destroy him.

Ahhh, if only I could venture within, myself, to face the creature directly. Should we enter the tomb, however, our own power is nullified by Kel-Garas's magic and we are helpless. Some have... still tried.

The most recent was my own uncle, Hammad, the last to hold the power before me. He entered and... returned a fortnight later, a zombie himself. I was forced to slay him, my own kin, and banish his soul.
There are many things I could brave, stranger, but undeath... no, not that. Anything but that.
Alas, our time grows short and I am sure Kel-Garas knows this. I am the last of my own blood and the power that was handed down to me... it has been waning even as Kel-Garas's own power grows.
When I noticed my power beginning to fade, I voyaged to the distant prison my ancestor had found long before... to speak to this same phaerimm if it still existed.
It was dead. How it was killed I never found out, but I can only assume that its death has caused its power within me to fade... and, at the same time, allowed Kel-Garas's to increase.
There was no sign of who killed it. I assume that with the creature's death, my powers will fade until I am normal.
Many creatures have the ability to nullify the powers of a rogue, yet this doesn't stop me from doing what I know I must.
Only a fool goes where he cannot be sure of victory. It is lucky that Xanos is here, or who could triumph over this creature?
That not sounds like it ended good...
Because he lacked the power to defeat his rivals in life, Kel-Garas sought powers through death, that he might find a way to become the supreme ruler amongst the Netherese.

Kel-Garas became a creature of undeath, gaining the abilities of the supernatural plus retaining all the power he held in life. He did not, however, anticipate the reaction of his rivals to this change.

So it would seem. All things must come to their end, good or evil, as did even the great Netheril Empire itself. In fact, it was the Empire's fall that allowed Kel-Garas to live.... but I get ahead of myself.
Many have thought so... there are wizards today who seek lichdom, after all. But it is foolishness to believe that such evil will not be countered by good. The world must always seek a balance.
If you do not wish to hear the entire tale, I can sum it up for you, though I will take no blame if you lack any depth to your understanding. I do not enjoy catering to fools.
Kel-Garas's soul is tied to a magical rod, which he keeps on his person at all times. So long as the rod continues to exist, so does he.
If you wish the water to return to this oasis, you will have to go into the tomb and defeat Kel-Garas himself... then return to the surface with his rod in order to destroy it.

Kel-Garas is immortal, so the only way he can be permanently destroyed is by placing the rod on the altar to the Morning Lord within his temple, here, and allowing Lathander to remove its foul power forever.
I trust that was a brief enough tale... or do you have questions?
As part of Kel-Garas's change into his evil, undead form, his own soul had been trapped within a rod that he kept close at hand... for this rod could be used against him.
Kel-Garas's rivals discovered this fact and had the rod stolen. They performed a great binding ritual upon it that drove Kel-Garas deep into the earth and imprisoned him there.
Kel-Garas's immortal form was protected by the power of Jergal, himself, and not so easily destroyed. Even the great power wielded by the mages of that age could but contain him, in the end.

And then, after Kel-Garas had been imprisoned for centuries, the Empire fell and its magic vanished. The binding that held Kel-Garas was broken and he was once again free. He recovered the rod and then built an elaborate tomb from which he planned to rule.
In the end it was my own people, the Bedine, who stopped Kel-Garas from succeeding. But only at great cost.
Are there other questions you have?
I did ponder thoughts of becoming a lich once, but I decided that there would be too many people who would seek to destroy Xanos. I will have enough enemies without that.
Then you have foreseen a possibility that Kel-Garas did not.
That is because Xanos learns from the mistakes of others.
An undead priest? Then this is a creature that cannot be turned!
He has many protections, young dwarf, but he must be defeated.
That sound like bad news. Old Master once tell Deekin story about dragon that do that. Old Master say he look terrible without skin.
The horror of the undead goes far beyond their appearance, little one.

Yes, an empire of wealth and magic of a level unseen anywhere in Faerun today. Kel-Garas was a Netherese priest of Jergal, though the legends say he also conspired to become ruler of the Empire, itself.
In the time of Netheril, Jergal was a powerful god of evil and darkness. It is said his power has diminished in this age, if he even exists at all, though Kel-Garas remains as powerful as ever.
It is said that Kel-Garas used the powers offered to him by Jergal and attempted to gain rulership of the Empire, itself. That is how he became what he is now.
He tried, though he ultimately did not succeed. There were many who sought to rule the Empire in that age, and Kel-Garas had many rivals with powers that paralleled his own.
Powerful creatures usually collect powerful items. This could be a good opportunity for us.
It is never just a simple job, is it? We could not just come up here and ask to use the water... no! We have to go and fight undead and other, more powerful creatures.
Ooo! You says creature? Wait! Deekin gets out notes... he gots to write this all down!
You return, I see. Do you desire to hear our tale now, or no?
As you desire. I suggest you leave this oasis soon, if you can, for your own safety.
Very well, even though this tale is not normally told outside the Bedine I suppose it is only fair that you know of the cursed creature who hunts us both.
I see you have returned, wanderer. How goes the battle with my ancient foe?
The shifting sands are ever treacherous, but trust must be placed somewhere. I beg you... do not fail us, wanderer.
Excellent. Perhaps the time of Kel-Garas's doom has finally come. The Bedine shall hold you in honor, if you honor your word to us.
I pray that al-Rashid's weapon will aid you in the battle to come. May the wings of the flies of a thousand camels speed you to victory.
I know it is, but I have given you all I can. I will pray that your path will be true and your choices wise.
I agree, the task is difficult. Here, let the strength of my blood fill yours.
The effect will not last forever, but it should stand you in good stead. Be swift, wanderer, that you might take Kel-Garas by surprise.
I will help as much as I can.
Kel-Garas's soul is tied to a magical rod, which he keeps on his person at all times. So long as the rod continues to exist, so does he.
If you wish the water to return to this oasis, you will have to go into the tomb and defeat Kel-Garas himself... then return to the surface with his rod.

Kel-Garas is immortal, so the only way he can be permanently destroyed is by placing the rod on the altar to the Morning Lord within his temple, here, and allowing Lathander to remove its foul power forever.
May the gods of my people guide you to swift victory, wanderer.
A magnificent triumph! You are truly one with the spirit of the Bedine! There is just one more task, and you must hurry, if you are to return life to the oasis.
The rod must be taken into the temple to be destroyed. Once Kel-Garas is destroyed, the water will flow in the oasis once more.
Please, wanderer, do not utter such words. My people's lives depend on you to destroy this evil. Your people will suffer and die without the water.
Even if you survive without the water, if you do not destroy the rod, Kel-Garas will not rest until you are dead and the rod is back in his possession.
Legend tells us that Lathander himself will destroy the destructive power within the rod and replace it with the power of healing. If it is a reward you wish, then the gift of the god is yours.
Xanos has no wish to have this mummy hunting him down for the rest of my life. We must destroy this rod.
Why there be always more to do? This takes forever to writes down...
I suppose you could, but legend tells us that Lathander himself will destroy the destructive power within the rod and replace it with the power of healing, no trifling thing.
It seems only fitting that such an honor should fall on you, my friend.
This is hardly a difficult choice, <FirstName>. Let us destroy the rod and collect the reward. We can always use more healing.

Before you go, legend tells us that Lathander himself will destroy the destructive power within the rod and replace it instead with the power of healing. It seemed fitting to me that you should be rewarded.
Should there be any trouble, my men and I shall try to help you.
Destroy the rod, quickly!
Victory is ours, wanderer. I am pleased to note that your actions were ever honorable. I thank you for all that you have done.
Tell little Katriana that her caravan is welcome to return to us at any time and water will always be free for her.
It was our pleasure. There was much looting of the evil temple, I am proud to say!
Xanos is glad that you acknowledge his help, but it is only proper that you should also thank my assistant, <FirstName>.
Ah... yes... well... I was thanking both of you, of course.
Ummm... Deekin helps, too, you know.
Of course you are correct, my little friend. I thank you both.
We bless the day the gods saw fit to bring you to us, wanderer.
Is that a threat?
Where are these zombies from?
All I need is some water.
Do you not have any reserves of water?
We will need to work together, then. I must have water.
Why do these things always happen to me?
As I too need water, it seems our lives are intertwined.
Our caravan is in desperate need of water.
I will be going now.
So what do I get for helping you?
I want to know more about this phaerimm.
I have no further questions about the phaerimm.
Why did it give you this power?
But what did it get in return?
What sort of power, exactly, did it give you?
Where is this prison it was in?
What manner of creature was it?
How did it die?
Could Kel-Garas have been responsible?
I have questions about this oasis.
Tell me about the crypt.
Tell me about the Temple of The Morninglord.
I have other questions.
I want to know about your people.
What is a phaerimm?
I want to know more about Kel-Garas.
How did Kel-Garas get rid of all the water?
So how do you propose we defeat Kel-Garas?
Have you tried fighting Kel-Garas directly?
What did he find?
Does this power still exist?
You are a coward! Why have you not used your power to destroy him already?
Are you too afraid to face Kel-Garas in his own lair?
Why only if he leaves his tomb?
Why the shift in power?
What do you know of Kel-Garas, himself?
Such evil is always undone, in the end.
There must be great power beyond death.
Is this story much longer?
I really do not want to hear the whole tale.
How do I destroy the rod?
Never mind. Continue on.
Please continue.
Why did they not just destroy him?
Why would his rivals drive him underground?
That's all my questions about Kel-Garas.
What cost was that?
Tell me about the Netheril Empire.
Tell me about Jergal.
And did he rule the Empire?
No, that's not necessary.
Yes, tell me what's going on.
Goodbye.
I have found al-Rashid's weapon.
It goes poorly. This is a difficult task.
I have questions for you.
What was I supposed to do again?
I have the rod.
I would like to keep the rod. It seems quite valuable.
Could I not just give it to you to do?
I will do it, then.
I will do that.
Go in peace, stranger. If you have business, I suggest you speak to Ali.
I greet you, stranger. It is too bad that you have come to our oasis at such an inopportune time.
We will die soon, and the desert shall take us... and then the evil lord shall escape his tomb at last. These are dark days, indeed.
I am afraid I possess no supplies to sell you, stranger.
You must speak to Ali, stranger. He will know what to do.
You are the one out of prophesy! Salaam, <FullName>. Your name will remain on our tongues and on the tongues of our children for generations.
The ox, having gotten used to your presence, appears to no longer be bothered by you.
Ironic as it might seem, the ox wishes you would stand downwind so it wouldn't have to smell you anymore.
Should I worry about your sanity when you begin mooing at the oxen that way, <FirstName>?
The ox proceeds to launch into a long exposition on why the gods should never have created tsetse flies.
The ox wishes you would open the gate so it could run free. Then it looks around at all the sand and hastily changes its mind.
The ox tells you how much it would like to give the caravan wagons a good stomping.
The ox wishes that it could have a long drink and a bucket of oats.
The ox explains in slow and repetitive snorts just how much it really hates all the sand.
<StartAction>[Communicate with the beast.]</Start>
You could possibly climb this rock face to reach the ruins above, though there is likely the chance of injury should you fall.
<StartAction>Leave the boulder alone.</Start>
<StartCheck>[Dexterity]</Start> <StartAction>Attempt to climb the boulder.</Start>
<StartAction>[There are numerous runes inscribed on this headstone. The language is unfamiliar, but further study could possibly reveal its nature.]</Start>

<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> <StartAction>The language is Ancient Netherese, and the inscriptions speak of four elder priests of Jergal who are buried at this spot, going on for some length on the nature of their foul deeds.</Start>

<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> <StartAction>[Though you discern that the writing is probably Netherese, you can make out little of the meaning beyond that it names four priests of Jergal buried here.]</Start>

<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> <StartAction>The language is Ancient Netherese, and the inscriptions speak of four elder priests of Jergal who are buried at this spot, going on for some length on the nature of their foul deeds.</Start>
<StartAction>The priests were named Zephid, Amadus, Isiraal and Que-mish... all dedicated their immortal soul and bodies to the defense of this tomb upon their deaths.</Start>
<StartAction>[Leave the tombstone alone.]</Start>
<StartCheck>[Decipher Script]</Start> <StartAction>[Attempt to translate the runes.]</Start>
<StartCheck>[Lore]</Start> <StartAction>[Attempt to translate the runes.]</Start>
Here lie Kassal, Ra-Matul, Ishkil and Jeb - Elders of the order of the Divine Fist.
Here lies Zaar, Great Master of the Order of the Divine Fist.
An intruder in my ancient abode! Stay, friend... stay forever!
You prove to be quite an adversary. Perhaps if you survive this, you might also prove to be a useful ally.
<StartHighlight>You hear a soft voice in your head.</Start> Come, my follower... the time for your reward is now, if you can prove yourself worthy in this challenge.
<StartAction>[The runes inscribed on this pillar are unfamiliar. Further study could possibly reveal their nature.]</Start>
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> <StartAction>The statement translates to something quite brief and clear: Kel-Garas, priest of Jergal and servant of the darkest path.</Start>
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> <StartAction>You cannot make out the meaning of the runes, though the message is short. It may relate to a title of some sort, perhaps a priest.</Start>
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> <StartAction>The statement translates to something quite brief and clear: Kel-Garas, priest of Jergal and servant of the darkest path.</Start>
<StartAction>[Leave the pillar alone.]</Start>
<StartCheck>[Decipher Script]</Start> <StartAction>[Attempt to translate the runes.]</Start>
<StartCheck>[Lore]</Start> <StartAction>[Attempt to translate the runes.]</Start>
<StartAction>[There are ancient runes inscribed on this pillar. The language is unfamiliar, but further study could possibly reveal its nature.]</Start>

<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> <StartAction>The runes tell of a powerful priest of Jergal, relating his following statement as both a curse and prophecy: "Netheril shall return! I shall bring it back and rule on high!"</Start>
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> <StartAction> The runes seem to tell the tale of a priest and some form of curse, but you cannot make out the details.</Start>

<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> <StartAction>The runes tell of a powerful priest of Jergal, relating his following statement as both a curse and prophecy: "Netheril shall return! I shall bring it back and rule on high!"</Start>
<StartAction>[Leave the pillar alone.]</Start>
<StartCheck>[Decipher Script]</Start> <StartAction>[Attempt to translate the runes.]</Start>
<StartCheck>[Lore]</Start> <StartAction>[Attempt to translate the runes.]</Start>
<StartAction>[This massive statue looms above you, as if about to strike you at any moment. Two exceptionally large rubies seem to be the statue's eyes.]</Start>
<StartAction>Step away.</Start>
<StartAction>Climb the statue and grab the rubies.</Start>
Stranger! You have destroyed much of what I created. Tell me, do you feel an urgent need to fight me and die, or do you have time to... parley?
I hoped you might have had more of a mind than that, but you have proven me wrong. Very well, we will fight, though I tell you now, even if you defeat me again, you will never be rid of me.
Kel Garas oct hothik Ral!
When a living person enters my dominion, I always assume they are here to destroy me or to rob me. Either way, I must protect myself and my... people.
But do not worry, you are alive and my people can be brought back too, so no harm is done. Will you speak?
There is always something to learn from speaking to another, particularly if the other has a mind of any value. Believe me, I could teach you all sorts of things.
But you have to be willing to listen and learn and share your thoughts as well. Is this something that interests you?
It has been long years since I had anyone to converse with. Let me get a sense of you, first.
A worshiper of the natural order? I should have known! Your kind deserve only the most painful kind of death!
A holy priest? I should have known! Your kind deserve only the most painful kind of death!
An unholy priest came to my lair? I am sorry I attacked you then. This has all the markings of a most profitable relationship.
Ah, I sense the mystic forces you hold under your control. Many of my enemies and allies were mages of great power.
A thief are you? Well do I understand the greed for something I did not possess. We might have much in common.
An entertainer? I never had much use for your sort in life, but now that I face eternity with only the mindless dead to keep me company, I find you intriguing.
Ah, I see you are a warrior of some power. I have known some generals with strong, tactical minds. We shall see how yours compares.
So what is your name, <class>?
Come now, if we are to speak in earnest we must have free exchange of information. I, as you already know, am Kel Garas of the Netheril, and a priest of Jergal.
Then our exchange ends here. Now death awaits you with eagerness.
<StartAction>[Failed]</Start> So that is how it is going to be, is it? Very well, I shall call you Katriana, though I doubt it is your name.
<StartAction>[Successful]</Start> Greetings, Katriana. Welcome to the dead lands of Kel Garas, though, as I am sure you have noticed, I am not quite dead.
<StartAction>[Failed]</Start> So that is how it is going to be, is it? Very well, I shall call you Torias, though I doubt it is your name.
<StartAction>[Successful]</Start> Greetings, Torias. Welcome to the dead lands of Kel Garas, though, as I am sure you have noticed, I am not quite dead.
Greetings, <CUSTOM502>. Welcome to the dead lands of Kel Garas, though, as I am sure you have noticed, I am not quite dead.
I was once a powerful priest of the Netherese. But I am sure you have heard the tale from the twisted minds of the Bedine warriors. Perhaps you have questions of me?
Let me see that. It looks very familiar. Hmm, I cannot seem to recall where I have seen it before. Perhaps if I could hold it, I could divine what it is with my powers.
You can trust me, <CUSTOM502>. Just let me hold the crystal and I can tell you exactly what it is.
You have the source! With it I can truly reign supreme! Nothing will ever be able to destroy me! I shall take it from your corpse and then raise you so that you may serve me!
<FirstName>, what are you doing? Ixnay on the ystalcray!
Hmm, you are an unusual duo. What do you want to know?
How would you feel about a tribe of people whose sole purpose was to destroy you? But you have me wrong; I do not hate them. I have only contempt for them.
They are mere dregs, an entire people whom civilized society holds in contempt. They have no homes, no palaces, no great libraries, nothing other than their lives.
When they are swept away, no one shall remember them, nor care that they are gone. I respect those who make something worth remembering. How about you?
Will you have anything worth remembering when your time has ended?
Then you are a fool, and I have no time to suffer fools. Your time is over now, and none shall remember nor mourn your passing.
And when you die, who will remember? Your kin? Your spawn? No, they shall take your kingdom and it shall be divided and fall and all you accomplished will have been for naught.
The ravages of time wear even stone to the ground, and your enemies shall pull down your monuments and use the stone to build their castles.
And the moment you die, others will take your wealth and you will be forgotten. Such things are transitory.
Who are the great heroes of the Netheril? We had some, but they are forgotten. Such things are transitory.
That is why I became what I am today, that I might live and be my own monument. Someday all shall know and fear me. Have you other questions?
There are... certain individuals I have held in contempt. I do not think there is such a great difference between the two.
That is a feeling Xanos knows well. There are many I have only contempt for.
Wait, wait! Deekin not writes so fast! Speaks slower!
Contrary to what many people believe, my people were not evil by nature. We were arrogant and powerful, and that led many of us to commit evil deeds.
There was a purity to the power that we wielded, so far superior to the magic of today. There are too many limits for true power.
We broke mountains, and then built cities that flew through the air. We fought our enemies with spells that could wreak havoc as far as the eyes could see.
Such power is not available in this world. Not since the disappearance of my people.
We did fail, but I still live. Perhaps more of my people survive somewhere else. I have felt... something different, recently.
Ah, but it matters not. It is my turn to ask you a question. I know so little about the world beyond this temple. Is there a power you serve? A great king?
The path to power comes to he who serves those more powerful, until he is more powerful than anyone else. You will learn this, <CUSTOM502>, or be destroyed by those with the power.
What else would you like to know?
Most people who serve others and then betray them, are soon betrayed themselves. You should have learned that lesson already Kel Garas.
You are an annoying little dwarf. <CUSTOM502>, you need to learn to keep your servants under better control. That is why I prefer mine dead.
I am not <his/her> servant!
But you should be, little dwarf. <He/She> is obviously your superior.
These are words of wisdom, <FirstName>. Listen well and we may learn a great deal from this one.
I was a powerful priest in the church of Jergal... a powerful god in my time. Despite my position in the church, I wanted more. I wanted to usurp the power of the mages and rule Netheril.
I did the research and found that I could increase my powers in the church and eventually in my society, but only if I were immortal. The ceremony was performed and I bound my soul to a magical rod.
Indeed. The rod was stolen by my enemies, just as it was by you presently, and I was cast out of Netheril society, buried in a cave, unable to rise and use my powers.
If my soul remained with my body, then the destruction of my corpse would end my life. By joining it with the magical rod, blessed and protected by Jergal, I survive death all the better.
The rod was stolen by my enemies, just as it was by you presently, and I was cast out of Netheril society, buried in a cave, unable to rise and use my powers.
Then, after an age of imprisonment, I found myself free... but entirely alone.
Then they have better knowledge then I would have thought, but I am sure the next part they would not know about.

Indeed, you have the bartering stick, if I may use that turn of phrase. I suppose the fools told you to destroy me by destroying the rod. Always there is someone who would destroy those who would be great.
But what will this creature trade for his eternal soul? That is what I am wondering.
A statement I myself have made in the past. This is a learned... man. We should pay attention to what he has to say.
Hey! Old Master used to say that all the time!

The Netherese disappeared with all of their cities and magic. I have no idea what became of them, other than the one who possessed my soul. I found his corpse near here, in fact, my body being drawn to my soul.
I was torn by the loss of my people, and I was determined to discover what had happened to them. Then I found a true horror.
Not so quickly. I have told you some of my story, but now it is my turn. Information is valuable and not to be easily given away.
I want to know something about you. Tell me; was your father a <class> too?
And driven by your mother's accomplishments, you decided that you just had to make more of your life, to prove you were as good; no, better than she was.
My, what a heart wrenching tale, <CUSTOM502>. I can see it now, driven by the loneliness of not having a father, you vowed to do more with your life.
Ah yes, I can almost smell the stench of the nobility flowing through your veins. Driven by the right to rule, you set out to show everyone you were worthy of your birthright.
And driven by your father's accomplishments, you decided that you just had to make more of your life, to prove you were as good; no, better than he was.
Ah yes, I can almost smell the stench of the common blood, flowing through your veins. Ashamed of the life your parents led, you vowed to make more of your life.
My, what a heart wrenching tale, <CUSTOM502>. I can see it now, driven by the loneliness of the orphanage; you vowed to make something better of your life.
Yes, you are as easy to read as a simple text. Go ahead, tell me I am wrong.
That's right. Lie to yourself and try to make up excuses for your choices in life, but in the end you will see that I was right.

Of course I am. The sorrows of life drive all her creatures down similar paths. We can lie to ourselves and believe that our choices are somehow more noble than others, but it is nothing more than a lie.
So where were we?
I was hoping I could trust you, but I do not think I know you well enough. I guess it is time to find out how well you die.
Well, I know a little bit about you, but I guess the most important knowledge must come now.
Are you willing to make a deal with me, knowing that it means you must betray your friends, the Bedine?
No, you must choose your path and choose it now. Once you decide, there shall be no going back. Now choose, yes or no?
Then it is time to find out how well you die. Farewell, fool.
Well then, we are entered into a contract. So here is the deal. I have created a dagger with special properties similar to the rod that holds my soul.
You take this dagger, and plunge it into the body of the Bedine leader. The dagger will consume his soul, killing him instantly.
I shall leave here until the fool is dealt with. When the deed is done, take the dagger and place it on the altar. Doing this will curse the altar.
Jergal will use the energy of the Bedine's soul to forge you a powerful item. Use it or sell it, I care not. I will be going now.
You shall never see me again, until the time of my triumphant return. I shall remember what an excellent servant you have made. Perhaps I will give you a kingdom or two to run.
Oh, and one last thing, I will take the rod and return the water to the oasis. You have my permission to partake of as much as you wish.
Here is the dagger. Good luck, my evil friend.
Quick and easy; this is a powerful weapon. Whatever shall we do? I will allow you to make this decision, my friend.
Like the ultimate thief, I would say. Still, this gives me an uneasy feeling. Please choose carefully.
That sound like nice knife. You makes one for Deekin, maybe?
Silence, fool creature.
Very well, what do you want to know about?

A creature of great evil, a phaerimm... enemy to the people of Netheril and itself trapped in a prison of their making... had twisted the minds of a Bedine tribesman and granted him great power to destroy me.
My research was lost as I fled back here to my lair, where I was able to block the creature's magic with my own protections.
I believed I was trapped in my tomb indefinitely, but it seems something has gone right finally and I have grown in strength.
I do not know. Perhaps Jergal waxes in power once again, or perhaps the phaerimm perished, weakening the Bedine. Or something else beyond my awareness has occurred. Does it truly matter?
But now it is my turn to ask a question again. You left home to become an adventurer, and you obviously have the skills of some experience.
Someone must have become the replacement parental figure in your life. Was he or she kind? Did you love your mentor?
Only a fool cannot admit weakness. You had a mentor and you loved him like he was your own father.
Do you believe the lies you tell yourself? It is only a fool who cannot admit weakness. At least a part of you loved your mentor.
Every lie you tell tells me more about you. Every lie pushes you a little closer to the same path that I walked. You loved your mentor.
Every lie you tell tells me more about you. Every lie pushes you a little closer to the same path that I walked. There was a mentor and you loved him like a true father.
We all love our mentors in one way or another. I loved mine even as I killed her. She made an excellent sacrifice.
And yet there is a part of you that would liked to have tested your mentor... to best him, and to watch his life's blood flowing from a mortal wound of your own making.
What a moronic statement! Even as you hide behind the veneer of diplomacy, your soul is stained and someday you shall find that the dark path has consumed you so greatly, you enjoy evil.
Do you see the path before your feet? Even if you destroy me, your evil nature will bloom, as it always does.
What he says is true! How I would have enjoyed that contest. Maybe I will still have the chance, though I would not kill Drogan, just teach him a lesson for once.
Yes, I am. But unlike you, I have never sought to hide my nature behind a guise of righteousness.
Oh, <CUSTOM502>, this is such fun. It is your turn. Ask your questions.
There lies the difference between us. I would never have hurt Master Drogan.
Old Master was mentor to little Deekin. He threatens to eats Deekin lots.
Phaerimm are creatures that destroy all other magic-using creatures of any race. By almost any definition, that would make them evil, no?
Truthfully, it is humorous, don't you think? I mean here are these people, thinking they are doing the world a great service for the good of all, yet binding themselves to a creature of pure malice.
Yes, they do not even comprehend the irony of thier situation. Irony is the most beautiful form of humor.
Exactly! Irony is the most beautiful form of humor.
Then you must have scrambled your brain with all the fighting you have been doing. Irony is the most beautiful form of humor.
I told you, I was researching what happened to my people. Taking over the world would have made that research easier.
I do not see the profit in ruling over the dead. Of what use is an empty world?
You fail to see the grand scheme, but then, you are short, you must fail to see a lot of things.
You live only at the mercy of Xanos and his brave companion!
Perhaps, or perhaps I will just keep coming back until you are so weakened that you can no longer defeat me. Then you would be my undead slaves.
Bleh. That just because boss not kills you rest of way, yet.
Silence, fool lizard, lest I show you first-hand the glory of undeath!
Ummm... okays. Deekin just goes back to writing epic story...
Hrrrrm. A paladin, I see. And one who speaks with the undead? You are nothing more than a dissembler, fool, and I shall rend you apart with my unholy powers!
I am here only to destroy you, evil creature!
You try to kill me and then wish to speak?
Why should I want to speak with you?
I will speak with you.
I do not wish to share my name with you.
I said no.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - lie]</Start> My name is Katriana.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - lie]</Start> My name is Torias.
I am <FullName>.
I have no questions for you.
Are you interested in making a deal?
<StartAction>[Pull out tower crystal.]</Start> Do you know what this crystal is?
Why do you need to hold it?
I don't think so. It is important.
Definitely not.
I'm not sure...
<StartHighlight>[Put the crystal away.]</Start> No.
<StartAction>[Quickly put it away.]</Start> Uh, never mind. I have a different question.
<StartAction>[Show him the crystal anyways.]</Start>
Why do you hate the Bedine so much?
I do not care for such things.
Someday I will forge a kingdom.
They shall build monuments to me, someday.
I will have riches beyond belief.
My fame shall live on.
Tell me about the Netherese.
I would love such power.
Not so powerful that they survived though.
So why did they fail?
There are kings and tyrants, but I serve none of them.
I serve my god.
I serve my people.
I serve no one.
Tell me your version of the story.
You mean the rod I stole?
Well, that was pretty stupid.
Why would you bind it to a rod?
This is pretty much exactly what the Bedine told me.
And now I have the rod they placed your soul in.
What happened to your people?
How did you get free?
Enough, I want to ask you about something else.
Hurry up and finish your story.
What did you find?
No, but my mother was.
I never knew my father.
No, he was a noble.
Yes, he was.
No, he was a commoner.
No, I am an orphan.
You know nothing about me.
You are wrong.
You are close.
I have no more questions.
Is there no other way?
No. I will not betray them.
Yes, if it is worth my while.
They are not my friends. I merely sought water from them.
I like it, so far.
What do I get for doing this?
What happens then?
I changed my mind. I think I will destroy you instead.
Give me the dagger.
Very well.
I want to ask something else.
Finish telling me your story.
What has bolstered your powers?
I do not wish to answer that.
No, I used him for my own purposes and left when he had nothing more to give.
He was a good teacher, but I had no feelings for him.
There was no mentor in my life.
Yes. He was a good teacher.
Yes, there is truth in what you say.
You have your opinions; I have mine.
Perhaps you are right.
You are disgusting.
The Bedine said the creature was combating your evil.
Why should I believe this phaerimm was evil?
What fools.
Somewhat ironic I suppose.
I don't find that funny.
You spoke of research; I thought you were trying to take over the world.
<StartAction>The magical crystal that you received from the Formians begins to feel warm in your hands...</Start>
<StartHighlight>[There is an old inscription on this obelisk. The language is unfamiliar, but further study could possibly reveal its nature.]</Start>
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> "The gift of the fairy can really be fun, when used on the offense, your opponents it will stun."

"But defensively used and even when you attack you will be seen by no one."

<StartCheck>[Lore]</Start> <StartAction>[Attempt to translate the runes.]</Start>
Welcome to Musharak's Fine Desert Emporium! I am Musharak, sole proprietor and scrounger of the only mid-Anauroch mercantile business.
How might I serve you today, good <lord/lady>? Would you care to see Musharak's generous supply of goods at low, low prices?
Well, I am disappointed that you don't want to buy anything right now, but I guess you'll come around.
In hopes that you will soon be in the purchasing mood, I will answer whatever questions you have.
Very good. Now, we should get down to business. How about I show you my fabulous merchandise?
I do not like to talk about my neighbors much. They are odd, but accommodating.
They are excavating in the Valley of the Winds. I told the fools that if they found any powerful magic items, I would pay gold for them, but they seem to think they should keep it all. Greedy fools.
If you speak to the minister, I heard rumors that one of the mages returned from the valley today, pretty roughed up. That is all I know about it though. None of my business.
Have you ever cut a worm in half and noticed that both halves keep on living? Well, I have noticed that, but I do not know how they manage it.
I do not know how these fools survive either, but there you have it. Every once in a while they come to me and purchase supplies. But I rely more on my income from trading with the Bedine tribes.
The minister is the leader of this group, if it can be said that anyone is a leader here. Do not ask him about his religion though, unless you really want to waste a day or two.
If you need to find him, he is in the big temple. I would not bother if I were you, but it is your time.
Surely a simple merchant and scrounger is unworthy of your scrutiny, but if you insist, I suppose I can reveal a bit about myself.
Very well, now that you know I am just a kind and caring individual, how would you like to support my twenty three children and buy some of my goods?
NO! None. What a frightening thought that is. What would make you think such a thing?
Of course I did. I want you to buy something from me. Have you never haggled with a merchant before? Few of them have children, but most of them will tell you they do. Now, want anything else?
It is very hard for a hobgoblin to make a living in large, civilized cities, and hobgoblin communities are simply too dangerous, so I came to the desert to sell supplies to the Bedine.
Then I heard about this encampment. The Aoists were selling water to the Bedine for pitifully low prices, so I came here for a visit. I liked what I saw, so I decided to settle down here.
Every item is wonderfully crafted and will never break, bruise, spoil or run out of charges (unless it is designed to do so).
If you want it, I can get it... well, so long as you are not trying to buy any of the Aoist wine. That Jasmeena can be so frustrating and the minister is even worse!

We have lived in the same encampment for a few years now, and he still refuses to tell me his name. It has become something of a game now. I will throw a probing question at him and see how well he can deflect it.
But that should tell you something of his personality. He is obsessed with his religion, and I will not tolerate talk of such things. Duvockri is offended by such utterings.
<StartAction>[He shows you a small idol.]</Start> Duvockri is the hobgoblin god of trickery. I keep my idol and offer it small gifts to help protect me from being fooled as I fool others.
Congratulations. No, really, how wonderful for you. Oh dear, I think I just dribbled a little sarcasm onto my tunic.
Unless she sent you here with a regular supply of wine for me to sell, I really could care less. Sorry.
Jasmeena is a Bedine woman who lives here with the Aoists and makes a special holy wine. I have no idea why she stays, but she is devoutly loyal to the minister, though not an Aoist.
Her pathetic, subservient view of life has led her to make a special wine that the Aoists treat as almost holy. Can you believe she does not even charge them for the wine?
She is one of those pathetic druids who stumble around trying to save every ant and flea, with no real understanding of what is truly important: gold! She and the fool of a minister belong together.
Like yourself, Jasmeena is a noble druid whose purpose in life is to assist nature here in the nearly lifeless desert. She and the fool of a minister belong together.
Oh no, ha ha, certainly not. He is an old man, while she is a young woman. I simply meant that they have much in common, with unusual ways of looking at the world.

My, you are terribly observant. I assure you, I, Musharak, may have the body of a hobgoblin, but I have the mind of an elf and the heart of a dwarf. And do not worry; their original owners were well compensated.
If I only had the feet of a halfling I would be the most well rounded individual in the realms. Hmm, well, anyways. Was there more to your question?
Well then, perhaps you are in a pleasant, spendthrift mood now?
They really are an interesting little group, so long as they keep their religious ideas to themselves and keep paying me for the supplies they need.
It was very kind of them to allow me to take over trading the water to the Bedine. I was afraid they might put up a fuss, but they just looked at my guard, Ludo, and shrugged.
Say hello to the nice <lord/lady>, Ludo.
<StartAction>[Grunt]</Start>
See? We are all getting along so well. How lovely. Now, how would you like to browse my wares and maybe make a purchase or two?
Sort of like a little protection scheme you have then?
A protection scheme? Not a bad idea.
And who are you going to say you are protecting them from?
Good point. Besides, the poor fools can barely afford supplies.
Great Duvockri, I should think not! Most of my kind could hardly string a four-word sentence together. I do not claim any great virtue, but neither would I stab you in the back just to test my blade.
All that I am, is a humble merchant, though I am the best in this part of the world. Alright, so perhaps I am not humble. I am also a scrounger, but what good merchant is not?
<StartAction>[He shows you a small idol.]</Start> Duvockri is the hobgoblin god of trickery. I keep my idol and offer it small gifts to help protect me from being fooled as I fool others.
Ever get caught in a sandstorm and suddenly feel the need to relieve your bowels? I imagine I am only slightly less of an annoyance than that.
But just like the sandstorm, in the end, I really just do not care. I am me and they can take me as I am. They are far too nice to chase me off.
Ha, you caught me there. Occasionally a caravan, such as the one you came in with, will wander through, but I am the only steadfast merchant here.
Most of my gold comes from supplying the locals, trading water to the Bedine tribes (an excellent trade there), from passing caravans and the occasional adventurer.
Now what kind of fool would I have to be to do such a thing? I was a traveling merchant, making minor deals with the Bedine until I found out about this little settlement.
They were trading this water for supplies from the tribes, so I thought it would be a good idea to settle down and help out both sides.
Now I sell the water to the Bedine and supplies to the Aoists. How could I possibly have a better set up than this?
You are absolutely right. I was really very impressed that they gave in so easily. It was a most fortunate turn of events. Most neighbors would have put up a fight, thrown rocks, done something.
It is really very strange that they are being so obdurate now. I could make my fortune if they would just tell me the secret to making their wine, or at least let me sell some.
That is the only secret they seem to care about. They will talk about everything else for hours on end. Do not get them started on a conversation about the holy glory of ambivalence.
Have you ever experienced a moment in life where the universe suddenly come to a halt and you think you are on the verge of understanding all the deepest questions about life?
Have you ever stood on the precipice of a mountain in the early morn, surrounded by fog and then suddenly the sun rose, the fog lifted and it was like you were seeing perfection?

I do not pretend to be a poet, friend, but my first sip of this wine changed the way I look at life. That was the moment I knew I could live in this desolate place and still feel fulfilled. That is how good it is.
Deekin feel that way one time when his old master let him sit on his head and master breathes ice on human knights. It like watching little statues.
You sat on a dragon's head?
Well, me was composing song for master and me tells him Deekin gots to get it right. Now how that song goes?
Ah, thank you, I will take your word on it. No need to sing anything.

That is a good question. It is irrelevant however, as they will not even listen to me on this matter. Maybe someday I shall convince them, or they will get a new minister who might take my offers seriously.

Oh, I know, but they know next to nothing about how to make a decent sale. They barely get by with the amount they trade, but I swear, I could be rich inside of five years selling their wonderful wine.
Would I like to find a beautiful, intelligent hobgoblin woman wandering the desert, looking for a mate? Of course I would, but I think it rather unlikely.
I am a very persuasive man, but they will not budge for me. Still, you are welcome to try. I would be willing to pay handsomely for such a deal. How does 2000 gold sound?
I have sold family members for less than that! How could you possibly ask for more? No, it cannot be done. Two thousand is all I can offer you. It is not like I am asking you to slay a dragon!
Good Duvockri, no! It is merely an expression. Why I do not have any family members to sell, even if I were inclined to do so. Actually, now that I think about it, who would buy a hobgoblin?
No! That is a bad thought. Even I would not sink so low! Now, are you going to try to do this for me, or not?
I doubt you could have done the deed anyways. It would be far to difficult for you, I fear.
Very well. If you are successful, I shall pray to Duvockri that your life will be free from treachery. Is there anything else?
He has a good point, <FirstName>. There is no real reason to get angry at him for having good business sense.
Let us say that you were interested in purchasing an item that I did not happen to have in stock. I would contact certain friends and see if I could find something you might find worth purchasing.
If you needed something a little faster than my friends could get it to me, I could scrounge around and see what I could find. There could be a cloak or robe, perhaps.
Sure, there might be a small tear and a spot of blood on it, but if you are in a hurry...
It is not how I prefer to do things, but some people can get in a downright hurry. If it bothers you overmuch, then don't ask.
Well, I certainly could, but you should probably peruse the wonderful stock that I already have, as the effort it takes to scrounge up a magical item makes the cost somewhat prohibitive.
Besides, it can take an awfully long time to reach my contacts and you would likely be gone before the item arrived.

If you would like, I can take a look around the encampment and see if there is anything interesting. That is a bit of time from my day, however. If you want me to see what I can find it will cost you 100 gold.
I always mind; but do not worry; I shall keep a smile on my face while my heart weeps on the inside.
Ah, well, maybe you should sell me some of your own valuables. I am always interested in a good deal.
The word is *acquire*, not steal. Steal is such an ugly word. If it would sooth your conscience, I will promise to pay the owner if I find something for you. Is that good enough?
I will start working on that right away. In the mean time, is there anything else I can help you with?
A magical robe is always a good thing. Xanos always likes something that provides protection.
Oooo... maybe you gets Deekin a magic lute that makes big fireballs! Deekin makes even better companion for hero with that.
A magic fireball lute? Try not to get your hopes up. I have my doubts.
Deekin could use good cloak too, he guesses.
Now that has a certain ring to it, doesn't it. A scrounger... well, conjours up images anyways.
Where you gets these parts? Deekin could use nimble fingers like gnomes.
You travel with a kobold bard and you think a hobgoblin merchant is strange? Well, it takes all kinds.
Hah! We shall have to tell that one to little Dorna. It will be as much fun as turning invisible and pulling the tale of a wildcat.
I do not care for your sense of humor, hobgoblin. Control your tongue or I shall be forced to remove it.
My apologies, mistress, I meant no offense to you. All I meant was that my heart was noble and true, like a dwarf's.
Hmph, and I should be mollified by that? I am not so easy.
Since you were so kind as to set up my supply, I will sell you some for very cheap, say 200 gold for a bottle.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Do you know that I charge 500 gold for each bottle of this fine wine? People will pay that much! 100 gold is a fine price.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Oh, quit flexing your muscles in my face! 150 gold, and that is my final offer.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Do you know that I charge 500 gold for each bottle of this fine wine? People will pay that much! 100 gold is a fine price.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Oh, fine, but do not expect me to be pleased at almost giving it away. 150 gold, and that is my final offer.
Excellent. I am certain you will enjoy it. Will there be anything else?
Excellent. I am certain you will enjoy it. Will there be anything else?
For a friend? Of course, of course. Cannot have it known that a hero like yourself was drinking alcohol. Do not worry, should anyone ask, I will swear up and down that it was for your... friend.
Unfortunately you are asking the wrong person. The minister of the Aoists is the one who controls the wine, while Jasmeena makes it.
I would surely love the honor of selling the Aoist wine, but I have been unsuccessful in arranging a deal with either of them.
Since you were so kind as to set up my supply, I will sell you some for very cheap, say 200 gold for a bottle.
Suit yourself. There are plenty of wealthy people who will spend the 500 gold I normally charge them. More gold for me.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Do you know that I charge 500 gold for each bottle of this fine wine? People will pay that much! 100 gold is a fine price.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Oh, quit flexing your muscles in my face! 150 gold, and that is my final offer.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Do you know that I charge 500 gold for each bottle of this fine wine? People will pay that much! 100 gold is a fine price.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Oh, fine, but do not expect me to be pleased at almost giving it away. 150 gold, and that is my final offer.
Excellent. I am certain you will enjoy... I mean, your friend will enjoy it very much. <StartAction>[Wink.]</Start> Will there be anything else?
Excellent. I am certain you will enjoy... I mean, your friend will enjoy it very much. <StartAction>[Wink.]</Start> Will there be anything else?
A repeat customer: my favorite kind! How might I help you?
Good enough. Goodbye.
I had a look around the camp and spoke to some... well... people, and they have something that was found in the Valley of the Winds. It is a magical belt, and it cost me fair coin to buy it.
In this case there was no other way for me to acquire the item, so I hope you are ready to pay 40000 gold for it. The item will allow you to move quickly and absorbs damage, so it is quite powerful.
That is very disappointing, but I hope you will be able to purchase it later.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Ah! My seventeen children would starve should I accept an offer like that. I can go no lower than 40000 gold.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Ah! My seventeen children would starve should I accept much less than that. You may steal the belt from me for a mere 35000 gold.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Ah! My seventeen children would starve should I accept an offer like that. I can go no lower than 40000 gold.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Ah! My seventeen children would starve should I accept an offer like that. You may steal the belt from me for a mere 35000 gold.
Excellent. That is what I love to hear. It is always a pleasure to please a customer, especially when it also helps fill the coffers. Is there anything else?
Excellent. That is what I love to hear. It is always a pleasure to please a customer, especially when it also helps fill the coffers. Is there anything else?
How dare you come here and try to change my religion! Duvockri take you! I have my own god. I have no need for their pathetic one!

Of course I am right, though I am slightly disappointed that you would give up so easily. It has been a while since I had a good argument. Ah well, why don't you assuage your guilt by spending some money?
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> I do not take kindly to your aspersions, my <lord/lady>. I am willing to overlook them, because I value your business.
Well now, why did you not say so in the first place? For profit, I am sure Duvockri would be willing to smile on a good bit of trickery! Right, you can tell them I am now a devout Aoist.

<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Duvockri is the hobgoblin god of trickery... I think I can see the point you are making. I even think Duvockri would find it amusing. Right, you can tell them I am now a devout Aoist.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> I do not take kindly to your aspersions, my <lord/lady>. I am willing to overlook them, because I value your business.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Ah... sure... I can see your point. There could be some profit in such a conversion. Right, you can tell them I am now a devout Aoist.
Good point. I guess I will have to give up my idol. Do not worry Duvockri, someday we may be rejoined, but for now I must live my faith. Oh, friend, I hope he understands why I must do this.
I need some time to think about things. You should go and tell the Minister. Now, how much can I gouge customers for a single bottle of wine?

Hah! A good leader must be flexible in all things, especially religion. Those who cling too hard to one god tend to make foolish mistakes. If I were a god I would detest such followers, even as I used them.
What kind of nonsense are they spouting now, or did you fill their heads with delusions of grandeur? I see no profit in sharing with them!

Of course I am right, though I am slightly disappointed that you would give up so easily. It has been a while since I had a good argument. Ah well, why don't you assuage your guilt by spending some money?
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> They are, are they? Well, that makes a difference. I can charge a great deal more for a small amount of wine than for barrels of water.
Ah, friend, I can hear the clinking of the gold in my coffers already. <StartAction>[Sigh... sob.]</Start> What beautiful music!
Tell my neighbors that I shall gladly share my profits on both the water and wine. And let it not be said that Musharak is never generous.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> I do not take kindly to your threats, my <lord/lady>. I am willing to overlook them, because I value your business.
Just keep your nose out of something you obviously do not understand. If the Aoists are so determined to make profit, they may come to me themselves and bring wine with them.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Uh... I get your meaning, good <lord/lady>. I... I guess that there is room for negotiations, this being their water and all.
Tell the fools... I mean my neighbors, that I will give them a share of whatever I make from selling the water. And let it not be said that Musharak is above charity!
I cannot believe she would go behind the minister's back in such a way. Tell me, what condition would this be based upon?

I agree with you and I have not even heard the conditions. You must be feeling guilty for giving up so easily though; I think it would make you feel better if you just spent all your gold on something frivolous.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> What an outrageous proposal! I make most of my gold selling the water to the Bedine, why should I give that up? There is precious little profit in such a deal.
You would be better off speaking to the minister than that fool druid! Bah! She makes me as angry as the time Uncle Calahuk told me I should be calling him 'Daddy'!
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Well now, give away freely-gotten water and sell expensive, but still freely-gotten wine? I suppose there is room for profit there.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> What an outrageous proposal! I make most of my gold selling the water to the Bedine, why should I give that up? There is precious little profit in such a deal.
You would be better off speaking to the minister than that fool druid! Bah! She makes me as angry as the time Uncle Calahuk told me I should be calling him 'Daddy'!
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Well now, give away freely-gotten water and sell expensive, but still freely-gotten wine? I suppose there is room for profit there.
It will not be as much gold as I was anticipating, but I suppose it will have to do. Go and tell her that like a tree that topples over onto the axe man, so I too have fallen to her will.
The wine business is a success. How goes your business? Need some more supplies?

You murderous fool! We could hear the sounds of the slaughter from out here! You have ruined my business and now I will have to flee. Once the Bedine hear about this, it will not be safe to be the only living being here.
Goodbye.
I would like to ask you some questions.
That is all my questions.
I have questions about the Aoists.
Where are the archeologists?
How do the Aoists survive here?
Who is their leader?
I have questions about you.
That is all my questions about you.
You have children?
You just said you did!
What brought you here?
It doesn't really seem like they are your people.
You liked the Aoists?
I would like to see your goods.
What kind of things do you sell?
Tell me about the minister.
Who is this Duvockri you spoke of?
I met Jasmeena.
Who is Jasmeena?
I want to speak about something else.
Is there something between the two of them?
Tell me about this wine.
Aren't you a hobgoblin?
That's all I was wondering.
How do you get along with the Aoists?
Are you as evil as your kin?
Who is this Duvockri you spoke of?
How do the Aoists feel about your worship of this other god?
How many merchants are there around here?
Do you pay for the protection or water of the Aoists?
Sounds like a good situation.
That isn't very fair to your neighbors.
I want to speak about something else.
Is their wine really that good?
You have stolen their only other source of income. Why should they share with you?
It is their secret; leave them alone.
Would you like me to try to get you a supply?
That is not enough.
You sell your family members?
Forget it then.
I will do it.
That would be good.
What is a scrounger?
That's horrible!
Could you do that for me?
Never mind.
No thanks. I don't have that kind of gold on me.
I don't want you to steal anything from others.
See what you can find.
I would like to buy some Aoist wine.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - Intimidate]</Start> You call that cheap?
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> You have to be joking!
I will take it.
I will take it.
I need to purchase a bottle of wine for a friend.
Never mind.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - Intimidate]</Start> You call that cheap?
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> You have to be joking!
I will take it.
I will take it.
Goodbye.
Have you found anything special I might wish to purchase?
Never mind.
I do not have enough.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - Intimidate]</Start> I will not pay so much. Try again.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Surely it did not cost you that much. 30000 gold should be enough.
I will take it.
I will take it.
The Aoists want you to convert to their religion.
I guess you are right.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> There is converting... and then there is converting. You get my meaning?
They would let you sell their wine.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Is one religion so much different from another? They are willing to let you sell their wine.
I don't think they will just take your word for it.
You will have to show them some proof.
The Aoists would like you to share your profits with them.
I guess you are right.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> They are willing to allow you to sell their wine, if you share profits.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - Intimidate]</Start> You owe it to them. It angers me to see someone take advantage of these people!
Jasmeena says she will allow you to sell her wine.
I don't think you will like it. Never mind.
<StartCheck>[Persuade - Intimidate]</Start> You will supply the Bedine with free water!
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> You can only have the wine if you supply the Bedine for free.
You are an intruder. You destroyed other intruders. Destroying of intruders is a job for guardians. You destroyed intruders, therefore you are a guardian. How may I assist you, guardian?
The guardian protects the master. Do not touch the master.
Treasure? Inquiring into definition of treasure. Concept does not fall into accepted commands. What is treasure?
These things do not fall within accepted commands. Query unanswerable within defined parameters.
Master is valuable. I guard the master. The master is behind me. Query answered.
No intruders in immediate vicinity; request does not fall into accepted commands.
I am a guardian. You are a guardian. We are guardians. Nothing else is known.
The great master made me. I protect him now. The great master is behind me.
I protect the great master. I do my job. You do not act like a guardian. Maybe you are an intruder.
Intruders must find death. You must die, intruder!
The great master takes many forms. Once he walked and talked, now he is in silent meditation.
Good, we do not want to disturb the great master's rest.
But the great master is here. But the great master does summon guardians. This is ineffable. I would ask the great master, but I do not wish to disturb his rest. We shall wait until he awakens.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Commands contradictory. Insufficient guidelines. Priority one, destroy intruders. Now destroying all intruders.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Commands contradictory. Insufficient guidelines. Mission aborted.
The master needs no flesh. He is wise in everything.
Insufficient input for argument. Please end this line of questioning.
Dead? Death happens to intruders. Death does not happen to great master.
The guardian returns. How may I assist you, guardian?
Goodbye.
What do you guard?
Tell me where the treasure is.
Gold or magic items.
Something valuable.
Help me fight the other intruders.
What are you?
Who made you?
You are not doing a very good job.
You mean the skeleton?
Let's talk about something else.
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> Your master summoned me to gather his belongings.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> The master is in a hurry and wants me to take something off his body.
Can I touch your master?
Silent meditation!?! There's no flesh on his body.
Wisdom doesn't enter into it. He's dead I tell you.
Your master is dead.
You were a decent traveling companion. If the gods wish it, maybe we shall meet again someday.
Thank you for healing me! The demonic creatures swarmed out and slew everybody.
I am getting out of here before they come back.
Death... death came... so swiftly. Horrible laughter... we screamed and cried... for mercy... then, more laughter...
One more thing.... they... they have found the....
The rat wishes it could find some more shiny rocks for its home.
The rat winks an impish eye at you then flees to safety.
The rat sniffs, then drops the diamond into your hand. It takes the quartz and flees to the safety of its hole.
The rat trembles with defiance. It seems to be very desperate to hang on to the shiny rock.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> The rat ignores your bullying and sniffs itself defiantly.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> The rat heaves a mighty sigh, then drops the diamond. It quickly flees to safety.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> The rat ignores your request and scratches itself defiantly.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> The rat heaves a mighty sigh, then drops the diamond. It quickly flees to safety.
<StartAction>[A rat jumps out of the rubble, grabs the diamond in its mouth and runs away.]</Start>
Alright, fine. Keep the rock.
<StartAction>[Hold out a piece of quartz.]</Start> Let us exchange shiny rocks.
Give me the diamond, rat!
<StartCheck>[Persuade - Intimidate]</Start> Give me the diamond or I crush your skull!
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Please give me the rock. I need it.

<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> <StartHighlight>[Though you discern that the writing is Netherese in origin, you cannot make out the message it conveys.]</Start>
