The barbarian reacts with surprise. "I see. Are you certain this is wise? You may have need of my strength and skill in battle as you progress through Undermountain."
"You won't regret this decision, <FirstName>. I swear it on the Red Tiger blood in my veins."
Daelen frowns. "I do not like this, but I will respect your decision, <FirstName>. I will wait here for you to return."
"As you wish, though I think you are making a mistake. Goodbye, <FirstName>."
"What tactics would you like to change?"
"I will leave the traps for those more suited to handling them."
"My skills in disarming traps are somewhat lacking, but I will try my best."
"An Uthgardt warrior was not meant to hide in the shadows, anyway. Such tactics are more suited to rogues and assassins."
"I shall remain hidden until the battle begins, then I will burst forth to slaughter our foes."
"It is not the way of my people, but I will strike from the shadows whenever I am able."
"That is probably a good idea. I will leave the locks to those with more skill than I."
"I will smash open any obstacle that stands in your way!"
"Very well. How far away would you like me to stay?"
"As you wish."
"This is the way of the Uthgardt people and the Red Tiger tribe. I will gladly charge your enemies on sight."
"I will protect your life with my own, and I will take my lead in battle from you."
"As you wish. Take a look at my pack and make whatever changes you feel are best."
The half-orc gives you a strange look. "My rage is best used in battle. Are you certain you want me to unleash my fury now?"
The half-orc shrugs. "I am not one for words, but if you wish to talk we can talk."
"As you wish. Is there anything else you need?"
"As well as can be expected, given our current situation. I am healthy and whole, and ready for whatever Undermountain has in store for us."
"Is there something else you wish to know?"
"I'm still suffering from a few minor injuries, but it's nothing serious. I can wait for healing if others are worse off than I."
"My wounds are serious, but not life threatening. I'd like to get them tended to before the next battle, if possible."
"My wounds are bad. If I don't get some healing soon, I won't be of much use in the next battle."
"My vision is still dark, the world is all shadows and night. I won't be of much use if we don't find a way to restore my sight."
"This poison has left me weak. We need to find a way to neutralize it as soon as possible."
"This illness that's afflicted me is growing worse. The sooner we find a way to cure the disease, the better."
"I haven't given it a lot of thought, <FirstName>. But spending time in the darkness of Undermountain has given me a new appreciation for the open plains of my homeland."
"I think... I think after this I will return to the Red Tiger tribe. Should the Elders still want me, I will accept their invitation to join the tribal council."
"No, I don't think so. Not this time. Of course, all these plans assume we will survive what lies ahead - something we won't do if we spend all our time talking. Let's get back to our mission."
"Yes, I believe I am. Of course, all these plans assume we will survive what lies ahead - something we won't do if we spend all our time talking. Let's get back to our mission."
The barbarian frowns. "I suppose you have earned the right to hear this tale. After all, you did raise me from the dead."
"I went back to my people: the Red Tiger tribe of the Uthgardt. When I left, I had been an outcast, a pariah among them because of my orcish blood. But I returned to a hero's welcome."
"The Elders knew my part in Neverwinter's salvation. What's more, during my adventures I had found Uthgardt's Spear, a sacred artifact of my people that had been lost for centuries."
Daelen frowns. "If you only intended to mock me, why did you ask about this in the first place?" He shakes his head and stomps away.
"For a brief time, I was happy among the sons and daughters of the Red Tiger. But then the tribal Elders came and asked me to join the tribal council. They wanted me to help lead the tribe."
"I refused the honor. I was not ready for such responsibility, I knew some other purpose still lay ahead of me - though I didn't know what it was."
"I could have continued to dwell with my tribe, I was still a respected hero. But something was missing in my life, I had no sense of purpose. And so I left the Uthgardt tribe once again."
"I wander the north for a time, hiring out my skills as a mercenary or bodyguard. Eventually, I met up with Linu and Sharwyn, whom I had met in Neverwinter. I took it as a sign."
"I convinced them our destinies were intertwined. Soon after, we ran across that rogue, Tomi. He was on the run - as usual - and he happily joined us, too."
"Perhaps, though I see it differently. Soon after we were all together, we heard about the attacks on Waterdeep, and our new destination was clear."
"I thought so as well. Soon after we were all together, we heard about the attacks on Waterdeep, and our new destination was clear."
"We had all played a part in saving Neverwinter, now we have come together to save another city. Forces beyond our control have brought us here - and to you, <FirstName>."
"But Waterdeep will not be saved if we spend all our time talking. We can continue this discussion later, but for now we should get back to the task at hand."
He shrugs. "Maybe I was. It would only be further proof that I was not ready to be a tribal Elder. But I don't see it as running away. I see it as a search for something I didn't have."
"I am not originally from Neverwinter. But you are correct: I was there during the time of the Wailing Death, a deadly plague that swept the city."
"I journeyed with the great Hero of Neverwinter, and I played a small part in ridding the city of the evil that plagued it."
"I'm not surprised. My own role in saving the city was a minor one. Hardly anyone in the city even knew who I was."
"Really? That's surprising. The truth is, my own role in saving the city was a minor one. Hardly anyone in the city even knew who I was."
"Actually, few in the city even knew who I was. My part in that tale was a minor one, at best."
"However, I was given a substantial reward by Lord Nasher, the city's ruler, for my efforts. But even with my wealth, I could not find happiness in Neverwinter."
"No? That's strange, as it was you who started this conversation. Very well, let's return to our mission, and I won't speak of my time in Neverwinter again."
"Maybe it was my heritage. Many of the Uthgardt tribes had joined in the attacks on Neverwinter. People looked on me with suspicion and hate. Being a half-orc only made it worse."
"But I think it was something else, as well. There is something wrong with Neverwinter; it is a city that destroyed its own spirit, a city betrayed, a city that turned against itself."
"I'm talking about Lady Aribeth, the champion of the city, and her lover Fenthick. Fenthick was executed to appease an angry mob: a cruel and unjust punishment."
"Yes - her and her lover Fenthick. He was executed by Lord Nasher because the mob called out for blood, but his only crime was being blinded by his desperate need to help save the city."
"Fenthick's death lead to Aribeth's betrayal: the city turned its back on one she loved, and she responded in kind."
"Aribeth represented everything good about Neverwinter, and when she fell a part of the city's spirit died. The city still stands, but some wounds are slow to heal. Perhaps that is why I left."
"I returned to my home, the lands of the Red Tiger tribe of the Uthgardt people."
"Bleak, yes. But accurate. The city will rebuild, in time. But I wanted nothing more to do with it. I returned to my home, the lands of the Red Tiger tribe of the Uthgardt people."
The massive barbarian gives a forlorn sigh. "Maybe it would be best if we continued this discussion at a later time. I'd rather keep my mind focused on surviving Undermountain right now."
"As you wish."
"I shall serve you with fierce loyalty, as if you were one of the Red Tiger tribe itself."
"Very well. Perhaps I can tell you later, if you wish."
"I was thinking about Undermountain, and about all those who have died here. Throughout Faerun Halaster's dungeon is well known as an adventurers' graveyard."
"Very well. I will keep my thoughts to myself, then."
"I just can't understand why someone would want to come down here. Why risk your life in a dungeon designed specifically to kill you."
The half-orc nods. "I suppose I can respect that. But it still seems there are other places besides Undermountain to test an adventurer's mettle."
"There's treasure, yes... but not enough to justify the risk. There must be a dozen other places a person could find more riches than in Undermountain; places a lot less dangerous."
"Heroes? The adventurers who came in here only came to help themselves - that's not very heroic. I'm sure they could have found a more useful way to prove their worth."
"This place has a strange hold on the minds of adventurers. It's legend has spread far and wide, and I can't help but wonder if there's something unnatural about it."
"I was thinking the same thing. Halaster spent decades designing this dungeon, he poured all of his time and energy into its creation. He probably wants his creation to be seen."
"Wouldn't it make sense for Halaster to weave a spell into the very fabric of this dungeon? A spell that gives the very name of Undermountain itself the power to draw unsuspecting adventurers in?"
"Maybe. But maybe there's something more. Maybe the name of Undermountain is like some type of geas: adventurers who hear the name are compelled to visit it."
"No? Halaster is an archmage. Who are we to say what his power is? Maybe the name of Undermountain is like some type of geas: adventurers who hear the name are compelled to visit it."
"The compulsion is weak, it can be resisted... but it's there. The thought sits in the back of your mind, eating away at your thoughts until one day you give in and go to Undermountain itself."
The half-orc shrugs. "I don't know. It just seems like Undermountain is inside my head, and I can't get it out. Maybe everything will be fine once we find Halaster. At least, I hope so."
"Think about it. Halaster spent decades designing this dungeon, he poured all of his time and energy into its creation. He probably wants his creation to be seen."
"That's different. We're serving a noble purpose, we're trying to save an entire city. But what about those who came here before the attacks on Waterdeep? What was their purpose?"
"I have something to confess, <FirstName>. Something that is... difficult. But this is something I feel you have a right to know."
"As you wish. Let's just get back to the task at hand, then."
"I don't like this place. I suppose nobody in their right mind enjoys traveling through Undermountain, what with all the traps and monsters. But for me it goes beyond that."
"The air here is heavy and stale. The halls are too narrow. The ceilings are too low. And what if the mountain above us collapses, and buries us under an avalanche of rock and stone?"
"I will not abandon you! We of the Uthgardt believe we must face our fears. By doing so, we conquer them, and they have no more power over us."
"I just thought you should know about my... condition, since you seem to be leading this expedition. But I swear I won't let it affect me during our mission."
"I know it must seem irrational, but I have lived my life on the great plains of my tribe. I am used to the open sky and the sting of the cold wind against my face. This place feels wrong to me."
"Yes, of course. I know that. And we of the Uthgardt believe we must face our fears. By doing so, we conquer them, and they have no more power over us."
"No! Well... yes. Maybe a little. It isn't normally a problem, I've been in dungeons beneath the earth before. But Undermountain is different. More intense."
--------- Random Conversations begin here ----------
"This door looks like some kind of fail safe, a way for Halaster to control the creatures of Undermountain and keep them confined to their respective levels."
"This dungeon is filled with all manner of powerful and dangerous creatures. If they banded together they could prove troublesome, even for an archmage like Halaster."
"What really concerns me is the fact that this door is sealed. If the emergency systems have been triggered, it likely means Halaster is no longer in control."
"As you wish."
The half-orc shakes his head. "I couldn't even begin to guess. But I suspect we'll have to figure it out if we want to go any deeper into this maze."
There is a legend among we Uthgardt, a tale of a lost tribe. It says they vanished beneath the earth, and the bones of the chieftains now stand guard over the tribe's treasure."
"I am only saying we should be careful here. Make of my warning what you will."
"The legend holds that the skeletons remain still until their treasure is disturbed, then spring to life to slay the living."
"I doubt we have found the remains of the lost tribe from the Uthgardt legend, but I imagine every culture has similar tales of undead guardians lying in wait."
"No, probably not. But I imagine every culture has similar tales of undead guardians that sit silent and still until their treasure is disturbed."
"As you wish."
"It wouldn't surprise me, given what we've already seen in this dungeon."
"As you wish. Would you like me to join with once more?"
"I can't deny the truth of what you say, <FirstName>. My failure brings dishonor to my tribe and my Uthgardt heritage. Yet I know I can do better!"
The half-orc sighs. "If my role as a front line fighter can best serve the group, then I suppose I will just have to find some way to accept that my death will always be close at hand."
Daelen nods. "I know you speak the truth, but I have always prided myself on my strength. I do not take well to dying... though I suppose nobody does."
"I will not make vain boasts or promises I may not be able to keep, <FirstName>. But if you will have me join you again, I swear I will serve you as best as I am able."
The half-orc looks as if his pride has been momentarily wounded, but he is quick to try and hide his disappointment. "As you wish. I will be here if you change your mind."
The half-orc allows himself the hint of a smile. "Then let us return to Undermountain... and this time I plan to fare far better than my last visit!"
------- This line must be placed at the end of inter-party banter ---------
"Yes, Daelen? Is there something you need?"
"What? What are you talking about?"
"You've been watching me quite closely. Not that I mind - I'm used to men staring at me. But I just wanted to make sure there wasn't anything more to it than a simple ogling."
The half-orc clears his throat, clearly uncomfortable. "I was not ogling you, Sharwyn."
The bard arches an eyebrow. "You weren't? That's a shame, Daelen. So why weren't you ogling me? Don't you find me attractive?"
"Well... yes. You're attractive. But I wasn't... Okay, maybe I was. But that doesn't mean..." The half-orc gives you a desperate look. "<FirstName>, I could use a little help here."
"Yes, Daelen. You made this bed, now you have to lie in it... if you're lucky." She gives the Daelen a knowing wink and a laugh, then walks off with a toss of her hair.
Sharwyn smiles. "I'm out of every man's league. But some men are closer than others." She gives Daelen a knowing wink, then walks off with a toss of her long, red hair.
The half-orc barks out a harsh laugh. "A couple? I think you got hit on the head in the last battle, <FirstName>. Look at us. Sharwyn's way out of my league."
"But it's so fun! Besides, deep down he loves it. Don't you Daelen?" She gives the half-orc a knowing wink, then laughs and walks off with a toss of her long, red hair.
The half-orc gives you a sheepish grin. "Maybe I was staring, but you have to admit she's a hard woman to ignore."
"Sharwyn, may I speak to you for a moment? I was... I was wondering how you were feeling after... well, after being killed during the ambush."
"I'm doing quite well, considering. No ill affects, no lingering symptoms." She tilts her head to the side and gives Daelan a long stare. "It's something we've all been through before, Daelen."
The half-orc suddenly drops his eyes. "Yes, of course. I just... I just feel like I let you down. I'm the warrior of our group, I was supposed to protect you. Uh... you and the others, of course."
Sharwyn's brow knots up in anger. "Are you saying I need my own personal guardian? I may not be as strong as you, Daelen - few people are. But I have other talents that serve me well enough."
"We don't all rely on brutish strength and a big axe! My spells and bard songs are all I need, so don't waste any extra effort watching out for poor Sharwyn. She can look after herself!"
The half-orc is obviously taken aback by her harsh reaction. "I... I didn't mean it like that, Sharwyn. I've watched you in action; I know you can look after yourself."
The bard gets a mischievous glint in her eye. "You've been watching me in action, have you? And do you like what you see?"
The half-orc blushes. "Yes... I mean no, not like that. That is... look, I'm just glad you're okay." Sharwyn laughs and walks away, leaving the half-orc shaking his head in exasperation.
"Deekin, could you please stop with that humming? It's beginning to get on my nerves."
"You hear Deekin's humming? You gots good ears. Maybe you like if Deekin sing instead? Deekin sing real good. Just ask Boss. Boss likes when Deekin sings."
"Please don't. No singing, no humming. How about we try moving with no sound at all? Just to see what it's like?"
"Okay, that give Deekin time to work on song about you, Daelen."
"You're working on a song about me?" The half-orc's voice betrays more fear than you've ever heard from him in battle. "What kind of song?"
"You big, strong orc-man! You need big, strong orc-man song! But it hard... not much rhyme with orc. Fork... uh... pork..."
"Fork and pork? Those are my options? They seem more suited to a cook than a barbarian. What about... uh... hmmm, I guess it is hard to find a good rhyme for orc."
"Yeah, it be easier if you a cook. You ever think about changing jobs? Deekin knows lots of rhymes for cooking: fork and pork; pot and hot; eat and meat. See?"
"Tell you what, Deekin. If I ever become a cook, you can write all the songs you want about me. Until then, let's just leave me out of your music. Deal?"
The kobold smiles. "Sounds good to Deekin." The kobold walks off, humming once again. Daelen watches him go, then smiles and shakes his head.
"Oh, Boss. You not mean that. You just in a bad mood. Deekin sing a song to cheer Boss up."
"Tomi... what are you doing?"
"Huh? What? Doing? Eh... I ain't doing nothin'! Relax, me burly mate. Let yer guard down a bit. Yer always so suspicious."
"I've learned to be suspicious when you're around, Tomi. You're watching me more than I like, halfling. I know what you're up to. You're *casing* me!"
"Casing you? Nah, you got it all wrong. I just... uh... I just like to watch you fight. You sure can smack folks around. I just like to see our enemies get what's coming to 'em, is all."
"Keep playing me for a fool and I'll see you get what's coming to you, Tomi. I know exactly how many coins I've got on me, and if even one goes missing..."
"Oi, that ain't fair! You got them fat ol' fingers. What if yer digging something out of yer pack and you drop a coin in the dust? You can't blame Tomi if he picks it up. Finders keepers, right?"
"Finders keepers? Tell you what, Tomi: if I *find* you took anything from me and I'll *keep* smacking you upside the head until you give it back."
Tomi's eyes go wide with surprise. "Okay, okay. I get it. Daelen doesn't like to share. Sheesh, you'd think I was some kind of common criminal."
"Linu, would you be so kind as to watch where you're walking? This is the third time you've stomped on my heel this morning."
"Oh, I'm sorry, dear. I don't mean to do it, but I tend to stumble on this uneven ground. You know how clumsy I can be... it's a wonder I haven't broken my leg on this trip."
"I wouldn't worry about that. Your accidents have a way of working out.
Linu shrugs. "Yes, I do have a bit of luck when it comes to that sort of thing. Still, I wish I wasn't so clumsy. Sometimes I wish I could be graceful, like so many other women."
"But maybe if you were more graceful, you wouldn't be so lucky. These things have a way of balancing out. A stumble or two is a small price to pay for long term good fortune."
"Hmmm... I never thought of it that way before. Thank you, Daelen. It's time I realize these clumsy feet of mine are really a blessing!"
"I'm glad you feel that way. But please, just try to keep your *blessings* from treading on my heels for the rest of the morning."
Linu smiles. "Of course, dear. I'll just walk a little farther behind you from now on."
"Join me."
"Never mind."
"I think we need to part ways."
"I've changed my mind. Stay with me."
"Wait here until I return."
"I'm sure. Go back to Durnan's inn."
"I want to change your tactics."
"I don't want to change anything else right now."
"I want you to leave any traps that you see alone for now."
"I want you to disarm any traps that you see."
"Don't try to be stealthy anymore."
"Stay stealthy, but only until the next fight."
"Try to remain stealthy all the time."
"Don't help me if I fail to open a locked door or chest."
"Help me if I fail to open a locked door or chest."
"I want to change the distance you stay away from me."
Stay a long distance away.
Keep a medium distance.
Stay close.
"Go ahead and attack as soon as you see enemies."
"Defend me and don't attack until I do."
"I want to adjust your equipment."
"I need you to use your barbarian rage."
"On second thought, don't bother."
"I'm sure. Do it now."
"What was it you wanted to say earlier?"
"Let's stop and talk for a moment."
"That's enough chatting."
"No, nothing else."
"I'm just wondering how everything is going with you."
"What do you plan to do after all this is done?"
"A month after that you'll want to leave again."
"Finally ready to settle down?"
"What did you do after you left Neverwinter?"
"Do I look like I care about this?"
"What happened next?"
"So you were finally accepted?"
"Where did you go?"
"Nothing more than a strange coincidence."
"Sounds like fate to me."
"Sounds like you were running away."
"You said you came from Neverwinter?"
"That's funny. I don't remember hearing anything about you helping to save Neverwinter."
"I remember hearing about you. You're quite famous."
"You must have been very popular in Neverwinter after that."
"I really don't care about this."
"Why not?"
"What do you mean?"
"You're talking about Lady Aribeth, aren't you?"
"Where did you go after that?"
"That's a pretty bleak account of what happened."
"No, not yet. Stay here."
"Yes, come along."
"Not right now."
"What is it?"
"I don't have time for this."
"Is there some point here?"
"Yes, it's a truly dangerous place."
"It's about the challenge. Testing yourself, testing your limits."
"Greed. There's a lot of treasure down here."
"Fame. It's a place for heroes to prove themselves."
"Maybe it has something to do with Halaster's magic."
"This is crazy. Undermountain is famous on its own merits."
"I hadn't thought of that before."
"No spell is that powerful."
"What do you mean?"
"We're down here."
"We don't have time for this."
"Fine - out with, half-orc."
"What? Is something wrong?"
"Are you quitting on me, you big baby?"
"Don't worry, the mountain won't collapse on us."
"Maybe you should go back to the surface."
"Don't worry, Daelen. Everything will be fine."
"You're claustrophobic!"
"That seems rather obvious, don't you think?"
"Why would he need a fail safe?"
"Let's just move on."
"Any idea how we get this door open?"
"I think I can handle this without your little tale."
"Stand guard? What do you mean?"
"And you think these skeletons are from that tribe?"
"You didn't really tell me anything I didn't already know."
"Thanks for the warning. Let's move on."
"So you think these skeletons will come to life?"
"Never mind. I don't want to discuss it."
"You keep dying. That's not very helpful."
"You're in the front of every battle. What do you expect?"
"Undermountain is a dangerous place. Death isn't unexpected."
"Just stay here, for now."
"I want you to join me again."
"Don't worry about it."
"You were the one staring. Get yourself out of this mess."
"Forget about her, Daelen. She's out of your league."
"What's the problem? I think you make a nice couple."
"Sharwyn, stop picking on Daelen."
"Maybe this isn't the best time for a song, Deekin."
"That's true. Why don't you sing for us now, Deekin?"
"I do not!"
"You takes Deekin with you now, yes?"

"What should Deekin calls new book when it done?"
"Mmmm... maybe Deekin gots ideas. But Deekin thought he maybe asks boss this time."
"Book is all about the boss and the great, epic adventure! Does boss really not haves an opinion?"
"Hmm. Maybe Deekin calls it 'Adventures of the Boss'? Now that gots nifty ring to it!"
"Hmph. Don't reminds Deekin. Deekin hates that guy! Deekin tracks him down one day and gives him swift kicks in buttocks! Grrr!"
"But the boss is probably right. Oh well."
"That be what Deekin wants to calls it last time. Hmmm... maybe 'Adventures of <FullName>, the Sequel'? Nobody ever tries that before."
"Oh. Ummm... Deekin wasn't thinking of calling it anything so silly. Ha ha..." he pulls out his notebook and begins quickly scratching out several notes.
"Gosh. Deekin was thinkings exactly the same thing. Isn't it great that Deekin and boss thinks so much alike?"
"Ha ha. The boss is a comedian now, Deekin sees."
"Deekin is writing in epic tale... and Deekin just wondering..."
"Deekin wonders how boss wants to, ummm... how you wants to be described?"
"O-oookay, boss. But don't you come cryings to Deekin later if people says you not looks like Deekin writes you looks."
"Ummm... Deekin could, maybe, but he hears that <race> men be very vain..."
"Ummm... Deekin could, maybe, but he hears that <race> ladies be sensitives about that sort of thing..."
"But... that entire purpose of Deekin travelings with you, boss! Deekin is here to records your journey! To brings your greatness to all of the world! Does you not want say in how you is described?"
"Well... I says that you is a handsomes <race> man. I always calls you that, when I not calls you boss."
"Hmmm... now how Deekin describes you without gettings into trouble..."
"Okay, Deekin thinks he gets hint, boss. Thanks for helping."
"Tells the truth? Peoples always gets mad when Deekin tells the truth. No, Deekin thinks he much safer when he lies kobold butt off. Thanks, boss."
"Really? But nobody recognizes you from *that* description. Oh well, Deekin keeps on trying..."
"Well... I says that you is a beautiful <race> lady. I always calls you that, when I not calls you boss."
"Does you remembers old master at all?"
"Deekin remembers when you tells Deekin that he be free. He almost not believe it that old master lets him go. Deekin was very happy."
"Deekin just wonders... when you talks to old master, did he talks about Deekin at all?"
"Oh. Sometimes Deekin misses old master, too, but that not what Deekin talks about."
"Old master tell Deekin once that Deekin gots lots of dragon blood. Deekin not be sure about that... Deekin not be bigger or stronger, he not breathes fire or anything."
"Maybe that be okay... unless Deekin breathes fire all the time. Then it be hard to eats."
"No, old master not jokes often. Not with Deekin. Lots of times he not makes sense, though."
"Maybe. Deekin not really thinks so, but sometimes he wonders."
"Old master tell Deekin once that Deekin gots lots of dragon blood. But he never tells Deekin more... and now that Deekin go through changes..."
"So Deekin wonder if old master not say anything abouts Deekin? Nothing likes that?"
"Oh. Deekin hopes that... well, Deekin just gots to makes best of it."
"Oh. Deekin... Deekin try, boss."
"So you not remembers if old master says anything? Anything at all?"
"Yes, Deekin remembers you tellings Deekin that. Deekin felt a bit sad... though Deekin know that old master would never let him go otherwise."
"Oh. Deekin hope maybe you remembers. It not important."
"Ummm... you thinks it be okay if Deekin writes in book that he not likes Waterdeep?"
"Deekin reads so much about Waterdeep when he was with old master... there be so many books, so many! Deekin read them all! He always wonder how so many peoples lives in one place!"
"So when Deekin leaves Hilltop, he heads first to Waterdeep. Deekin go to the big city! If Deekin makes it there, Deekin makes it anywhere!"
Deekin shuffles his feet. "Deekin not makes it there. Everybody in Waterdeep is very mean to little Deekin."
"Sorry, boss. Deekin just... want to gets it all right in book."

"They chases Deekin with pitchforks, sends guards to run Deekin down. Deekin gets thrown out of so many inns... he sleeps for three days in cold gutters before Deekin finally find half-orc who lets Deekin use stable."
"Deekin just was hoping that... maybe Waterdeep gots people who treats him nice. Like you."
"You free Deekin. That nicest thing anyone does for Deekin."
"Heh heh... you talks like that, boss, but Deekin knows you not means it."
"It not so bad, maybe. Eventually people stop chasings Deekin. Deekin publishes great epic tale of boss, just like he says he would."
"But Deekin not gets great adventure he hopes for. World is so big and Deekin is so small. Maybe next time Deekin start with village and works up to Waterdeep from there?"
"Deekin not knows much about drow. Does boss knows about drow?"
"Uh, Deekin gots question about drow. Maybe boss knows answer?"
"Oh. Okay. It not so important, anyway."
"Ummm... most surface creature that be underground for long time and not gets sunshine, they gets all pale and whites. Deekin's tribe sometimes take slaves and they all gets like that."
"Deekin hear that drow be from surface once. How come they not be all whites and pale? How come they gots black skin?"
"And why they gots white hair? Somebody scares them real bad, once? It all very strange to little Deekin."
"Maybe you is right boss. Deekin always think they shoulds be grey, then, like dwarves and gnomes... but Deekin not knows a lot about these things. It is strange."
"Oooo... Deekin writes that down! Thanks, boss!"
"But... some <race> folks is evil..."
"Oh. Deekin not realizes that be a rule, exactly... thanks, boss."
"Deekin sees one once. But old master eats him really quickly. He says drow be extra, extra tasty."
"Yup. Old boss says dark meat be best."
"Oh? Deekin not realize that be important."
"Ummm... yeah. Of course Deekin knows that! Gosh... what you thinks of Deekin, boss? Ha ha..."
"Do you thinks Deekin should change name, maybe?"
"Really? Not even if Deekin changes name to Deekin the Greatest Kobold Ever, maybe? Could boss calls Deekin that?"
"Oh. Okay. Sorry, boss."
"Awww. Deekin would call you the Greatest Boss Ever. If you asks Deekin to."
"Ha ha! Boss be so funny!"
"Deekin was thinking he need better name, maybe. To go on Deekin's book."
"But what should Deekin change it to? Something macho, maybe?"
"Deekin likes the boss' name... but it probably not be very appropriate for little Deekin. And you probably not thrilled if Deekin do that..."
"Ummm... it not exactly roll off tongue. Maybe Deekin names himself Donald?"
"Really? Deekin not so sure. 'Donald Scalesinger'... hmmm. Deekin sleeps on it, maybe..."
"Okay. Deekin think on it some more, boss."
"Deekin reads it on scroll somewhere. Hmmm. Maybe Deekin thinks on it a bit more..."
"You thinks so? Okay. Maybe Deekin just worries too much. Thanks boss!"
"Oh, it just sound so... so... Deekin. People who picks up book, they scrunches up nose and says Deekin's name out loud like they think chicken writes book, maybe."
"Hmph. Ha ha. Boss is so very funny. Deekin ask you later when you not feels like giant comedian."
"Deekin wonder sometimes... does you ever miss old dwarf? What his name? Master Drogan?"
"Oh. Deekin just wonders. Deekin misses old master sometimes."
"Yes, that what Deekin want. Deekin got everything he want, in the end."
"Not all the times. Some of the times old master treat Deekin nice, and he teaches Deekin everything Deekin knows. That why Deekin serve old master so long... Deekin owe him."
"No. Deekin not want to go back to ice caves... there be nothing there for Deekin, anyway. And Deekin not want to risk becoming slave again."
"Sometimes Deekin just wants to go and tells tale to someone who know Deekin then, so they sees Deekin as Deekin is now. So Deekin share what Deekin has become."
"Deekin think old master would be happy for Deekin. Does... does boss think Master Drogan would be happy with boss?"
"Oh. Sorry, boss. Deekin be quiet, then."
"Deekin thinks so. Yes, Deekin quite sure that Master Drogan woulds be happy with boss."
"No? Oh. Deekin finds that very sad, somehow. Oh, well."
"How we divides treasure we finds? You keeps it all? Deekin gets some, maybe?"
"So... you wants Deekin to call dibs?"
"Oh. So Deekin is now just hireling. Deekin understand." Deekin takes out his notebook and, hiding it from you, furiously scribbles several notes.
"Well... Deekin hears that adventurers always works out who gets dibs. Deekin *could* just calls dibs whenever we finds treasure."
Deekin smiles broadly, showing rows of sharp teeth. "You so good to little Deekin, boss! Dibs it is!"
"But... Deekin wants to be proper adventurer!"
"Mmmm. So says the boss who carries all the gold. Deekin gets it." He takes out his notebook and, hiding it from you, scribbles some notes furiously.
"Deekin not thinks of it quite that way. You are so good to little Deekin, boss!"
"So just because Deekin be kobold he not be proper adventurer? You hurt Deekin's feelings, boss. Deekin remembers that when it come time to right dedication on epic book!"
--------- Random Conversations begin here ----------
"Ummm... Deekin guesses this all be over soon, right? We almost be out of here?"
"And then what? We fights the bad guy?"
"Well... Deekin just want to tells you, boss... Deekin gots full confidence that you goings to win. You is the greatest hero ever."
"Oh, Deekin would never forgets that! Onto the end of the adventure! Woo hoo!"
"Heh... is nice of you to say, boss. Onto the end of the adventure! Woo hoo!"
"Onto the end of the adventure! Woo hoo!"
"What you calls this place?"
"And who is Reaper? Or maybe Deekin should ask *what* is Reaper?"
"Okays, Deekin just writes... ummm... 'strange, scary place with creepy ghost that boss knows'. That work good."
"Deekin need background for epic tale. Deekin never be here before, remember?"
"And you finds rock in Shadow Plane? And rock brings you here?"
"And Reaper sends you wherever you wants to go?"
Deekin scratches his chin thoughtfully and then finally takes out his book and scribbles several notes in it. "Okay, boss. Deekin just needs to check. You goes on, now."
"Deekin wants to know what boss says, first, before he talks to something named Reaper."
"Deekin be pretty sure we has up and gone to the Hells."
"Oh. Ummm... sorry, boss."
"Ummm... there not goings to be many nice people here, Deekin thinks."
"You is thinking of the Abyss, maybe, boss. That be completely different place."
"All the, ummm, dead people? And demons. Or is these devils? Deekin always gets that mixed up."
"Deekin thinks he remember legend about lost city. He reads book with old master, once, long time ago."
"Okay, then, boss. Deekin keeps it to himself."
"Well... this be part of avariel city. Avariel be winged elves, or so book say. Deekin never sees any elf that gots wings since he leaves caves, so maybe book not tells truth."
"Avariel city be high up in mountains, and everybody happy. Then one day - POOF! - everything disappear. Nobody know where, but legend say they go to darkest depths... which be here?"
"Aye-aye, boss! Let the adventure continue!"
"Deekin always love fact you is so ready to adventure, boss!"
"It looks just like picture."
"Umm... maybe there be a curse. Or a wizard. Or a queen. Or maybe that be a different story. Deekin can't quite remembers. Deekin just remember one day - POOF! - everything disappear."
"Ummm... nope. Story not say. It just say one day - POOF!. It not say one day - POOF! because..."
"Deekin not knows. Legend not mention where city gets sent, exactly, just that it go from mountain heights to darkest depths. Deekin thought that story just be guessing."
"You thinks tentacle-heads be able to read Deekin's thoughts, too?"
"You knows Deekin too well, boss."
"That... makes Deekin feel oddly comforted, boss."
"That is such a nice thing you says about Deekin, boss. You is so good to little Deekin!"
"Oo! You going to gives them heck, boss? Deekin looks at them and thinks they might go nice with tartar, maybe, but maybe you not thinks same thing."
"Deekin gots a bad feeling about this place."
"Okay, boss. Deekin just says it silently, though..."
"And who protects the boss? Like Deekin says: he gots ba-aaaad feeling about this place."
"What is wrong? Look around, boss? We is going inside Evil Fortress of DOOM!! That is *never* good."
"Well, Deekin means it. He gots ba-aaaaad feeling. Maybe it be the giant fortress of DOOM we is walking into, he not sure."
"This village... these all be surface people. What they doing here in Underdark, boss?"
"It is just... Deekin not sees anyone in village who not from surface. And who not dresses in ragsy clothes. Maybe they all be poor?"
Deekin looks again carefully. "All of them, boss? Deekin not sees any people who is not from surface. And not dressed in ragsy clothes."
"If they be slaves, maybe, then who they be slaves to?"
"You are right, boss! Let the adventure continue!!"
"Okay, boss. Deekin just worried... he pictures Deekin in chains and ragsy clothes and not likes that picture so much."
"How you thinks floating eyeballs makes tunnels? They blasts with eye-rays, maybe?"
"Oh. It just occurs to Deekin to wonder. Just ignore Deekin, boss."
"Slaves? You thinks maybe they gots kobold slaves?"
"Ummm... okay. Point taken, boss."
"That... not give good image to Deekin, boss. Bad boss! Bad, bad boss!"
"Hmm. Maybe they gots pretty female kobold slave that Deekin coulds rescue. That gives Deekin idea for good story..."
"Deekin wishes he gots eye-ray that makes stuff disappear. Monster come at boss: ZZAPP!! Deekin's room get dirty: ZZAPP!! Publisher smiles too much: ZZAPP!!"
"Oh. Deekin just... stand over here, then..."
"He changes title on Deekin and treats Deekin like silly kobold. ZZAPP!! Yeah, you takes that! You hears Deekin! ZZAPP!!"
"Deekin sees sarcastic boss: ZZAPP!!"
"Ruins be... strange place. Some different race lives in ruins before eyeballs, maybe, boss?"
"No. Deekin not recognize ruins at all. Deekin think it look drow, maybe, but then again Deekin be no expert on drow."
"Deekin just... feel strange. Magic feels dead here, boss. Deekin not likes this at all."
"Deekin do his best, boss. Without magic, though... that not exactly inspires Deekin with confidence."
"Deekin not know, really. It sound strange, but maybe there be artifact around that take magic away? That not natural thing, after all."
"Okay, boss. Without magic, though... Deekin feels queasy about that..."
"Deekin not knows much about golems. They be puts together by wizards, right?"
"So... is they alive, like Deekin? Do they gots to eats and sleeps and dreams and stuff? Do they wants things?"
Deekin nods, considering your words. "Deekin thinks you is right, maybe."
"It just seem to Deekin that if golems can thinks and feels and stuff that it be really sad they be down here since maker go away. Maybe they be stuck. Maybe they is angry."
"If Deekin was golem and dwarves keep coming down and taking golem parts, Deekin would be angry. Bored, mostly, but angry too."
"You be turned to stone once, boss. That not be same thing, maybe? How you feel when you be stone?"
"Deekin think it not be pleasant. Not be anything, maybe, to be stone is to feels nothing."
"Maybe that what it like to be stone. Or maybe to be golem is to be shut off and on, to exists and not exists. Maybe stone golem think about same thing?"
"Oh. It just stuff Deekin thinks about. Just ignore little Deekin, boss. Let us get back to adventuring!"
"Ooo, coulds we? That be great idea, boss!"
"Aww, that nicest thing boss says to little Deekin."
"That true. Though maybe it be fun to be made of wood... or gold, maybe! Then Deekin be worth lots!"
"Happy? If maker be gone, how you gots purpose? Deekin not wants to be thing that is made but gots no purpose. That not sounds happy to Deekin."
"Deekin realizes that there be water underground... even deep, deep caves where old boss lived gots lots of water..."
"But if drow gots ships... you thinks that be ship, maybe? If drow gots ships, that means that there be whole *sea* here! Maybe whole *ocean*!"
"Okay, boss. If you thinks we going to be on ship, soon, all Deekin asks is you warns him first..."
"Deekin not travels on ship, yet. Ummmm... it not looks very safe..."
"They not gots whole ocean underground, does they? How big cave would you needs?"
"Ummm... how you fits whole ocean underground? How big cave would you needs?"
"How you knows that, boss?"
"Oh. Deekin wishes he was as smart as the boss."
"Deekin remember reading in books that there whole races that lives underwater in Underdark. Fish mens with big lips and giant squids with brains that blows up your head!"
"And how they sails without stars and winds and stuff? Deekin not travels on any ship, yet, even back on surface. It not looks very safe..."
"Well that make Deekin feel better. Though Deekin's stomach still frightened. You just makes sure you tells Deekin first if we plans to go on ship, okay?"
"Hmmm. Maybe you is right, boss. Deekin not thinks about it that way. Deekin's stomach not so sure it agrees, though..."
"Ummm... okay, Deekin takes your word for it, boss. If Deekin gets his brain exploded by giant squid, though, he be very unhappy."
"That not makes Deekin feel better, boss. If you goings to puts us on ship, just makes sure you warns Deekin first, okay?"
"Ummm... we is really in Underdark. We is really, *really* in Underdark!"
Deekin stops and looks at you incredulously. "You wants a way out, boss? But why?"
"You not be happy?" Deekin's tone is incredulous, and he stares at you as if you have suddenly turned into a green ape. "Why you be not happy?"
"This be wonderful!" Deekin runs around on the spot, waving his hands in the air excitedly. "Deekin read *so* much about Underdark, now Deekin actually be *here*!"
"This be so good for Deekin's book! 'Epic hero goes to the deadly Underdark'! Sequel be greatest book ever!"
"Right, boss! Let the epic adventure continue!"

"Deekin travels all over when he leaves boss last time. What he really want to do, however, is go to Underdark! Even name is cool: Underdark! Gives Deekin little shiver. But Deekin too small to go, it too dangerous."
"Is not just Deekin's book, it is book of great, epic hero, too! You wants book to be good, don't you, boss?"
"You wants coin, boss? Deekin not earns much coin. Maybe publisher gots coin, Deekin not really know. All Deekin know is that lots of people read story. That make Deekin happy."
"Scared? Deekin want so bad to travel to Underdark earlier, during journeys, except he knows he just ends up slave to tentacle-heads or fed to drow spider, maybe."
"But now... now Deekin be in the Underdark with the great, epic hero! Deekin gets to travel Underdark while solving urgent mission of doo-oooom!"
"That be really, really cool, boss."
"Oh... no no! Don't leave Deekin now! Not until he sees the Underdark! Please, please, great hero!! Have mercy!!"
"Oh, Deekin is right. You come around to Deekin's way of thinking soon, boss. This be greatest adventure! You see!"
"Exactly! Yaaay for the boss! This be so much fun, Deekin just knows it!"
"Well, maybe it because you not pays much attention, boss."
"You sees that doorway? Deekin thinks we needs to get through that to go any further."
Deekin thinks about it for a moment and then points at the ground. "Down."
"It just is that Deekin remembers this doorway being mentioned in book Deekin reads. There be, ummm... four? Four chains? Four chains that bind the door to this plane."
"Every time door be used, chains disappear to places they is held, and you needs to gets them again to open door. Door gots long name, but Deekin forgets it now."
"Right-o, boss! Let the adventure continue!"
"Yeah, Deekin knows what you means, boss. Halaster must really gots puzzle fixation."
"Books say it changes, but always Undermountain be very big, very deep. We could go for weeks and weeks and still not sees end of it. But you not gets any deeper unless you finds chains first, boss."
"Deekin not knows. Book never says. Deekin thinks maybe it be different each time."
Deekin looks around the chamber with a wide-eyed expression of awe. "Deekin... Deekin knows what this place be called. It be, ummm, Hall of Sleeping Kings."
"Oh, sorry boss. Deekin just tries to help out."
"Ummm... okay, boss."
"Deekin thinks you gots to be careful not to upset nobody. Maybe if you pay good respect it be okay, Deekin not sure."
Deekin steals a wary glance at the skeletons about the room before continuing. "Deekin read long time ago that bodies of ancient human kings rest in Undermountain."
"They be great kings and queens and sorcerers, all from northern lands that existed before other lands that have also been forgotten. That means they is very old, boss."
"They wons great wars against enemies who not even exists any more. And here they is given place of honor by Halaster. Here they sleeps."
"Right, boss! Let the adventure continue!"
"You is welcome, boss. Always glad to helps out."
"It not be so different if there be lots of magic. You knows that, boss. Dead humans gets up and attacks just as quick as live humans. Sometimes quicker."
Deekin shrugs. "Deekin not knows. Maybe. Deekin doubts it be so easy to takes from them. Maybe that just wakes them up."
"Ummm... Deekin read about this place once. It be called the Hall of Mirrors, if Deekin remembers right... which he might nots..."
Deekin cringes away. "Oh. Sorry, boss... Deekin just tries to help..."
Deekin nods, but seems quite fearful. "Okay, boss..."
Deekin scratches his head and thinks for a moment. "When Deekin reads about it, Hall of Mirrors be nearer to entrance maybe. Some people who goes not far into Undermountain sees it before."
"Big mage Halaster moves it, maybe? Deekin not knows. But you needs to be careful if you looks into mirrors... some of them does strange things, like they pulls you in or copies you. Bad stuff."
"You is so good to little Deekin, boss."
"Aye-aye, boss! The adventure continues!"
"Then Deekin thinks you should be okays. Though Deekin kind of thinks that be very boring..."
Deekin shrugs. "Deekin thinks so. There might be mirror here that not likes that much, though. It be lots of bad luck, anyway, no?"

Deekin scratches his chin thoughtfully. "There be magic mirror which makes copy of someone who looks inside. Evil copy, kind of, that attacks you. Deekin seems to remember that one of these mirrors is one of those."
"You knows... like there be world on other sides of mirror which is all backwards? Or maybe that be another story Deekin reads..."
Deekin cautiously looks around before continuing. "You, ummm... you knows we is in Undermountain now, don't you?"
The kobold cringes away from you a little, obviously uncertain. "Well, ummm... you knows what that means, yes?"
Deekin dances from foot to foot, nervous. "Once you gets into Undermountain it means you not able to gets back out easy. Magic not work to takes you anywhere."
"Oh? Boss knows about that already? Deekin should have known. Sorry, boss... Deekin just be nervous. Deekin reads lots about Undermountain."
"Ummm... if you climbs rope, yup."
Deekin thinks for a moment and shrugs. "Deekin not knows for sure. Maybe boss' relic be more powerful. But stories all agree on same stuff, like teleports not works here."
"Deekin reads lots of stories about Undermountain. They all says same stuff, like teleports not works here."
Deekin shuffles a bit in place, seeming to get agitated just from standing still. "So, ummm... back to the adventure, boss?"
"Sure thing, boss."
"And so the saga continues!"
Deekin nods enthusiastically. "Deekin glad to hears it, boss! So, ummm... back to the adventure?"
"Back when Deekin work hard to amuse old boss, Deekin reads lots of books. Old boss likes to hear stories about Undermountain, so Deekin reads about those whenever Deekin finds them."
"Lots of it be just stories, maybe, but Deekin think lots of it be truth, too. Old boss had books which nobody else gots, so maybe Deekin knows things that nobody else knows."

"Some things Deekin knows, Deekin rather not knows. Like fact that wizard Halaster... human who builds all this... he be really crazy and wants to kill everybody who comes in. That makes Deekin nervous."
Deekin grins toothily. "Oh, Deekin knows *that*. Deekin worried more about boss than about Deekin. So, ummm... back to the adventure, boss?"
Deekin seems pleased by your response. "That be very true, boss. You is really smart. So, ummm... back to the adventure?"
Deekin seems unconvinced. "Wizards gots ways of living long time. Especially crazy ones, Deekin thinks."
"Ye-essss, but that not all it mean, boss."
"Oh. Boss really had no idea?"
Deekin stares at you for a long moment, and then blinks several times. "Deekin hears of Rashaman. Is that what peoples do there?"
"Oh." Disconcerted, Deekin takes out his tome and makes several notes in it, eyes wide. He then looks up at you again. "Well... we is in Undermountain now, boss. You knows what that means?"
"Okay. Deekin just worried that boss gets mad at Deekin, that all."
"Ummm... can Deekin expect to be raised lots, too, then?"
Deekin sidles up next to you and looks up at you pitifully. "So... you wants Deekin to comes along with you again, boss? That why you raises Deekin, right?"
"Yay! Onwards and forwards!"
"You wants Deekin... to stay here? Ummm... okay. Deekin do that. But Deekin gets lonely quick, you know..."
"Deekin just gets all excited! Deekin always think that boss be right behind him! Oh, well... Deekin tries to do better."
"Deekin not knows. He thought maybe there be more 'Wheeee!' and less 'Aiieeeee!' on this adventure, is all."
Deekin nods thoughtfully. "Ummm... okay. Deekin thinks hard about how to solves that."
"Oh. That good to know. Deekin was beginning to get worried."
------- This line must be placed at the end of inter-party banter ---------
"Ummm... is you really dead, elven lady? You not looks really dead."
"I am really dead, yes. Is that truly what you wished to know?"
"Ummm... not really. Deekin wonders how you be so good all of the time? Is it really hard?"
"Whatever do you mean?"
"Deekin try to be like you. He try to think only nice thoughts and even be holy... but then Deekin thinks of something funny and he laughs lots and it be too hard."
"To be pure of heart does not mean you must be humorless."
"But... you not laughs ever. You is always sad."
"I... but that does not mean anything, little one. That only means... that I am sad."
"You is sad? Why you be so sad? There be something Deekin can do to make you not sad?"
"N-no... no, little one. There's nothing you can do for me."
"Ummm... not really. Deekin wonders how you be so evil? Is it really hard?"
"Whatever do you mean?"
"Deekin looks in mirror and tries to be like you. He bares teeth and growls and goes 'Grrr! Grrr! Deekin be evil!' But he never be as scary as you."
"I assume that is a compliment."
"Just when Deekin thinks he be close to being evil, suddenly he think of something funny and he laughs lots and it be too hard."
"To be evil does not mean you must be humorless, kobold."
"Valen... Deekin just want you to know that he thinks you is really good fighter."
"I'm so happy you noticed."
"How you learns to fight like that?"
"The hard way. One death at a time."
"Ohhhh. Deekin was thinkings of asking for pointers... but maybe that not such a good idea."
"Why not? You perish much more, kobold, and I'll begin to suspect you're copying my methods."
"Deekin knows sarcasm when he hears it, you know."
"Perhaps you'll use that same keen sense to detect a proper musical note, sometime."
"Deekin is going to stop talkings to you now."
"Generous to a fault. You're a breed apart, kobold."
"Why is it you gots horns? Is you part goat?"
"In a manner of speaking. I am part demon... a tiefling, if you've ever heard of such a thing."
"Demons makes babies?"
"When they wish to. Are you always so blunt with your questions?"
"Deekin can be very innocent when he tries. That be part of his charm."
"Well, I have a weapon that can crush a man's skull into pulp before he even realizes he is dead. I've made corpses whose jaws still wag as they try to speak. That's part of *my* charm."
"Deekin once have old master who eat bad mushrooms and passes gas so bad it kill entire cave full of kobolds. Deekin stick head in water bucket, only reason he alive today."
"I've cut my way through a hundred men, breathing in their own gore, and felt the slash of a hundred blades against my skin yet never died."
"Old Master roll over on top of Deekin once while he sleeping. Old Master be real heavy."
"Not much fazes you, does it?"
"Nope, not much."
"So Deekin hears that you never sees sun before."
"I have not yet been to the surface lands. That is correct."
"Is you nervous at all? The sun be very bright. Deekin remember when he first sees it."
"I... have tried to imagine it."
"You never imagines it. It be so bright, it bores into your skull. And the sky be all open above you, you be sure you going to fall up and up and up into big blacknesss --"
"Silence!"
"You not looks so good."
"It... is a passing thing. Perhaps you feel the need to bother <FirstName> a bit longer, yes?"
"Nope. Deekin is fine here."
"Joy."
"Why is it that Deekin never hears you when you walks, drow lady?"
"It... is a skill that has been imprinted upon my heart. To make sounds when I walk was death when I was a Red Sister."
"You had to learns to be real quiet?"
"Indeed. Or my tutor would have slain me."
"He kills you if you not learns it properly?"
"No. *She* had no eyes. And if she ever heard something moving within her hearing she would lash out with poisoned darts. And she never missed. That made it imperative to move silently."
"You coulds just move faster, too."
Nathyrra smirks. "Aye. You could simply move faster, as well. But so could she."
"You pays lots to go to this school?"
"It was not a school. The Red Sisters are an order of assassins that I trained with."
"You gots lots of friends who becomes Red Sisters with you?"
"You mean of my class? No. After the training, it is the last survivor of a class who graduates and becomes a full Red Sister."
"Ummm... Deekin not sure he think that kind of education is a good idea..."
"But it is... thorough."
"Ummmmm... heh heh. Did Deekin ever tells Sharwyn lady that she is so very pretty?"
"No, Deekin never has. By the way you've been staring at me, however, I kind of figured that's what you had in mind."
"What you means?"
"You needn't be coy, my little lizard friend. Between one bard to another, I know what such glances mean."
"Deekin was lookings at Sharwyn's hair."
"Really, I'm flattered, but you must know it just isn't... what?"
"Deekin was lookings at Sharwyn's hair. Is very pretty, but there be different color near Sharwyn's head. That be normal? Deekin not sees that before."
"Of... of course it's normal! Look... I'll give you twenty gold not to mention that to anyone else."
"Thirty."
"Fine, thirty. Now stop talking."
"Ummm... Deekin gots question for Sharwyn. Did you writes book called 'Neverwinter Nights'?"
"I did, indeed, my little man. And I assume you were the scribe behind 'Shadows of Undrentide'?"
"You reads Deekin's book? Deekin so excited! Did you likes it?"
"Well... it started out well enough. But the second chapter seemed a bit... rushed..."
"Deekin was running lots."
"There were other problems, too. I'd be happy to list them for you sometime, if you're of a mind."
"Deekin would likes that! Deekin can tells you what was wrongs with 'Neverwinter Nights', then, too!"
"What are you talking about? There was nothing wrong with my book."
"Is you joking?"
"Oh, shush, you." Sharwyn turns away. "Critic."
"So does they gots kobolds where you comes from, Daelan?"
"Near my tribe? Yes, they do. I have crushed many kobolds in my day, as have the other warriors of my tribe."
"Ohhhh. That not be good."
"Not at all, Deekin. You are nothing like those wicked fiends I battled as a youth. You have something they will never possess."
"A good pair of shoes?"
"Honor. That is the true mark of difference that divides the beasts from the civilized men."
"You thinks Deekin gots honor?"
"I think you strive for honor, little one, whether you know that is the path you are on or not. To strive for honor is to achieve it, and that makes you worthy of respect."
"No kobold ever be worthy of respect before."
"You need not be the last, Deekin. Maybe it is your destiny to be an emissary. Have you ever thought of that?"
"You makes Deekin thinks lots."
"I certainly hope so."
"So... Deekin is wonderings something. You is part orc?"
"Yes, that is true."
"Deekin sees lots of orcs before. You looks a little likes them, maybe, but not whole lots."
"I am also partly human. The product of violence against my tribe. Surely you have heard of such couplings, kobold... your kind raids as much as the orcs ever have."
"Kobolds not do such things. Deekin not think kobolds able to do such things."
"Perhaps your kind is simply too different from the other humanoid races."
"Old Master says that kobolds gots dragon blood! Though, ummm, he not exactly says that in a happy way..."
"Dragon blood is strong. You should be proud of that. Draw strength and courage from it, little one."
"You is kind of neat. Deekin likes you. Maybe he pencils you into the boss' epic story as sidekick."
"I would be honored."
"Ahem! Ummm... Deekin writes a poem for you, nice elven lady..."
"Oh? Ha ha ha! You can call me Linu, Deekin. It's quite alright."
"Oh, no... Deekin coulds never do that!"
"Suit yourself, dear. Do I get the honor of hearing your poem?"
"Okay! Holds on... how it goes again? Oh! Deekin remembers now!"
"There once be elf lady so pretty and sweet, such pretty red hairs and two big left feet, in combat she fumbles, while walking she stumbles, it be so cute you thinks she be neat!"
"Err... and this is complimentary?"
"Deekin thinks you is the greatest!"
"I see. Err... thank you. Perhaps I'll... walk closer to <FirstName>. Excuse me."
"Can Deekin asks pretty elven lady somethings?"
"My, aren't you the sweetest thing? You can ask me whatever you like, dear."
"Okay. Deekin wants to know why you is so clumsy? Deekin sees lots of elves and they not be so clumsy like you."
"Well, I... I wouldn't say I was *clumsy*, exactly..."
"No, you is really clumsy. Deekin sees you getting stuff out of pack before, and you ends up almost knocking boss unconscious."
"Yes, well... I did apologize for that..."
Linu sighs, not entirely pleased. "I... let's just say that everyone has their area of speciality, alright?"
"So you is especially clumsy?"
"How about you go back to singing that lovely doom song again, my little friend? That was so much more entertaining."
"Okay. Deekin be glad you likes it."
"But she say Deekin could asks! Deekin just be curious."
Linu glares at you with a mixture of mortification and exasperation. "I *said* I was sorry! The pan was so wedged in there..."
"Deekin thinks it was funny. Boss gets really weird look. But, ummmm... you not answers question."
"Boss! Deekin not likes how Tomi is lookings at him!"
"I wasn't looking at ya any which how, ya overgrown lizard!"
"Deekin says you is, you... you scale-less kobold!"
"Scale-less kobold? Are you joshing me? Is that the best you can do?"
"Deekin not wants to insults you lots. That not be very nice of Deekin..."
"That's sort of the whole bleedin' point! You need to shake your fist and really threaten someone. Come on, now..."
"You mean like this? Grrr!!"
"There ya go! Now say 'You are a pink-skinned, smelly little sewer rodent!'"
"You is a pink-skinned smelly little sewer rodent!"
"Not bad, not bad. You've really got to work on that, though."
"Deekin feel all funny. He wants to go slaps something, maybe."
"Where did Deekin's money pouch go? Deekin hads money pouch, and now it be gone. It falls off, maybe?"
"Now there's no need ta look at me with them beady little eyes o' yours, kobold! Just 'cause I'm a thief doesn't mean I steal."
"Ummm... Deekin not looks at you likes anything..."
"Oh, yes you did! I saw them accusing little eyes! Do you know who I am? Tomi Undergallows, that's who! And you... you're just a kobold!"
"But Deekin not *says* anything! There only be few coins in pouch, maybe..."
"Oh, I see. Now it's the guilt trip, is it? Alright. Fine. Here, take it. Take your bloody money pouch! Are you happy now?"
"You gots Deekin's money pouch! Yay! Tomi, you is the greatest!"
"Hmph. Tell me somethin' I don't know."
"Join me."
"Never mind."
"I think we need to part ways."
"Alright, fine. Stay with me, then."
"Wait here until I return."
"Go on. Maybe we'll meet later."
