"What was it you wanted to say earlier?"
"Let's stop and talk for a moment."
"We're done chatting."
"No, nothing else."
"I'm just wondering how everything is going with you."
"I wish to discuss your training."
"I want you to do whatever you like, Deekin."
"Continue with what you're doing now."
"Concentrate on becoming a dragon disciple."
"I want you to focus on being a bard."
"I'm wondering... what do you plan to do once this adventure is done?"
"Yes, after that."
"Yes, yes, after the book."
"You damn well better get a better price."
"You think you will?"
"Why would you go back there?"
"Don't you want to stay with me?"
"That seems like a very odd thing to do."
"You want your tribe to live in civilized lands? Why?"
"Whatever works for you. Just keep the crazy to yourself."
"Well... let's concentrate on finishing this adventure, first."
"If there's anything I can do to help..."
"I think that's a noble goal."
"Do you think you can really make them change?"
"How about a good tale?"
"Are you saying we're doomed?"
"You did? When was this?"
"Why didn't you normally do that?"
"Sounds like you got lucky."
"What happened next?"
"And you ended up leaving?"
"I'm flattered, Deekin."
"Yeah, yeah, yeah. Let's move on."
"You missed me? Awww, Deekin..."
"You couldn't protect her?"
"I'm so sorry, Deekin. That's horrible."
"What was she doing outside?"
"This isn't like the time you met a dragon, is it?"
"Go ahead, then."
"You forgot your lute?"
"A drow elf? In Waterdeep? Are you sure?"
"Sounds like a drow all right."
"I've heard that scream."
"He let you go?"
"Did he tell you his name?"
"Drippits? That doesn't sound like much of a drow name."
"Really? What kind of dragon?"
"Inside Waterdeep?"
"How do you know that?"
"He went to Hilltop to eat pie?"
"What about the Gold dragon? What did he want?"
"So that's your story about meeting another dragon?"
"Err... I can't help but notice that you've grown wings..."
"Can you fly with them?"
"A kobold with wings. How interesting."
"You were hoping for something different?"
"You don't like it?"
"*That's* your complaint?"
"Be thankful for what you have."
"But red is much cooler than white."
"You seem a bit different from when I first met you."
"Strange how?"
"You damn well better not mean it, kobold."
"Just make sure you control these urges, Deekin."
"Errr... yeah..."
"If it makes you stronger, I'm all for it."
"I'm glad you're enjoying your progress."
"The boss wouldn't want that, either."
"Talk to me about what?"
"You could certainly afford to be stronger..."
"It does seem a *bit* strange."
"Not really. Where do you think it could lead?"
"Go ahead and become a dragon disciple, if you can."
"I could really use a bard, actually."
"I can't tell you what to do, Deekin."
"What happened to you after we parted ways last time?"
"Why didn't you get very far?"
"You could have come looking for me, you know."
"I had a copy of your book, actually."
"How much coin are we talking about?"
"Some of that should have been mine."
"You should have demanded more."
"Hmph. If you weren't such an idiot, that wouldn't have happened."
"You let them walk all over you?"
"What were you expecting? You're a kobold."
"I don't know what to say. That's horrible."
"Alright, whatever. Let's just move on, shall we?"
"I have complete faith in you, Deekin."
"Well, good luck with that."
"I think you're charming enough, Deekin."
"So you're going to give up?"
"So why didn't you kick some butt? You're no weakling."
"Do *you* think you're weak?"
"'Little Deekin' fights by my side against powerful monsters."
"You're a powerful bard by any standard, Deekin."
"It sounds like you had a difficult time."
"That's it? I remember the book being quite successful."
"That's not so bad."
"Do you know anything about Halaster?"
"I'll ask you about it later, perhaps."
"Tell me what you know about him, then."
"Go on."
"What happened since then? Do you know?"
"How was Waterdeep able to grow over top of Undermountain?"
"So all these monsters were originally in Undermountain?"
"Undermountain doesn't look like a dwarven mine, though."
"What had happened to all the dwarves?"
"Why did he disappear into the mines?"
"Just how long ago was this, anyway?"
"There's a tower? Is it still in Waterdeep?"
"Are his apprentices still alive?"
"Well, I hope you learned a lesson."
"Good enough. You're forgiven... for now."
"Forget it! I'm through with you!"
"Not good enough!" <StartAction>[Reprimand him some more.]</Start>
"No, not yet. Stay here."
"Yes, come along."
"Not right now, Deekin."
"Yes, Deekin?"
"We're not friends, kobold. Keep it straight."
"Really? I think of you as more of a henchman."
"Awww... that's very sweet of you to say, Deekin."
"Great. Let's move on."
"You've earned your place beside me, Deekin."
"Who else is going to write my tale?"
"Of course. You've been very amusing."
"You do know how powerful you are now, right?"
"I think of you as a great friend, too."
"No, go ahead... what did you want to say?"
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> "It's okay, Deekin. You can tell me."
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> "Come on, Deekin. Talk to me."
"Oh. Errr... sure, go ahead..."
"Alright then."
"You must have some ideas of your own."
"Why are you asking me?"
"No, I really don't care."
"Won't your publisher just change the name on you again?"
"How about 'the Adventures of <FullName>'?"
"Call it anything but 'Hordes of the Underdark'."
"Call it 'Hordes of the Underdark', then."
"Finished."
"Yes?"
"I really don't care about that."
"You can't describe me yourself?"
"You think I'm vain?"
"You think I'm sensitive?"
"I really wish you wouldn't put me in your book."
"Write what you want, and leave me be."
"How are you describing me now?"
"Describe me however you think best, Deekin."
"More along that vein would work, I think."
"You don't need to compliment me. Just tell the truth."
"That sounds fine to me."
"Of course I remember Tymofarrar. Last I heard he was still as blase as ever."
"Not that I recall."
"He talked about you with affection... sort of..."
"Why do you want to know?"
"No, but it would be nice if you did."
"He said you have dragon blood? Was he joking?"
"Maybe the potential is there. You never know."
"Yes, I've noticed."
"I really don't remember."
"I'm sorry Deekin. He never did."
"No, he didn't, so get over it already."
"That was a long time ago, Deekin."
"Are you wondering about something specific?"
"Tymofarrar? Of course. I remember killing him, too."
"Err... the white dragon? Not really... it's been a long time."
"You don't like Waterdeep?"
"And?"
"Big deal. Keep the sob story to yourself."
"You're complaining because they were rude?"
"Life isn't like that, little fella."
"I'm sorry things didn't work out, Deekin."
"I don't treat you nice."
"And that's the saddest thing I've heard all day."
"You blackmailed me, you little creep."
"I suppose I did."
"Good idea."
"I think that probably would have happened anywhere."
"What were you expecting, Deekin? You're a kobold."
"No, not that much."
"A fair amount, yes."
"Not now, Deekin."
"Ask away."
"I don't really know."
"If they were surface creatures once, Deekin, they aren't anymore."
"Maybe because they're a lot like the shadows they live in."
"Because they're evil. All black things are evil."
"The evil <race> folk have to wear black. Black hat or robe, preferably."
"You lived in caves and you never saw a drow?"
"Extra tasty? Really?"
"Ugh... I didn't need to know that..."
"Quite a bit. I am an elf, after all."
"You do know that a drow is a type of elf, right?"
"I really don't care."
"Enough. This is a dumb topic."
"Not on your life."
"Yes. Change it to Deekin Diesalot."
"You want to change your name?"
"That's the dumbest idea I've ever heard."
"That's a good idea. Change your name."
"Think about it. I'm sure you'll come up with something."
"Err... <FirstName> the kobold?"
"Donald? Sounds great."
"No. Don't do that, Deekin. Please."
"What kind of name is that?"
"Don't you have any favorite names, Deekin?"
"Maybe something a little less cute?"
"Yes, macho. Like 'the Deekinator'."
"I think Deekin is a fine name."
"What's wrong with your current name?"
"A chicken did write the book."
"Who? Oh... my mentor. No, not at all."
"Are you joking? He was an old fool, no more."
"Drogan sacrificed himself nobly. I will always cherish his memory."
"My old mentor? Perhaps a little, sometimes."
"That's nice. Let's move on."
"But you have a whole life of adventure now. Isn't that what you wanted?"
"But Tymofarrar treated you terribly."
"Have you never been back?"
"That's a stupid question."
"Undoubtedly not."
"I hope so."
"I couldn't care less."
"You want treasure, do you?"
"If you want something we find, let me know."
"You'll get what I give you, no more."
"What? You don't trust me to give you a fair share?"
"Fine, fine. Call dibs."
"Dibs? No I don't think that would work."
"You're my scribe and sometimes you're handy... at best."
"You already are an adventurer, Deekin."
"We are friends, Deekin. That's better than being an adventurer."
"You are a *kobold*, Deekin."
"Looks that way, yes."
"I guess there's no escaping that."
"Right. Just remember to write it all down."
"We're a team, Deekin, remember?"
"Thanks, Deekin."
"The Reaper has always referred to it as his realm, nothing else."
"Keep your questions to yourself, kobold."
"Why are you so interested?"
"I don't know what the Reaper is, Deekin. A demon, perhaps? He just is."
"That's right."
"Enough questions, Deekin."
"I have to pay his price, first, but basically yes."
"Er... usually. There's some explanation to how this works, but I don't know much about it."
"This place is a nexus, or so the Reaper says. I'm not sure I understand it all."
"The Reaper says his realm is a nexus. It connects to many places, but not all."
"Why don't you ask him yourself?"
"Silence, kobold. I'm not in the mood."
"Unless you can think of some way out of here, shut it."
"Is there anything about this place you can tell me?"
"Seems a bit... cold to be one of the Hells, doesn't it?"
"What was your first clue?"
"I know all I need to."
"Tell me what you know, then."
"Alright, enough chatter about legends."
"Well, let's keep going and see for ourselves, shall we?"
"There's no way to know this is the place you're talking about, Deekin."
"Anything else interesting about the tale you recall?"
"Do you know why the city vanished?"
"Why send the city here?"
"Worried they'll steal your book, eh?"
"Don't worry. I'm sure there's nothing in there for them to get excited about."
"I think your thoughts may be a bit beyond their comprehension, Deekin."
"Not if they're lucky."
"Silence, kobold!"
"Don't worry, Deekin. I'll protect you."
"Why? What's wrong?"
"You always say that, Deekin."
"How should I know?"
"Why don't we ask them?"
"Or they're slaves of some kind."
"They are probably slaves or servants, Deekin."
"Let's find out."
"Enough with all these questions! It's time to act."
"Something we haven't seen yet, perhaps."
"That's a stupid question."
"They might keep slaves to work on it, too."
"They could always have one more if you keep blathering."
"No, I'm sure they just eat the kobolds."
"Why not? We've seen plenty of surface races down here."
"Sounds like a reasonable idea."
"Keep up that silliness and *you'll* disappear."
"Don't care for your publisher, I see?"
"I guess we can all be glad you don't actually have one, then."
"Can you tell anything about them?"
"We may find evidence of them if we look around."
"Just pull yourself together."
"How would a dead magic zone come to be, you think?"
"It shouldn't be that much of a problem. We'll be fine."
"That may very well be."
"So I hear."
"What makes you ask that?"
"Why not? Anything is possible."
"I truly doubt it."
"I don't know. Perhaps."
"I agree. That would be a terrible existence."
"I really doubt that's how it is."
"You were stone, yourself. You tell me."
"I don't want to talk about that."
"I didn't feel anything when I was stone."
"Don't be so stupid."
"I truly doubt it, Deekin."
"Maybe. If we meet one, maybe we can ask it."
"If a golem thinks as much as you, we should be very frightened."
"It's a good thing you're not a golem, then."
"We don't know for sure, Deekin. They might be happy, too."
"I really don't want to hear about it, Deekin."
"You're not afraid of water, are you?"
"I suppose you're right. I hadn't thought of it like that."
"And so? What's wrong with that?"
"Enough, Deekin. I don't need to hear more of this prattle."
"There's just as much water below the ground as above it, Deekin."
"I know lots of things, Deekin. I'm smart."
"I, uh, don't think it works quite like that..."
"I've never been on a ship, either."
"Since when is an adventure supposed to be safe?"
"Don't be such a coward. It's perfectly safe."
"Well, it's not safe, really."
"You got me. I haven't a clue."
"You're not going to get all scared now, are you?"
"So we are. Do you know a way out of here that they didn't mention?"
"I know. I'm not very happy about that, either."
"Just figured that out, did you?"
"Great. Wonderful. Let's move on, shall we?"
"Well, I'm glad to know someone's keeping things in perspective."
"Is that all you're concerned about? Your book?"
"And maybe I'll see some actual coin from *this* book...?"
"You mean you're not scared to be in the Underdark at all?"
"I should kill you now, rodent."
"I suppose you're right."
"Cool? We're going to be in constant danger?"
"Sometimes I just don't understand you at all, Deekin."
"And where does that doorway go? Do you know?"
"That seems rather obvious, don't you think?"
"And what makes you say that?"
"Alright, let's get moving."
"Typical. More puzzle-work."
"How much deeper does this dungeon go, anyway?"
"And where are these chains held?"
"Quiet, Deekin. Stay on watch."
"Thanks for the travelogue. Let's continue."
"Is it very dangerous?"
"Sleeping Kings?"
"Let's move on, then."
"Alright, Deekin, thanks for the tip."
"They sleep? Or they're dead?"
"They could have great treasure, then, is what you're saying."
"Be silent. I've no need of your anecdotes."
"Yes, well, I'm sure we'll find out more soon enough."
"What do you know about it?"
"Thanks for the help, Deekin."
"Alright. Let's move on."
"What if I don't look in the mirrors?"
"Can the mirrors be broken?"
"Copies you?"
"Pulls you in?"
"Yes, of course. And?"
<StartAction>[Glare at him.]</Start>
"So I've heard, Deekin."
"I can still get back up to the inn, can't I?"
"Then that's all I need to know."
"Do you know a lot about Undermountain, Deekin?"
"You're saying the Relic of the Reaper won't work?"
"Why do you say that?"
"Thanks for the tip."
"Whatever."
"Just make sure you tell me if you see anything else you recognize."
"Yes, back to the adventure."
"Well, I'll be careful."
"You know a lot about Undermountain, do you?"
"Be watchful, then, and stay on guard."
"We'll be careful, Deekin, don't worry."
"You've nothing to fear while you're with me."
"Things have obviously changed in Undermountain since those books were written, Deekin."
"Maybe this Halaster isn't here anymore."
"It means my patience with you is less than it normally is, kobold."
"It means we're in a very dangerous place."
"No, what does that mean?"
"Of course I knew that, you stupid kobold!"
"You're kidding. I had no idea."
<StartAction>[Glare at him.]</Start>
<StartAction>[Sigh.]</Start> "Yes, of course I knew where we were going, Deekin."
"None whatsoever. I thought we were going to Rashaman to run naked in the fields."
"That and eat kobold stew as a delicacy."
"Never mind. I don't want to discuss it."
"You came with me. Expect to die."
"Right. Let's go."
"No. Just stay here, for now."
"Maybe you shouldn't go running off all the time."
"You're a tiny kobold and a bard. What were you expecting?"
"You keep dying. That's the real problem."
"Don't worry about it, Deekin. You're doing fine."
"He did ask a question, Linu."
"Don't be so hard on her, Deekin. She does her best."
"That hurt like hell, you know. Vicious assault with a frying pan."
"It is wonderful to see you again, dear. Have you a need of me?"
---------- Random Pop-Ups Start Here ------------
"Oh, my friend, is this true? Are you you sure this is what you want?"
"Very well. Just do not abandon me here, dear. I couldn't bear the thought of waiting here alone!"
"Ah, well. I'm sure I can find my own way back. Do not worry about me."
"What would you have me do, dear?"
"I rarely see them, but very well."
"If I can, certainly."
"Then I shall speed up for you, dear."
"Stealth is not my forte, but I will do my best."
"Just leave it alone? As you wish."
"I will do what I can to assist."
"Where should I be, then?"
"As you wish."
"I am no warrior, but I will do what I must."
"I'll try."
"Oh, good. Let me put my things down for a moment."
"I am no specialist in item lore, but I am not without some knowledge. I shall look through your pack and tell you what I can."
"And what sort of spells do you need me to use, dear?"
"What would you like me to cast, dear?"
"If you are certain..."
"And what is my target?"
"Talk? What about?"
"Fair enough, though I am a bit tired of traveling... not to complain, however."
"Shall we talk about something else?"
"I am fine, dear. Don't worry about me."
"As good as can be expected. I am up for the challenge, however."
"Oh, I'm quite fine, dear. Thank you for asking."
"I normally wouldn't complain... but this blindness effect I am under is quite disconcerting."
"My wounds are light, for the moment. Nothing a simple spell or two wouldn't cure."
"I am wounded quite badly, but I can still move onwards."
"Not well." She winces. "These wounds of mine are... considerable. But I'm not dead yet, naturally."
"I am poisoned. I hope I have a spell to deal with this promptly."
"I... do not feel well. I believe I might very well have been afflicted with some form of disease."
She ponders the question for a long moment. "I am not sure. I have considered perhaps going to Evermeet, but part of me believes that is simply not my destiny."
"Perhaps I might return to Neverwinter. Or build a temple to Sehanine Moonbow somewhere in these northern wildlands. The reward that Waterdeep offers is substantial, after all."
"What about you, dear? Do you have any plans once this adventure is done?"
She smiles. "I'm sure that is true. I hope you include charity amongst the good uses you mention... there is gold enough in the reward to ease the life of many who suffer."
Linu ponders for a moment. "I think my time adventuring is done, after this. After waking up in that sarcophagus," she shudders," no... I don't want to go through that again."
"Perhaps Sehanine sent you to me before something worse could happen, to show me the path I must take. Regardless, I am thankful that you rescued me, <FirstName>."
She chuckles. "I'm sure you will be rewarded all you deserve, my friend, and more. But come... let us move on. Waterdeep remains in need of our aid."
She smiles softly. "Let us move on, then, friend. There is much to be done and Waterdeep remains in need of our aid."
"*I* think it was something. But let us move on... there is much to do and Waterdeep remains in need."
"Truly? I must admit, my thoughts were much along a similar vein."
She nods, smiling. "I'm sure that is the case. There is always another adventure on the horizon for those such as us, isn't there?"
She blushes, looking away and smiling bashfully. "I see. I... can't say I wouldn't mind getting to know you better, <FirstName>. You seem a fine man."
"I come from Evereska originally, dear, but I spent a great deal of time in Neverwinter after I helped fight the plague there. Lord Nasher was very generous."
"There was so much to rebuild, and the city needed its heroes... Lord Nasher was generous to those of us who stayed, yes. It felt good, for a time."
"I should have returned to Evereska, but I simply could not. And after a time, I felt the need to move on and seek adventure elsewhere... and many of the others felt the same."
"Only for a short time, though it was truly a privilege. Never have I ever seen someone grow in power so quickly."
She smiles broadly. "<He/She> may as well have, for all the credit we others get. I don't mind, however. The Hero of Neverwinter deserves all that praise and more."
"I understand Sharwyn wrote a book about the whole affair." She rolls her eyes, grinning. "Silly and romantic and completely blown out of proportion. But such are bard's tales, correct?"
"To tell the truth, I don't know. Once <he/she> had returned from slaying Morag, there was some disagreement with Lord Nasher that I was not privy to. <He/She> left the city."
"It was unworthy of Lord Nasher to treat the true hero of the day so poorly... but perhaps I should not judge, as I do not know what transpired between them. I assume that <he/she> adventures still."
"Not as you might think... I was not one of the clerics who tried to keep the people of the city healthy. I joined Lady Aribeth in hunting down those responsible for the plot."
"Fortunately we proved successful and the city was saved." Her eyes grow sad. "It did not come without cost, however. I still pray for the Lady Aribeth."
"Of course. Enough about me."
"She was a paladin of Tyr, you see... and she fell, giving in to anger and hate." Linu shrugs, then, wiping her eyes. "In the end she died, the poor dear."
"Be careful when you say such a thing, my dear. All of us get what we deserve... in the end."
"It is. She was a good person, as was Fenthick." Anger clouds Linu's features for a moment. "I suppose some things are simply... difficult to forgive."
"If that is the way you feel, my dear, I'll not question you. I will pray to Sehanine to watch over you on your vital quest."
"Then I shall endeavor to keep you whole once again, my dear. Just try, occasionally, to keep out of harm's way. Sometimes I think you are as bad as I am for getting in trouble."
"I did not mean to trouble you. Another time, then."
She looks at you curiously for a long moment. "What do you know of the drow, <FirstName>?"
She nods. "Then I needn't prattle on about them. Let's continue on, shall we?"
Her face grows serious. "There was a time when the dark elves lived on the surface. Before the time of Man, however, they had already been driven underground."
"The Underdark is not their natural home. It is a place where they cheated, battled with and stole from the other races such as the dwarves to carve themselves an Empire."
"Their threat could be much more, but it is ever the destiny of the drow to war amongst themselves and keep themselves weak. Such is how Lolth, their goddess of spiders, prefers it."
"Let us move on, then. Speaking of the drow has made me... nervous."
"Yes, but to be frank this is no amazing feat. The evil races of the Underdark constantly war with one another, the drow are not special in this regard."

"I find it odd that they seem to be working together. The idea of the drow unifying is one thing, but the idea of drow working beside duergar and mind flayer and beholder... that is something else entirely."
"No, there is something going on within the Underdark that is entirely different from anything we've heard about before. Something very big."
"It doesn't seem likely. The drow are split into clans that are constantly at war in an effort to please Lolth, who wouldn't want them unified either. There is no incentive for them to unify."

"The only way I could see such a thing happening is if one drow clan was to perhaps grow strong enough to dominate the others through force. Such a thing seems unlikely so long as Lolth is their queen, however."

"She is one of a small drow pantheon, but by far she is the most powerful. Lolth is the queen of spiders and a being who believes only in suffering and pain and cruelty. She *is* the drow and they are her perfect children."

"She is no kinder to her own people, I understand. Those who displease her are either killed outright or turned into drider... half-spider abominations. Otherwise her altars run red with the blood of the sacrifices she demands."
"It keeps them strong... survival of the fittest, so to speak. Even as children the drow are," here her face twists into disgust, "encouraged to slay their siblings to prove they are the strongest."
"This means that most drow spend their entire lives trying to survive being killed and being forced to keep their wits sharp. This makes them formidable opponents and merciless killers."
"I am not certain that they even can return, for my understanding is that bright light causes them great pain now, but if they did want to return to the surface it would be as conquerors."
"The tales say that there are *some* drow who have returned to the surface to live in peace, however. These are followers of the goddess Eilistraee and outcasts from their own society."
"The hero Drizzt is not a follower of Eilistraee, I believe, but an individual drow exile who lives upon the surface." She shrugs. "There are exceptions to every race in Faerun, even the drow."
"True, but not all who are born elven know very much about their heritage. Would you like me to speak of them?"
"My people possess tales about Halaster Greycloak, the mage who constructed," she motions about her, "all of this."
Linu shrugs. "As you wish, dear. I was simply offering what I thought to be relevant."
"Well, you must remember the Yawning Portal Inn where we started. Back before Waterdeep had been established, Halaster's tower was built on that spot."
"He dug deeper and deeper into the ground, expanding down rather than up, until he broke into an ancient cavern that had belonged to the dwarven folk."
"According to our legends these dwarves had been murdered by the drow, who yet remained in the caverns. Halaster was quick to claim the area and either kill or enslave the drow."
"They were the original owners." She looks around. "Halaster has altered it to suit his purposes, and even expanded it further. Perhaps he went too far and broke into the Underdark?"
She nods in response. "You're quite welcome."
"He is an archmage with a long life of experience." She shrugs. "But he is also mad, so how does one judge true power in that respect? Certainly he can be defeated, as can anyone."

"The drow are powerful, possessing both mages and clerics who easily match the best of the other races. They are simply divided. If something were to unify them against Undermountain," her voice trails off, leaving the thought unfinished.
"I don't really know whether Undermountain extends into the Underdark itself. Some of the stories say yes, some say no... it seems obvious that some kind of conflict began here, no?"

"The tales say that Halaster was notoriously paranoid about losing his power. He created clones and traps and puzzles... all in an effort to keep his enemies away from his magic. His enemies being everyone, of course."
Linu giggles. "A fair bit older than most mages but maybe not so old as the great Elminster the Sage. Certainly old enough to impress an elf... he predates the city of Waterdeep, after all."
--------- Random Conversations begin here ----------
"I do not like the transition, and would wish it on no-one else. Especially you, my dear. I shall have to struggle even harder to keep you from such a fate. Shall I join you again?"
She nods. "I shall try to breathe life back into you and your quest."
She nods, rubbing her arms again. "As you wish, dear. Just... do not leave me here too long. I do not want to be alone."
------- This line must be placed at the end of inter-party banter ---------
"What is it, Tomi? You've been staring at me for quite some time, now, you may as well speak."
"All right, then. I just got t' wonderin'... what does you gots against us rogue types?"
"You mean besides the fact that you're all a bunch of thieves and scoundrels without the slightest regard for morals or the well-being of your fellow man?"
"Aye, besides all o' that rot. You gots something personal against us, the way ya goes on about it."

She turns away from him, lifting her chin up. "And why shouldn't it be personal? You add nothing to the community. On the contrary, you take and take and take from it until they CAN'T STAND YOU BASTARDS ANY LONGER!"
"Mmmm... sounds like ye're referrin' ta something specific."
"I am not! Just because my father was a rotten thief like yourself has *nothing* to do with --"
"Yer daddy, eh? Aye, that explains it. All ye lasses are so bloody wrapped up in what yer daddies did or didn't do... it's bloody pathetic."

"Just you wait, you rotten little guttersnipe. Sehanine will one day let me place such a curse on you that it will leave you naked and yowling in the streets and praying to all the gods for mercy that will never come!"
"Aye? Sounds like me last night on th' town, that does."
"Ahhhhrrrggh!" Linu screams in frustration and stalks off.
"Will you get away from me, you miserable little thief! I will not have you picking my pocket!"
"Oy! That's not nice of ya at all, saying such things to poor Tomi. An' besides, I was just thinkin' about something I heard about ya."
"*You* heard something about *me*? I can't imagine what that might be."
"Somethin' about you startin' a riot in the Bridge district back in Neverwinter. Was that you or not?"
Linu steps back, looking abashed. "Oh. Well... yes that was me, if it's the riot I'm thinking about. How did you know I started that?"
"So ye *did* start it?" He laughs heartily, slapping his knees. "I can't bloody well believe it! Miss Dainty Knees started a riot, she did!"
"There's no need to get all excited about it. It was an accident. Really I was only in the Bridge district at all to buy a chicken for some soup I was making Lord Nasher."
"Then the chicken got away from me and I had to chase it, and it ran in front of some horses that belonged to the guard... and they, ah, spooked."
"The chicken spooked the horses?"
"Well, not quite. I dove for the chicken and got it, but knocked over a cart... that, ah, had held a sleeping cat. Which became quite agitated as it was dumped into the nearby fountain."
"And *it* spooked the horses?"
"The dogs that ended up chasing the wet cat underneath the horses did the trick, yes."
"So them bloody horses ran amok and caused a bunch o' damage... an' that caused the riot?"
"Not... right away. I chased after the horses to get them back, and I caused some... damage... along the way..."
Tomi holds up his hands. "Aye, say no more. I think I see it now. Bloody hell! Yer a nightmare, ain't ya?!"
"I notice that you have been watching me for some time now, Daelan. Have you something to say to me?"
He nods, looking abashed. "I do, good elf. If I might be so bold, could you tell me why you walk as you do?"
Linu blushes. "How... how do I walk, exactly?"
"The elven folk are renowned even amongst my own people for their grace and beauty. You have all of their beauty, good elf... but why do you not possess their grace?"
She looks away from Daelan, her blush increasing. "I... have never had the grace you speak of, dear. It made me a target of mockery amongst my kind."
He nods sagely. "And so I have stumbled upon an unhappy topic. Please forgive me. I merely meant to observe that you have considerable grace in those moments you are not thinking about it."
Linu seems genuinely surprised. "Whatever do you mean? That's not true, is it?"
"I believe it is. When you are lost in reverie or when you pray to your goddess... in those moments you have all the grace of your kin. Could it be your awkwardness is not physical in its origin?"
Her voice is quiet. "I had not thought about it quite like that."
"We all believe ourselves inadequate in many ways, for our own reasons. Your fears and sadnesses I would not dream of betraying... if you wished to discuss them with a simple man such as me."
"Th-thank you for the offer, dear. I just might do that... sometime."
"Daelan... if I might ask, what exactly do the Uthgardt tribes believe in?"
"Do you ask about the beliefs of my people, Linu, or my own beliefs? If you wish to know what I believe in, you need only ask."
"I... would never want to offend you, Daelan. I am only curious."
"I would happily satisfy your curiosity, good elf. Your kindness is without equal... never would I believe that any question that came from you had its origin in malice."
"That's... very kind of you, Daelan. As a matter of fact, I am a bit curious. You've never mentioned any god that I can remember."
He smiles gently, looking down at her. "And perhaps that is because I believe in none. The Uthgardt have a pantheon of ancient gods, but I stopped believing in them long ago."
"May I ask why?"
Daelan does not respond for a long moment, his brow troubled. "Sometimes, in the darkest hours of a man's life, his faith can be broken. Faith is one of those things not easily repaired."
Linu lays a hand on his forearm. "But it is not impossible, Daelan. There are things to believe in in this world... good things, worthy things."
Daelan pats her hand, his eyes sad. "I believe in many things, good elf. I believe in compassion and honor and nobility. I do not believe in gods."
"Some gods are worth believing in, Daelan."
"From you I could believe that, good elf." He nods at her, smiling, gently removing her hand from his arm. "Someday."
"Is there something you wish to ask me, Sharwyn dear? You keep looking my way..."
"I do, but... I don't know, you might be embarrassed..."
"Go ahead and ask. By all means."
"Well... I remember hearing that there was some incident involving you and Lord Nasher, that he was angry with you over something involving Sembia?"
Linu suddenly blushes. "Oh. That. Yes, well... it was my fault that the Sembian ambassador returned home. It was a complete accident, however!"
Sharwyn grins. "What happened?"
Linu shrugs helplessly. "The ambassador and I were dancing at a court function. I tripped and fell into a waiter, who spilled soup all over the ambassador."
"That doesn't sound so bad."
"Except that the soup was boiling hot. The poor man flailed about in pain and caught on fire when he stumbled into one of the braziers."
"I tried to put him out... or I thought I was... by pouring a nearby bucket of water on him. I had no idea the bucket was full of oil for the brazier..."
Sharwyn holds up her hands. "Say no more. I get the picture. You poor girl."
"A question, Sharwyn. Do you... your mother is a seamstress in Neverwinter, correct? A proud woman named Delilah?"
Obviously Sharwyn was not expecting such a question. She stiffens and regards Linu suspiciously. "Yes. How could you know such a thing?"
Linu gestures helplessly. "I... met your mother. She had a sickness during the time of the plague, correct?"
"She didn't have the plague, itself. She had bonerot... and I was able to procure a potion for her that healed it. At great difficulty, I might add."
Linu nods, her expression unreadable. "So she said. Do you and she... speak much?"
"No." Sharwyn's expression is harsh and she turns away from Linu for a moment. "Not that it's any of your business, but no... we don't. I haven't seen her since I gave her the potion."

For a long moment Linu says nothing. Then, with a tone of dread, she finally speaks. "There were... complications from that sickness. Your mother died, Sharwyn. I did what I could, but I... couldn't do much."
Sharwyn's voice is quiet. "I see."
"I didn't think you had been told. You'd left Neverwinter, after all." Linu is obviously anguished. "I thought you... would want to know."
Sharwyn nods slowly. "Thank you, Linu." She thinks for a moment and then asks, "Did she...?"
"There was little pain in the end. She died peacefully."
Sharwyn is silent and wipes suddenly moist eyes. "That's good." She says nothing further.
"Deekin... you mentioned before that you've become, what was it? Some kind of disciple?"
"Deekin be a dragon disciple," he states proudly. "He gots heart of dragon, just like Old Boss says he gots."
"That's wonderful, dear. I certainly hope that doesn't make you become evil like most dragons are."
"Evil? Old Boss not be evil. Old Boss just be in bad mood lots."
"Mmmm... not according to what I've heard. We are speaking of the white Tymofarrar, yes? Were you not... aware of the extent of your patron's schemes, Deekin?"
He thinks about it for a moment, shuffling from foot to foot. "Maybe Deekin knows a little. Maybe that be part of reason why Deekin wants to leave."
Linu smiles gently at him and pats his head. "Just because our heroes sometimes disappoint us doesn't mean they didn't have good qualities, too. I'm sure your old master wasn't *all* bad."
"He treats Deekin nice sometimes. Deekin not... feels like kobold when Old Master teaches him. Deekin feels like dragon."
"A good dragon, I'm sure." She beams a brilliant smile at Deekin, and he chuckles and smiles back in response.
"Deekin, you don't look very well. Your scales are so gray! Whatever is wrong, dear?"
"Ummm... Deekin just be nervous. Deekin always be nervous when we walks around in dungeon. Deekin not be very courageous."
She smiles gently. "That's not so unusual, dear. We all feel that way."
Deekin looks up at her with bright, wide eyes. "Really?"
"Of course! I remember back when I left Evereska for the first time. I was supposed to search for Sehanine's holy chalice, but I had no idea where to start. I was so frightened!"
"I'd never been away from home before. I didn't know the customs of humans and I was so shy they took advantage of me terribly."
"Deekin knows what that be like."
"But you get better at it, dear. Everything in life requires courage, even when you're not adventuring. The fact that you're here says a lot about you."
"What does it say?"
"It means that you're far braver than all those people who need you to save their lives. It means that even if you fail, you're still a hero because you were willing to try."
He looks up at Linu and grins. "Deekin likes how you says things, pretty elven lady. You is really nice, just like the boss."
"Never mind."
"I think we need to part ways."
"No, never mind."
"Wait here until I return."
"I need to go."
"I want to change your tactics."
"I don't want to change anything else right now."
"I want you to leave any traps that you see alone."
"I want you to disarm any traps that you see."
"I want to move faster and not bother with searching or stealth."
"I need you to be stealthy right now."
"Don't help me if I fail to open a locked door or chest."
"Help me if I fail to open a locked door or chest."
"I want to change the distance you stay away from me."
"Stay a long distance away."
"Keep a medium distance."
"Stay close."
"Go ahead and attack as soon as you see enemies."
"Defend me and don't attack until I do."
"I want to adjust your equipment."
"Can you identify my equipment?"
"I need you to cast a group of buffing spells."
"Never mind."
"Cast all the buffing spells you have."
"Cast all the buffing spells that last a long time."
"Cast all the short duration buffing spells."
"I need you to cast a spell."
"Never mind."

"What would you like, Linu?"
"I know everything I need to know about them."
"I know they are evil and dark-skinned elves, but that's it."
"That's all I wanted to know."
"So the other races of the Underdark hate the drow?"
"Could the drow have unified somehow?"
"Tell me about this goddess, Lolth."
"Why would their goddess want them to war with each other?"
"Do the drow wish to return to the surface?"
"Isn't there another famous drow outcast named Drizzt?"
"A fair amount. I am an elf, after all."
"Yes, please. My knowledge is limited."
"No, I know plenty about them."
"I don't need to hear about him."
"Tell me what you know about him."
"So Undermountain once belonged to the dwarves?"
"I've heard enough, thanks."
"So how powerful is Halaster?"
"How could the drow have taken over?"
"Broke into the Underdark? What do you mean?"
"Why put all the puzzles and monsters in here?"
"The elves have tales about him? How old is he?"
"Yes, let's go."
"No, just stay here for now."
"It is good to see you once more. Do you have need of me?"
---------- Random Pop-Ups Start Here ------------
"Is that so? Well, I'll not stay where I'm not wanted. If you're sure...?"
"Well, off you go then. Just remember to come back for me before I die of old age."
"Fair enough. I'll find my own way back."
"There's something you'd like me to do differently?"
"That'd be my first instinct, yes. Ha ha!"
"If I can, certainly."
"Very well. I shall try to keep up with you."
"Let the shadows conceal me, then."
"I doubt there's much I could do to help with that, anyway."
"I'm no rogue, but I'll certainly try."
"Where do you want me, then?"
"Will do."
"Truly? Fair enough."
"I'll try."
"Adjust away. Just mind the delicates."
"I can certainly try. I'll look through what you have and let you know if there's anything I recognize."
"As you wish. Let my music inspire you."
"I see. What manner of buffing spells would you have me use?"
"What shall I cast, then?"
"I can do that. Are you certain?"
"And what is my target?"
"Talk? What about?"
"Couldn't be better. But I always feel good when something epic is underway!"
"Shall we talk about something else?"
"My feet ache and I could use a good bath. But, then, so could you."
"I wouldn't mind stopping to rest soon, but I can wait."
"Oh, well enough, I suppose."
"Not too bad. Do you think we will get to the Underdark soon? I've never seen it."
"It's fine. Personally, I'm waiting for something spectacular to happen."
"Everything is as well as one would expect. Why? What are you planning?"
"I'd feel better if I could actually see. Wait... where are you?"
"I am lightly wounded, nothing life-threatening."
"I have several wounds, but it is nothing critical just yet."
"I... am not that well." She winces in pain. "I need healing, if it is possible."
"I'm poisoned. This is not good."
"I would be far better were I not so ill, naturally. Is there not something we can do about this?"
"I am focusing on my fighting skills at the moment, as per your request. Should I do something differently?"
"I am focusing on my bardic skills at the moment, as per your request. Should I do something differently?"
"As you wish. I find that a more versatile arrangement, personally."
"My training? Well... I currently split my time between training to fight and my bardic skills. If you prefer, I could focus on doing one or the other."
She grins. "Easy enough to accomplish."
She nods affirmatively. "Fighter it is."
She nods affirmatively. "Bard it is."
"That depends, really, on whether or not I feel as if I'm done adventuring."
She ponders for a moment. "There are many places in Faerun where adventure can be had. I was pondering the possibility of journeying to Calimshan, perhaps... or even Rashaman in the east."
"I've never been to a desert, either. Perhaps the Anauroch Desert would be agreeable? You've been there, <FirstName>... what did you think of it?"
"You mean the Bedine? Yes, I would like to see more about them. And perhaps I could even search for ancient artifacts as you did?"
"Perhaps I could play as I traveled. I would play in front of the Witch-King of Vaasa, perhaps... or maybe even go to Shadowdale and track down Elminster, himself."
"What about you, <FirstName>? Are you through with adventures? Why not come with me?"
"You needn't put it so bluntly. I wish you well, anyway."
She laughs lightly. "I guess I understand. No hard feelings, anyway."
She grins. "Good! Then let's get on with finishing this one, yes?"
"Oh," she seems slightly disappointed. "From the book it sounded like your adventure was so much more interesting. I guess actually being there can seem much less exciting."

"Yes, I was originally born there, though I spent much of my career away. I only returned to help save the city from the plague, and afterwards I decided to stay." She frowns thoughtfully, obviously thinking back. "For a little while," she amends.
"True, I suppose. Let's move on, then, shall we?"
Sharwyn sighs heavily. "For a time I stayed, certainly. Lord Nasher was eager for all of us who had helped with the plague to stay and help rebuild the militia. We were heroes, and it felt good."
"I had always wanted to be famous, so I was in my glory at the time. It just... didn't last very long."
"A... man I fell in love with left the city. He did not come back. I know it does not sound very strong of me, but... Neverwinter just seemed so lonely after that. I wanted adventure again."
"That's why I came to Waterdeep when I heard the call. And met you, of course."
"I did. The revisionists like to play down <his/her> role in saving Neverwinter, but I was there... if it weren't for the Hero of Neverwinter, we would never have won the day."
Sharwyn shrugs, frowning as if this is an unpleasant topic. "<He/She> left not long after the plague ended and Aribeth died. There were... differences with Lord Nasher, as I recall."
"Same way I'm helping you now, I suppose. Fighting and casting spells when I'm not singing. I worked with Aribeth de Tylmarande, in fact." Her face grows somber. "Have you ever heard of her?"
"I know why you call her that, but there was more to her story than what you've heard. I think it was sad... especially what happened in the end."
"She died," Sharwyn says simply. "Isn't that how all these stories end?"
She nods, sighing. "I don't blame her for what she did. Not all of it. It's a sad tale, really... especially how it all ended."
"Truly? I thought her story would be everywhere by now. Let's just say she was once a paladin pushed to betray her people. A sad story... especially how it ended."
"As you wish, though I'll not stand about indefinitely."
"Excellent. I look forward to the adventure!"
"I see. Perhaps later, then."
"I have something of a... a confession to make."
She looks away for a moment, blushing. "Well, let me make it more of a question. Could you... could you ever see anything between us?"
Hurt to the quick, Sharwyn smiles wanly in an attempt to hide it. "I see. Well... that's good to know. Thank you."
She laughs and then wags a finger at you. "Now don't get all eager on me, it was just a simple question. We haven't known each other for very long, after all."
"At first I just thought of you as <FirstName> of Undrentide fame. Then, after you saved my life, I realized there was a reason you're considered such a hero."
"At any rate, we've a job to do, right? This is a discussion for later." She pauses for a moment and then, grinning, gives you a quick kiss before turning to continue.
She nods slowly, smiling. "I suppose that's a fair answer. We haven't known each other for very long, after all."
Sharwyn blushes more profusely, if that's possible. "No, I'm not joking."
She smiles a bit bashfully. "A bit of hero worship, actually. I don't know if I've ever told you how glad I am to be adventuring with you."
"I mean, at first I was excited because you were <FirstName> of Undrentide fame... but later, since you've saved my life, I know why you're regarded as such a heroine. I'm just... glad to be here."
Sharwyn nods. "Of course."
She nods. "I... just wanted you to know. That's all."
"Have you ever been to the Underdark?"
"Hmph. That's quite rude. Maybe you should just keep yourself company in the future, then."
"Well, the first thing you need to know is that it's likely the most dangerous place on Faerun... or in Faerun, if you prefer."
"We won't be able to rest anywhere safely. The drow will especially be on patrol. And while you might resist a beholder's eye rays, I can't say the same for an illithid's psionic attacks."
She shrugs. "At any rate, I just thought you might want a heads-up. I'm sure you've heard plenty about the Underdark as it is."
"It just seems that we're heading in that direction. With drow and illithids and beholders involved, I really can't see any other option."
"I'm curious... what are you going to do with all that reward money?"
"Fine. I was just asking."
"No? Well, I know what I would do with that kind of coin." Her eyes take on a far-away look.
"Oh come now, no need to play coy. Surely there must be *something* you'd like that costs a lot of money."
"Oh I know *that*. It's a lot of coin, however. Surely you must have given it some thought."
"Aha! I knew it! What's the first thing you would buy?"
Her eyes go wide as she grins. "Now *that's* more like it!" She ponders for a moment. "Can I think of something better? I'm not sure... hmmm..."
"I'd buy the grandest instrument that coin could buy, built by the finest craftsman in Faerun! And then I would travel the land, playing only in the most quality houses!" She laughs heartily.
"But I suppose we'd have to survive the current adventure first, right? Maybe let's do that."

She stares at you a moment longer to see if you're serious. "Oh. Well, I... I suppose that's a worthy cause." She shrugs. "Maybe it wouldn't be as benevolent of me, but I know exactly what I would do."

She whistles in appreciation. "Now that would be quite something to see. You sure a hundred thousand gold is enough for you?" She chuckles. "I, for one, know exactly what I would do with that kind of coin."
She rolls her eyes and smirks. "Now you're just playing with me. I, for one, know exactly what I would do with that kind of coin."
"Tell me something... you were the pupil of a dwarf by the name of Drogan, is that right? A dwarf wizard?"
She regards you archly. "A bit testy, are we? It's a simple question."
She nods sadly. "Yes, I know. I hadn't heard until I read it in the book, which came as something of a shock. He was a sweet dwarf. I'm glad he got to run his school after all."
"Very well. I apologize for asking, then."
"Oh?" She chuckles lightly. "You're not <FullName>, hero of the 'Shadows of Undrentide'? You're somebody else, I suppose?"
"So he did finally establish a school. That's good to know, as it was something he said he'd always planned to do someday."
"I did, though not for long. He tried to recruit me into the Harpers when I was younger. I always wondered what happened to him."
"Yes, only for a short while. Drogan was pretty insistent on trying to get me to join, but once I gave him my final answer, he gave me my space. And then I never saw him again."
"Sometimes I regret not joining the Harpers, however." She regards you with an arched brow. "What about you? Would you ever consider joining the Harpers?"
She nods. "That's what I would have expected."
She stares at you with renewed wonder, grinning. "I should have suspected as much, really."
"Well, we'd best be off. Talking about old friends always makes me sad. Let's do something exciting, shall we?"
"I'm surprised the subject didn't come up. Drogan was part of a group that dedicates itself to fighting evil throughout the lands." She shrugs. "Maybe by the time he met you he no longer took part."
"Yes, Drogan is the one who invited me." She sighs sadly. "In the end, I decided all that wandering and spying wasn't really for me. I'd rather have my own adventures."
--------- Random Conversations begin here ----------
"I can't believe we're still running around down here. That... that relic you carry... can't it teleport you past all these obstacles?"
"I'm just feeling a little on edge." She glances away, looking embarrassed. "I guess we've just been down here for quite a while, without really getting anywhere. Or that's how it feels."
She nods slowly. "Fine. I don't really want to talk about it anymore, anyway. Let's move on."
She stares at you for a long moment before continuing. "You say that, but how can you guarantee anything? It's not as if you and I have known each other for very long."
"Not scared, no." She looks at you with very serious eyes. "I haven't been scared of any adventure for a very long time now. I know the risks."
"No, I don't want to go back to the inn. I don't want to stop, don't take it like that."
"I just keep thinking of when you found me down here." Her expression becomes pensive. "I was killed so quickly... and if you hadn't found me..."

Sharwyn sighs heavily and then puts on a half-hearted smile. "I guess what I'm afraid of is a bad ending. To end so cheaply, to not even see the big climax... do you understand what I'm taking about?"

She looks at you with a sudden smile. "So you do understand. Thank you, I appreciate that. But... now's not really the time. I shouldn't whine like this... my story's not what's important here. Let's move on."
"I shouldn't talk like this. We've still plenty of work to be done before this is over? My story can wait."
"Well that's sort of useless."
She frowns thoughtfully. "I suppose you're right. I really should be surprised that teleportation works at all in here. It's not supposed to."
"I've heard about it. You're somewhat famous, remember?"
"Well we could certainly use *something* because all we seem to be doing is getting deeper and deeper into Undermountain."
"I... you're right, you're right. Please forgive me."
"Mind my own business?" She glares at you. "As if my own survival isn't my business? All we seem to be doing is getting deeper and deeper into Undermountain."
"Unless I'm mistaken, this is the Hall of the Sleeping Kings!" She looks around with awe. "I... I didn't expect it to be so large."
She nods. "All right. Just... just be careful not to touch anything."
She glances at you with a slight grin. "You should know better than that. You don't prop up fully dead folk in a throne and put them on display. *Mostly* dead folk you do."

She takes a deep breath, staring for a long moment at one of the skeletal bodies before continuing. "Mankind is an old race, older than we think even. Records of our true history have probably been lost in more ancient wars than we can count."
"There were nations here in the north of Faerun whose names aren't even known anymore, ruled by Wizard-Kings and valiant Lords and Ladies whose deeds are long forgotten."
She gestures to the bodies in the room. "The tales say that Halaster has collected the greatest of these ancient Kings and given them righteous burial. Here they sleep, in a place of honor."
"I wouldn't touch them. Really, I wouldn't." She nods to the other side of the room. "Let's just move on, okay?"
"Probably. This is Undermountain, after all. I... I would think these skeletons wouldn't bother you if you didn't bother them, but I've no way of knowing that for sure."
She shrugs. "I guess that depends on your point of view. They could be buried in some forgotten grave that someone built a whorehouse over. Me, I'd pick here."
"I think we may have stumbled onto the Hall of Mirrors. This is one of the few famous locales inside Undermountain."
"If you say so. It's not often that you stumble into something like this, that's all."

"There are some folks who have entered Undermountain and not gotten very far in before they retreated back out... they're the only ones who have lived to tell their tale, and this room often gets mentioned."

"It's configuration gets changed sometimes, but generally its at least two long rows of mirrors. Some of them are magical, some of them are not, and supposedly the magical ones are quite different... but usually deadly."
"One mirror that often gets mentioned is referred to as the Mirror of Opposition. It creates a hostile copy of yourself that attacks you. Talk about your fair fight!"
"Personally I'd just like to know where Halaster gets all these things. Do you think he makes them himself? How could he?"
"Not really, other than the fact that we should probably just move on through. But you'll want to look, won't you? Of course you will."
"Possibly, to the right buyer. But look at these things. How are you going to cart it out of here? Not to mention that as soon as you approach it, it would perform its magic."
"I don't know. The stories seem to be correct, as all the mirrors are identical."
"Naturally. Undermountain is older than Waterdeep and has been visited by the most famous adventurers in the land throughout its existence. Word gets out."
"This room is one that is normally nearer the entrance, if I remember the lore correctly. Apparently Halaster likes to rearrange his little maze on a regular basis. How I'd love to meet that man!"

"Some. Really, there's not much to be known... he's a great archmage who went insane with paranoia a long time ago and so hid himself within a dungeon of his creation. He's not exactly known for his sociability."
She looks at your with incredulity. "Wouldn't you? We're talking about one of Faerun's great archmages, here. I'd love to talk to him, find out what made him mad, I don't know."
"Yes, I suppose he does have lots of magic. People wanting to take it from him is likely what made him paranoid to begin with, wouldn't you say?"
"The good news, I guess, is that I just might get to meet him if I stick around with you. If something big is happening in Undermountain, Halaster has to be involved somehow."
"Well, naturally he'd never tell me such things, but we're talking hypothetical situations here anyway. Halaster doesn't meet anyone."
"Count on it. Halaster Blackcloak is deranged and paranoid. No doubt he just doesn't want maps to mean anything."
She grins ruefully. "But I'm sure you're not interested in my musings. We've more important things to do, right? Shall I join up with you again?"
She nods, pleased. "Excellent. A grand adventure awaits."
Her brow furrows in confusion. "You raised me back to life, but not to help you further? Well, then, you have my thanks still... should you need my help, I'll be right here."
------- This line must be placed at the end of inter-party banter ---------
"You know, I seem to recall a certain tale in which you were mentioned, Tomi."
"Aye? That's a new one. Did I come off lookin' good in it?"
"Not really. But, then, when you know who I heard the tale from, maybe that won't be surprising."
"Hmmm? Well, don't keep me in bloody suspense."
"I believe you know him. An old cohort by the name of Sammy?"
Tomi's reaction is explosive. His eyes go wide and he very nearly chokes on something. "Sammy?! Ye've seen him? Where?!"
Sharwyn chuckles under her breath. "Oh, more to the point, I told him where to find *you*."
"Now why would you bloody well do that?!"
"I've always been a bit of a believer in justice, my little friend." With that, Sharwyn merely smirks and continues on her way.
"You know, Tomi... have I ever told you about the golden ring I wear?"
"Naw. Why would I want to hear about that?"
"There's a tale about it that involves you, actually."
"Aye? Then gab yer story away. I always do like to hear about myself, heh."

"There was a man I loved with all my heart, you see. He wished to marry me, and I was willing... but he was poor and thought himself unworthy. He said he would find me a ring worthy of our love and sailed away one day."

"I never saw him for many months and sadly thought he had abandoned me. Much later, however, I received a small pouch with a letter written by a man who had sailed with my love on a vessel returning to Neverwinter."

"The letter said the ship had sank, and though my love had survived it was only to die from fever scant days later. My love gave his ring to the man and asked him to send it to me, asking that I wear it out of love for him. And I have."
"Pffft! And what's that got to do with Tomi?"
"You picked it off me not five minutes ago, you little runt. If you don't hand it over right now I'll cut off what passes for manhood amongst halflings and call it even."
"Oh. Heh... why, look-ee here! Could this be the ring ye were talkin' about?" Gingerly, Tomi hands the ring back to her.
"Much obliged."
"Tell me, Daelan, is it true what I hear about the Uthgardt requiring one to jump into ice-cold water once a year?"
"It is not a requirement, Sharwyn, but a celebration of the year's passing. A hole is carved in the ice and those who wish dive into the black waters."
"You can't be serious! Surely such a swim would kill a man! How could you not catch a deathly fever from such a foolhardy act?"
Daelan arches an eyebrow at her curiously. "You judge it as foolhardy but you have not even tried it?"
"I once attempted to walk across the river during the winter when I was young and fell through. It was a miracle I survived."
"We are not weighed down by clothing. And after the dive we move immediately back into warm environs to dry off. It is invigorating and joyful and not harmful at all."
Sharwyn regards Daelan with a shocked expression. "You dive into the icy water without clothing?!"
"Always without clothing, yes. The body heats itself quickly enough... it would be wet clothes that would leech our warmth. Hmmm... why do you stare at me so?"
She grins at the muscular barbarian dreamily. "Oh... just picturing you diving."
"If you like, and if we still live in the new year, I would be honored to show you. But only if you dive with me."
"Hmmm. Tempting. I'll have to think about it."
"You know, Daelan, I've met a great number of half-orcs in my day. Most of them were rude louts who reveled in their orcish blood."
"To humans we are orcs, to orcs we are humans, meaning in the end we are accepted by few. So many of my kind revel in our difference."
"And you understand that. You are far wiser than one would expect. Full of surprises, in fact."
"I am no great surprise, bard. I am a simple man who tries to maintain a noble existence."
"And that is not a surprise?" She chuckles lightly. "What about the fact that you bathe regularly? And that scent you wear..."
"I bathe because it is hygienic and an accepted practice in civilized lands. And what you smell is an ointment I prepare that repels flies which are unfortunately drawn to orcish sweat."
"Mmmm. I didn't need to know that. It smells wonderful. Like cinnamon mixed with rose petals and honey."
"I believe that is the rotaga root. Amongst the Uthgardt we also chew rotaga to prevent tooth rot."
"Just full of romantic notions, aren't you? Sigh..."
"Linu, I'm wondering... have you ever been to Evermeet?"
"Oh." Linu looks away, a bit sad. "The island where the elven nations have moved to."
"Is there another Evermeet?"
"No, of course not." Linu looks directly at Sharwyn and shakes her head. "And no, I have never been there, much as I might have liked to."
Sharwyn looks puzzled. "You wanted to go previously, but didn't? Why not?"
For a long moment, Linu struggles to find the words to speak. Finally she sighs and shrugs. "I sank the boat."
"The boat? You mean you sank the boat that was supposed to take you to Evermeet?"
Linu nods, not looking happy. "It was all a terrible accident! How was I to know the ship was to be carrying lamp oil to the island?"
"Normally that doesn't make a difference. If I might ask...?"

"Oh," Linu waves her hand irritably, "a cat had stolen my purse. Which had a mouse in it, I admit, but I was saving the poor creature. And then I tripped the steward, who had a torch... but only by accident, as the cat had scratched me and I'd jumped back..."
"Now you're just laughing at me. I'm not saying any more."
Sharwyn tries valiantly to hide her snickering. "I... I'm so sorry, Linu. That's so sad... (snort!)..."
"Linu, sometimes I think you're just too sweet for your own good. You really need to work on that."
Linu looks at Sharwyn suspiciously. "What are you talking about? There is nothing wrong with treating others kindly."
"There's plenty wrong with it. Remember that greasy fellow back at the Yawning Portal? The one you allowed to fawn all over you for three hours?"
"I asked him to stop and leave me alone. What else was I supposed to do?"
"I would have had him gone in thirty seconds." Sharwyn snaps her fingers. "Either that or he'd be a very sore man."
Linu chuckles, embarrassed. "I can't even think of what I would say! No, I could never do that."
"How about 'Listen, human, either back off or they'll be searching for your genitals somewhere in your rib cage.' It works, trust me."
"But... what if I like the gentleman and I don't want to drive him away?"
Sharwyn grins. "Now *that* is a completely different subject. We'll talk about that later... I'll need props."
"Deekin, do you realize that because of you, there have been several other kobolds coming into the civilized lands?"
"Deekin not knows that. Is that be true?"
"It is, indeed, though admittedly most of these new fellows are of more nefarious intent than yourself, or so I've heard."
"Nefarious? Is that means they smells bad?"
"No, it just means... well, it means that they're not very nice, Deekin. They're thieves and the like, working with mercenaries. Not at all adorable like you."
"You thinks Deekin is adorable?"
"How did we get onto this? We were discussing the other kobolds who have come out of the caves."
"Deekin wants to discuss how adorable he is again."
"Hmmm. Maybe we should just continue on with our journey, yes? That might be much better."
"If I might ask, Deekin... where did you learn your bardic lore? I can't imagine the kobolds have a tradition of music and folklore?"
"Nope. Deekin not learns bard stuff from kobold tribe. Deekin learns it all from Old Master."
"Hmmm. And this Old Master... he was someone amongst the humans? Some kindly stranger who took you in?"
"Nope. Old Master was big and gassy White Dragon named Tymofarrar. He keeps Deekin around so Deekin can entertains him."
"A White Dragon? I've never heard of any White Dragon who used magic."
"Old Master did. Old Master was smart, and he gots lots of books. Deekin reads all the time, that be how Deekin learns so much."
"And he taught you to play music as well?"
"No. Old Master not gots ear for music, not like Deekin. Deekin learns to play lyre on his own."
"Fascinating. You are just a pile of contradictions, my little man."
"Ummm... Deekin says thanks?"
"Never mind."
"I think we need to part ways."
"No, never mind."
"Wait here until I return."
"I need to go."
"I want to change your tactics."
"I don't want to change anything else right now."
"I want you to leave any traps that you see alone."
"I want you to disarm any traps that you see."
"I want to move faster and not bother with searching or stealth."
"I need you to be stealthy right now."
"Don't help me if I fail to open a locked door or chest."
"Help me if I fail to open a locked door or chest."
"I want to change the distance you stay away from me."
"Stay a long distance away."
"Keep a medium distance."
"Stay close."
"Go ahead and attack as soon as you see enemies."
"Defend me and don't attack until I do."
"I want to adjust your equipment."
"Can you identify my equipment?"
"I want you to use your bard song now."
"I need you to cast a group of buffing spells."
"Never mind."
"Cast all the buffing spells you have."
"Cast all the buffing spells that last a long time."
"Cast all the short duration buffing spells."
"I need you to cast a spell."
"Never mind."

"Divine Power."
"Dispel Magic."
"Death Ward."
"Death Armor."

"Continual Flame."
"Clarity."

"Bull's Strength."
"I've changed my mind."

"Cast it on <CUSTOM77108>."

"Cast it on my animal companion."
"Cast it on my familiar."
"Cast it on me."
"Cast it on yourself."
"Bless."
"Animate Dead."
"Aid."
"What was it you wanted to say earlier?"
"Let's stop and talk a moment."
"We're done talking."
"No, nothing else."
"How is everything?"
"I wish to discuss your training."
"Go back to splitting your time up between fighter and bard."
"Continue with what you're doing now."
"Focus on being a fighter."
"Focus on being a bard."
"Do you have plans for what you're going to do after all this?"
"And if you're not?"
"It was beautiful, I thought, with an interesting people."
"I'm a loner, but thanks for the offer."
"Not a chance in hell."
"No. I have my own plans."
"I might consider doing just that."
"I hated it. All sand and trudging, nothing more."
"I didn't see much of it, to be honest."
"It was nothing special."
"You said you came from Neverwinter, correct?"
"We've discussed this enough."
"So you didn't stay in Neverwinter long?"
"Why? What happened?"
"Did you know the Hero of Neverwinter?"
"What happened to <him/her>?"
"How did you help save the city?"
"That evil traitor?"
"How did it end?"
"Yes, I have."
"No, I haven't."
"No, stay here for the moment."
"Yes, come with me."
"Not right now. I'm busy."
"What is it, Sharwyn?"
"What kind of confession?"
"No. I really couldn't."
"Are you kidding! I was thinking you'd never ask!"
"I don't know. I barely know you."
"Maybe. Given enough time."
"Are you joking?"
"I see. Let's move on."
"Umm... yes, well... that was uncomfortable."
"Thank you, Sharwyn."
"Mind your own business."
"No, I've never been there before."
"Why do you ask?"
"It's none of your business, Sharwyn."
"I haven't thought about it."
"Wouldn't you like to know?"
"I don't have the reward money yet."
"I suppose maybe there's a few things..."
"A great theater of the arts!"
"I would give as much as I could spare to those in need."
"I might build a castle, I suppose."
"I would build a church to honor my god."
"A magical laboratory in a tower, perhaps."
"I'm not sure. A monastery somewhere quiet?"
"Maybe a huge mansion in Waterdeep."
"Some new shoes, maybe."
"I'd rather not discuss it."
"I suppose you're right. I was at Drogan's school in Hilltop."
"Master Drogan is dead. I'd rather not discuss him."
"I said no and I meant it."
"No, you've mistaken me for someone else."
"Leave it be. I mean it."
"Yes, that's right. He ran a school in Hilltop."
"You knew him?"
"So you knew him for just a short time...."
"No, never."
"I had my chance."
"Yes, I think I would."
"I already am a Harper."
"The Harpers? What's that?"
"Drogan tried to recruit you into the Harpers?"
"Being a little impatient, are we?"
"Pull yourself together! I don't need to listen to any whining."
"Don't worry, we'll be fine."
"You aren't scared of what's going to happen, are you?"
"You can go back to the inn, if you like."
"I think you're whining."
"Not really, no."
"But I did find you. Your story isn't over yet."
"I think so."
"It can only take me to places I've already been."
"Maybe so. What's it to you?"
"Useless? Are you crazy?"
"Actually, it's quite useful if you think about it."
"What do you know about my relic?"
"We don't need it to get past anything in our way."
"You don't need to come with me. Go back to the inn."
"Why are you getting upset?"
"At least we're making progress."
"Well, mind your own business."
"Enough. Let's move on."
"Sleeping? They look pretty dead to me."
"What do you know about this place?"
"Let's move on, then."
"They look like they're pretty wealthy for being dead..."
"Is there any danger here?"
"There's nothing honorable about this place."
"Fine. Talk about it later."
"Is there any danger here?"
"What do you know about it?"
"All right, let's go."
"Anything else I should know?"
"Is this Mirror of Opposition very valuable?"
"How can you tell that one apart?"
"There are famous parts of Undermountain?"
"Never mind that. Let's move on."
"Tell me about this Hall of Mirrors."
"Do you know much about Halaster?"
"You actually want to meet him?"
"I'd just want some of his power."
"Maybe that would be interesting, yes."
"You're crazy!"
"You think this dungeon gets re-arranged?"
"Yes, let's go."
"No, just stay here for now."
"And it shows, too, let me tell you."
